analyzed: tathā ca bīja aṅkura ādayaḥ ṅkura ādibhyaḥ bījam iti anavasthā
translated: And likewise, seeds and sprouts, sprouts and so on from seeds - an infinite regress.

analyzed: bhāti ca atra ādisarge paramāṇu mātrāt api bīja prādurbhāvaḥ tathā śarīra karmaṇoḥ anavasthā
translated: And here, in the initial creation, the manifestation of seeds from atoms and so on, and the infinite regress of body and action, are illuminated.

analyzed: idānīm api ca ādisarge ca adhikāra mātra vaśāt śarīra utpattiḥ syāt
translated: And now, even in the initial creation, the origination of the body would be due to the power of eligibility alone.

analyzed: sādhāraṇa vigraha tva prasaṃgaḥ iti ced syāt etat
translated: If it is argued that there would be the undesirable consequence of having a common body, this may be said:

original: yadyadhikāranimittā śarīrotpattirādisarge 'bhyupagamyate prāptamekena śarīreṇa sarvapuruṣāṇāmabhisambandho niyamahetvabhāvāt /
analyzed: yadi adhikāra nimittā śarīra utpattiḥ ādisarge bhyupagamyate prāptam ekena śarīreṇa sarva puruṣāṇām abhisambandhaḥ niyama hetu abhāvāt
translated: If the origination of the body due to the cause of eligibility is accepted in the initial creation, it follows that all persons are connected with one body, because there is no cause for restriction.

analyzed: tatas ca śarīra antara ānarthakyam
translated: And from that, the body is purposeless.

analyzed: tena eva sarveṣām upabhoga sāmarthyāt iti
translated: Because all can experience through that alone.

analyzed: etat anupapannam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt pratyakṣa virodhāt
translated: Why? Because of contradiction with perception.

analyzed: satyam etat anumānataḥ
translated: This is true according to inference.

analyzed: pratyakṣatas tu śarīrāṇi pratipuruṣam
translated: But according to perception, there are bodies for each person.

analyzed: tasmāt na ayam prasaṃgaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is not the undesirable consequence.

original: apavarganiyamaprasaṃga iti cet syānmataṃ yadyadhikāramātravaśāccharīrotpattiḥ paramarṣerevāpavargasādhanaṃ śarīrādutpadyeteti /
analyzed: apavarga niyama prasaṃgaḥ iti ced syāt matam yadi adhikāra mātra vaśāt śarīra utpattiḥ parama ṛṣeḥ eva apavarga sādhanam śarīrāt utpadyeta iti
translated: If it is argued that there would be the undesirable consequence of restriction to final liberation, it may be thought that if the origination of the body is due to the power of eligibility alone, then the means of final liberation would originate from the body of the supreme sage alone.

analyzed: ucyate na tasya eva
translated: It is said that it is not of him alone.

original: kiṃ tarhi sarveṣāṃ guṇānāṃ prādhānyāttannimittāni śarīrāṇyādisarge sāṃsiddhikānyutpadyante /
analyzed: kim tarhi sarveṣām guṇānām prādhānyāt tad nimittāni śarīrāṇi ādisarge sāṃsiddhikāni utpadyante
translated: What then? Due to the predominance of all the qualities, the bodies that are the causes of those [qualities] are spontaneously produced at the beginning of creation.

original: tatra yasya sattvapradhānaṃ kāryakaraṇaṃ sa paramarṣiḥ /
analyzed: tatra yasya sattva pradhānam kārya karaṇam sa parama ṛṣiḥ
translated: Among them, he who has a body and organs with sattva as the predominant quality is the supreme sage.

analyzed: yasya sattvam rajaḥ bahulam sa māhātmya śarīraḥ
translated: He who has sattva with rajas as the predominant quality is the one with a body of greatness.

original: evaṃ guṇasamparkād guṇapradhānāpradhānabhāvena yāvatsthāvaraśarīraprādurbhāva ityato nāsti guṇānāṃ śarīraviniyogapakṣapātaḥ /
analyzed: evam guṇa samparkāt guṇa pradhāna apradhāna bhāvena yāvat sthāvara śarīra prādurbhāvaḥ iti atas na asti guṇānām śarīra viniyoga pakṣapātaḥ
translated: Thus, due to the contact of the qualities, by the predominance and non-predominance of the qualities, up to the appearance of the bodies of inanimate beings. Therefore, the qualities do not have a bias towards being employed in bodies.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam etat kṛtaka tvāt na karma jagat kāraṇam iti
translated: Therefore, this is correct: The world is not produced from karma because it is produced.

analyzed: etena ca evam vyākhyām
translated: And this is explained in the same way.

analyzed: tat api hi karmaṇām eva prāpta paripākāṇām abhidhānam artha antaram eva iti ced sādhyam
translated: If it is argued that this is also a statement of only those karmas whose ripening has been attained, it is to be established that it is a different meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt api akalpanīyam iti
translated: Therefore, it is also to be imagined.

analyzed: yat api uktam kālāt jagat utpattiḥ bhaviṣyati iti tat anupapannam
translated: What was said - that the world will be produced from time - that is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt kāraṇa parispandasya eva tad abhidhāna sanniveśāt
translated: Why? Because that is the arrangement of the statement of the very activity of the cause.

original: na hi naḥ kālo nāma kaścidasti /
analyzed: na hi naḥ kālaḥ nāma kaścid asti
translated: For us, there is no such thing as time.

analyzed: kim tarhi kriyamāṇa kriyāṇām eva āditya gati godoha ghaṭa āstanita ādīnām viśiṣṭa avadhi sarūpa pratyaya nimitta tvat
translated: What then? The cause of the cognition of difference in the case of actions being performed, such as the motion of the sun, the milking of a cow, the pot, the thunder, etc., is the specific limit.

analyzed: para apara ādi liṅga sadbhāvāt pratipattiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the cognition is due to the presence of the gender of far and near, etc., it is not so.

analyzed: akṛtakeṣu tad anupapatteḥ
translated: Because that is not possible in what is uncreated.

original: yadeva kṛtakaṃ tatraiva paramaparamityādiḥ pratyayo dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yat eva kṛtakam tatra eva param aparam ityādiḥ pratyayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: The cognition of far and near, etc., is seen only in what is created.

analyzed: sa yadi kriyā vyatirikta nimittaḥ syāt aviśeṣāt nitya anityeṣu syāt
translated: If that were the cause of something other than action, it would occur in the eternal and non-eternal without distinction.

original: kvacitsāmarthādapākajavadadoṣa iti cet syānmatam yathāgnisaṃyogaḥ pākajahetuḥ tathā cāviśeṣe 'pi pṛthivyāmeva pākajotpattinimittaṃ bhavati
analyzed: kvacid sāmarthāt apākaja vat adoṣaḥ iti ced syāt matam yathā agni saṃyogaḥ pāka ja hetuḥ tathā ca aviśeṣe pi pṛthivyām eva pāka ja utpatti nimittam bhavati
translated: If it is argued that there is no fault anywhere due to capability, like in the non-cooked, it may be thought that just as the conjunction with fire is the cause of the cooked, and even though there is no distinction, the cause of the origin of the cooked occurs only in earth,

analyzed: na ākāśa ādiṣu
translated: not in space, etc.

original: evaṃ kālo 'pi parāparādiheturatha cānityeṣveva syānna nityeṣviti /
analyzed: evam para apara ādi hetuḥ atha ca anityeṣu eva syāt na nityeṣu iti
translated: In the same way, time is the cause of far and near, etc., and yet it occurs only in the non-eternal, not in the eternal.

analyzed: tat ca ayuktam
translated: And that is not proper.

analyzed: kasmāt viśeṣa upapatteḥ
translated: Why? Because the distinction is possible.

original: rūpādivikriyāheturagnistadyuktaṃ yadasau tadvati dravye pākajānādadyāt / nā
analyzed: rūpa ādi vikriyā hetuḥ agniḥ tat yuktam yat asau tadvati dravye pāka jān ādadyāt na
translated: It is proper that fire, the cause of the modification of form, etc., would produce the cooked, etc., in a substance where it exists,

analyzed: tadvati ākāśa ādau
translated: not in space, etc., where it does not exist.

analyzed: kālaḥ tu sambandha mātra upakārī na vikriyā hetuḥ
translated: But time only aids the relation, it is not the cause of modification.

analyzed: tasmāt asat etat
translated: Therefore, this is false.

original: evaṃ yadi kriyābhyo 'nyaḥ kāla iṣyate kāraṇaparispandasya jagatkāraṇatvamathānyatsādhyam /
analyzed: evam yadi kriyābhyaḥ nyaḥ kālaḥ iṣyate kāraṇa parispandasya jagat kāraṇa tvam atha anyat sādhyam
translated: Thus, if time is considered to be different from actions, the cause is the activity of the cause of the world, or something else is to be accomplished.

analyzed: yadṛcchā api na kāraṇam karma vat kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt
translated: Chance is also not a cause, like karma, because of the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhūtam hi idam vyaktam iti prāk vyākhyātam
translated: For this manifest is said to have the relation of cause and effect, as explained before.

original: sa ca kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ prekṣāpūrvakṛtānāṃ śayanādīnāmupalabdhau yādṛcchikeṣu cānupalabdhau na tasyā liṅgamiti śakyaṃ vaktum /
analyzed: sa ca kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ prekṣā pūrva kṛtānām śayana ādīnām upalabdhau yādṛcchikeṣu ca anupalabdhau na tasyāḥ liṅgam iti śakyam vaktum
translated: And that relation of cause and effect can be said to be the reason for the perception of things like beds made with foresight, and for the non-perception in chance occurrences.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ pi akāraṇam
translated: Non-existence is also not a cause.

analyzed: parimāṇa ādi darśanāt
translated: Because of the perception of size and so on.

original: na hi tata utpannānāṃ parimāṇamupapadyata ityato nāpyanvayaḥ /
analyzed: na hi tatas utpannānām parimāṇam upapadyate iti atas na api anvayaḥ
translated: For the size of those produced from that is not possible, therefore there is no concomitance either.

analyzed: sātmaka nirātmakayoḥ atyanta jāti bhedāt
translated: Because there is a complete difference in kind between that which has a self and that which does not.

analyzed: nā api śaktiḥ tad abhāvāt
translated: Nor is there power, because of the absence of that.

analyzed: na upakāraḥ nava sthānāt
translated: There is no benefit, because of infinite regress.

analyzed: na vibhāgaḥ nirātmaka tvāt
translated: There is no division, because of the absence of a self.

analyzed: tasmāt na paramāṇu puruṣa īśvara karma daiva kāla svabhāva yadṛcchā bhāvebhyaḥ vyaktam utpadyate
translated: Therefore, the manifest is not produced from atoms, Purusha, God, karma, destiny, time, nature, chance, or non-existence.

analyzed: na ced ebhyaḥ
translated: And if it is not from these,

analyzed: pariśeṣataḥ pradhānasya eva astitva liṅgam idam
translated: this is an inference for the existence of the primordial nature by elimination.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam etat bhedānām parimāṇa ādibhyaḥ kāraṇam asti avyaktam iti
translated: Therefore, it is correct that the unmanifest exists as the cause of the limited manifestations due to their finitude and so on.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: Kārikā

analyzed: āha evam api asya vyakta hetu tvam anupapannam ekatvāt
translated: Even so, the origination of this [unmanifest] from the manifest is not tenable, because of oneness.

analyzed: bahūnām kārya ārambhaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ tantu ādīnām
translated: The origination of many effects is seen from many causes like threads and so on.

analyzed: ekam pradhānam
translated: But the primordial nature is one.

analyzed: tasmāt na tad ārambha śakti yuktam iti
translated: Therefore, it is not endowed with the power to originate that [manifest].

analyzed: ucyate yadi api guṇānām pradhāna lakṣaṇam avasthā antaram abhinna buddhi nimitta tvāt ekam api  kārya kāle kiṃcid vaiṣamya upajanita vyapadeśya rūpābhiḥ itaretara upakāriṇībhiḥ śaktibhiḥ
translated: It is said that even though the qualities have a different state characterized by the primordial nature, which is the cause of the single cognition,

analyzed: smudāya tvam āpadyate
translated: at the time of the effect, some [qualities] attain the state of a collection through the powers that are mutually helpful, which have been produced by the generation of a slight inequality and have different forms that can be designated.

analyzed: tasmāt idānīm
translated: Therefore, now

analyzed: pravartate triguṇataḥ samudayāt ca
translated: it originates from the three qualities and from the collection.

analyzed: pravartate iti anena utpattim ācaṣṭe
translated: By it originates, it describes the origination.

analyzed: triguṇataḥ iti avyapadeśya rūpāṇām pradhāna apradhāna bhāvena guṇa śaktīnām vaiṣamyāt vyapadeśya rūpa antaram āha
translated: By from the three qualities, it mentions the different forms that can be designated due to the inequality of the powers of the qualities, which are the cause of the primordial nature and are not the cause of the primordial nature.

original: yatraitacchakyate vaktuṃ trayaḥ sattvādaya iti tadavasthānaṃ kāryārambhakamiti /
analyzed: yatra etat śakyate vaktum trayaḥ sattva ādayaḥ iti tad avasthānam kārya ārambhakam iti
translated: That state in which it is possible to say the three, sattva and so on, is the cause of the origination of the effect.

analyzed: samudayāt iti anena paraspara apekṣāṇām ārambha śaktim avadyotayati
translated: By from the assemblage he illuminates the power of origination of those that are mutually dependent.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati kāryakāle guṇāḥ parityaktapūrvāvasthā bhedaṃ pratilabhya parasparopakāreṇa saṃhanyate /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati kārya kāle guṇāḥ parityakta pūrva avasthāḥ bhedam pratilabhya paraspara upakāreṇa saṃhanyate
translated: This is what is said: at the time of the effect, the qualities, having abandoned their previous state, attain difference and are combined by mutual assistance.

analyzed: saṃhatāḥ ca vyaktam utpādayanti
translated: And being combined, they produce the manifest.

analyzed: tasmāt na avasthā antarasya abhinna buddhi nimitta tvāt pradhāna ekatva doṣaḥ guṇa bhedāt na ekasya kārya ārambhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because the cause of the non-difference of the different states is not the oneness of primordial matter, and because the effect is not produced by one due to the difference of the qualities,

analyzed: āha niṣkriya tvāt tarhi prakṛteḥ kārya ārambhaḥ nu papannaḥ
translated: he says: But then, the origination of the effect is not possible because primordial matter is inactive.

analyzed: kriyā tva anabhyupagame vā vyakta vaidharmya virodhaḥ iti
translated: Or, if activity is not accepted, there is contradiction with the difference in properties of the manifest.

analyzed: ucyate na kriyā vaidharmya bhedāt
translated: It is said: No, because of the difference in the absence of activity.

original: dvividhā hi kriyā praspandalakṣaṇā pariṇāmalakṣaṇā ca /
analyzed: dvividhā hi kriyā praspanda lakṣaṇā pariṇāma lakṣaṇā ca
translated: For activity is of two kinds: characterized by motion and characterized by transformation.

analyzed: tatra praspandaḥ pradhānasya saukṣmyāt pratiṣidhyate  pariṇāmataḥ
translated: Among them, motion is denied in primordial matter because of its subtlety.

analyzed: tu tat kāryam ārabhate iti
translated: But it produces its effect through transformation.

original: āha nanu ca pariṇāmo 'pi saukṣmyātpradhānasya nopapadyate /
analyzed: āha nanu ca saukṣmyāt pradhānasya na upapadyate
translated: He says: But transformation also is not possible in primordial matter because of its subtlety.

original: kasmāt / na hi saukṣmyātsūkṣmasyākāśādervipariṇāmo dṛṣṭa iti /
analyzed: kasmāt na hi saukṣmyāt sūkṣmasya ākāśa ādeḥ vipariṇāmaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti
translated: Why? Because the transformation of the subtle, such as space, is not seen due to subtlety.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: saṃskārasya saukṣmye pi pariṇāmaḥ abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Even in the subtlety of the conditioned, transformation must be accepted.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktaḥ sūkṣma pariṇāmī iti
translated: Therefore, it is appropriate to say it is subtle and transforming.

analyzed: āha kaḥ punar ayam pariṇāmaḥ nāma
translated: It is said: What, then, is this so-called transformation?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: jahat dharma antaram pūrvam ādatte yadā param
translated: When abandoning one dharma and taking up another,

original: tattvādapracyuto dharmī pariṇāmaḥ sa ucyate // iti /
analyzed: tattvāt apracyutaḥ dharmī pariṇāmaḥ saḥ ucyate iti
translated: the possessor of dharma, not deviating from its nature, is said to be transformed.

original: yadā śaktyantarānugrahātpūrvadharmān tirobhāvya svarūpādapracyuto dharmī dharmāntareṇāvirbhavati tadavasthānamasmākaṃ pariṇāma ityucyate /
analyzed: yadā śakti antara anugrahāt pūrva dharmān tirobhāvya svarūpāt apracyutaḥ dharmī dharma antareṇa āvirbhavati tat avasthānam asmākam pariṇāmaḥ iti ucyate
translated: When, by the grace of another potentiality, the possessor of dharma, not deviating from its own nature, manifests another dharma after obscuring the previous dharma, that state is said by us to be transformation.

analyzed: āha na etat abhidhāna mātram dṛṣṭāntam antareṇa pratipadyāmahe
translated: It is said: We do not understand this mere statement without an example.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā kim iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it should be said what it is like.

original: ucyate yathā pālāśaṃ palāśādapracyutanimittāntarasyātapāderanugrahācchyāmatāṃ tirobhāvya pītatāṃ vrajati tathedaṃ draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: ucyate yathā pālāśam palāśāt apracyuta nimitta antarasya ātapa ādeḥ anugrahāt śyāma tām tirobhāvya pīta tām vrajati tathā idam draṣṭavyam
translated: It is said: It should be seen as like a palasha tree, which, by the grace of another cause such as sunlight, not deviating from its own nature, goes from yellowness to redness after obscuring blackness.

analyzed: āha na anyathā utpatteḥ apratiṣedhāt
translated: It is said: No, because the arising in another way is not refuted.

original: kathaṃ punaretavagamyate pālāśaṃ svarūpādapracyutaṃ dharmāntarasya parityāgamupādānaṃ ca karoti /
analyzed: katham punar etad avagamyate pālāśam svarūpāt a pracyutam dharma antarasya parityāgam upādānam ca karoti
translated: How is it understood that the palāśa wood, not departing from its own nature, abandons one property and takes up another,

analyzed: na punar anyathā ca anyathā ca upapadyate iti
translated: and does not arise in one way and cease in another way?

original: ucyate kṣaṇabhaṅgapratiṣedhāt prāgeva kṣaṇabhaṅganirdiṣṭaṃ vinaṣṭānāṃ bhāvānāṃ punarutpattau nāsti kāraṇam /
analyzed: ucyate kṣaṇa bhaṅga pratiṣedhāt prāk eva kṣaṇa bhaṅga nirdiṣṭam vinaṣṭānām bhāvānām punarutpattau na asti kāraṇam
translated: It is said: Before the refutation of momentariness, it has already been shown that there is no cause for the re-arising of destroyed entities.

analyzed: tad abhāve ca utpattiḥ ayuktā iti
translated: And in the absence of that, arising is not tenable.

analyzed: āha dharma dharmiṇoḥ ananyatva abhyupagamāt dharma utpatti vināśe dharmi utpatti vināśa prasaṃgaḥ
translated: It is said: Because the property and the possessor of the property are accepted as non-different, there would be the undesirable consequence that when the property arises or ceases, the possessor of the property also arises or ceases.

analyzed: na hi vaḥ dharmebhyaḥ nyaḥ dharmī
translated: For you, the possessor of the property is not different from the properties.

original: tatra yadi dharmasya nivṛttirabhyupagamyate dharmiṇo 'pi nivṛttirananyatvātprāptā /
analyzed: tatra yadi dharmasya nivṛttiḥ abhyupagamyate dharmiṇaḥ u pi nivṛttiḥ ananyatvāt prāptā
translated: If the cessation of the property is accepted there, the cessation of the possessor of the property is also obtained due to non-difference.

analyzed: dharma utpattau tad utpattiḥ
translated: When the property arises, it arises.

analyzed: tatra yat uktam dharma utpatti virodhe dharmī svarūpa avasthānam iti etat ayuktam
translated: Regarding that, what was said - that in the contradiction of the arising of the property, the possessor of the property remains in its own nature - that is not correct.

analyzed: ucyate na senā ādi vat vyavasthāna upapatteḥ
translated: It is said: No, because the arrangement is tenable like an army and so on.

analyzed: tat yathā senā aṅgebhyaḥ na anya tvam senāyāḥ
translated: Just as an army is not different from the parts of an army,

analyzed: na ca senā aṅgānām vināśe senā vināśaḥ
translated: And the destruction of the army is not the destruction of the parts of the army.

analyzed: tat yathā na anyaḥ paṭaḥ
translated: For example, a cloth is not different from the threads.

analyzed: bauddhānām saṃyoga avayavi pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because the Buddhists deny conjunction and wholes.

analyzed: na ca paṭa vināśe tantu vināśaḥ
translated: And the destruction of the cloth is not the destruction of the threads.

original: tatra yaduktaṃ dharmivināśe dharmavināśa iti etadayuktam /
analyzed: tatra yat uktam dharmi vināśe dharma vināśaḥ iti etat ayuktam
translated: Therefore, what was said - that when the substratum is destroyed, the property is destroyed - is not correct.

analyzed: āha evam api ayuktam
translated: He says: Even so, it is not correct.

analyzed: tat kasmāt sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ dharmi svarūpa parikalpanā anupapatteḥ
translated: Why is that? Because it is not possible to conceive of the general and the particular as the nature of the substratum.

original: iha rūpādisāmānyaṃ vā dharmirūpatvena parikalpyamānaṃ parikalpyeta rūpādiviśeṣo vā / kiṃ cātaḥ /
analyzed: iha rūpa ādi sāmānyam vā dharmi rūpa tvena parikalpyamānam parikalpyeta rūpa ādi viśeṣaḥ vā kim ca atas
translated: Here, if the general of form, etc. is conceived as the nature of the substratum, is it conceived as the general of form, etc. or as the particular of form, etc.? What follows from that?

analyzed: tatra tāvat rūpa ādi sāmānyam dharmi svarūpam iti śakyam kalpayitum
translated: First, it is possible to conceive the general of form, etc. as the nature of the substratum.

analyzed: kasmāt asambhavāt
translated: Why? Because it is not possible.

original: yadi tāvatpṛthivī sāmānyaṃ ghaṭādirviśeṣastena pṛthivyapi tanmātrāpekṣayā viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yadi tāvat pṛthivī sāmānyam ghaṭa ādiḥ viśeṣaḥ tena pṛthivī api tanmātra apekṣayā viśeṣaḥ
translated: If the earth is the general and the pot, etc. are the particular, then the earth is also a particular in relation to that mere element.

analyzed: yāvat pradhānam iti na asti sāmānyam
translated: Up to the primordial matter, there is no general.
Due to the absence of that, there is no nature of the substratum.

analyzed: atha viśeṣāḥ ghaṭa ādayaḥ teṣām viśeṣa antareṇa saha avasthānāt dharmi svarūpa anavasthānāt
translated: Or if the particular pots, etc. are the nature of the substratum, due to their remaining in a state of mutual dependence, there is no stability of the nature of the substratum.

original: tataśca yaduktaṃ svarūpādapracyuto dharmī dharmāntaraṃ vijahāti /🔽dharmāntaramupādatte iti tadvyāhanyata iti /
analyzed: tatas ca yat uktam svarūpāt apracyutaḥ dharmī dharma antaram vijahāti  dharma antaram upādatte iti tat vyāhanyate iti
translated: And therefore, what was said - that a subject does not depart from its own nature when it abandons one property and takes up another property - that is contradicted.

analyzed: ucyate yat uktam rūpa ādi sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ dharmi svarūpa parikalpanā anupapattiḥ iti
translated: It is said that what was said - that it is not possible to conceive of the general and specific properties as the nature of the subject -

analyzed: astu sāmānyam
translated: let there be the general.

original: yattūktaṃ sāmānyaṃ sāmānyāntarāpekṣaṃ viśeṣatvamiti na pratyayanivṛttau sāmānyābhāvāvasthitestataśca dharmisvarūpasiddheḥ /
analyzed: yat tu uktam sāmānyam sāmānya antara apekṣam viśeṣa tvam iti na pratyaya nivṛttau sāmānya abhāva avasthiteḥ tatas ca dharmi svarūpa siddheḥ
translated: But what was said - that the general depends on another general, and is specific - is not the case. Because the general does not cease to exist when the specific is removed. And from that, the nature of the subject is established.

original: yāvatpṛthivītyayaṃ pratyayo na nivartate sāmānyaṃ ghaṭādirviśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yāvat pṛthivī iti ayam pratyayaḥ na nivartate sāmānyam ghaṭa ādiḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: As long as the cognition earth does not cease, the general is the pot, etc., and the specific is the substance.

analyzed: dravya tvam ca asau  dharma antara parivarteṣu tad ākāra pratyaya utpattitaḥ svarūpa avasthāna siddheḥ dharmāḥ ghaṭa ādayaḥ
translated: And that is the substance.🔽And when there is a change in the other properties, the cognition of that form arises, and the existence of the nature is established. Therefore, the properties are the pot, etc.

original: yadā tu pṛthivīpratyayanivṛttistadā tanmātrāṇāṃ sāmānyabhāvo dravyatvaṃ ca viśeṣo dharma iti yāvatpradhānaṃ tasya tu sāmānyāntarānupapatteḥ
analyzed: yadā tu pṛthivī pratyaya nivṛttiḥ tadā tanmātrāṇām sāmānya bhāvaḥ dravya tvam ca viśeṣaḥ dharmaḥ iti yāvat pradhānam tasya tu sāmānya antara anupapatteḥ
translated: But when the cognition of earth ceases, then the general existence of those is substance, and the specific is the property. As far as the primordial matter, but for that, another general is not possible.

analyzed: kauṭasthyam eva
translated: Therefore, it is only unchanging.

analyzed: yatra sarva viśeṣa abhāvaḥ tat pradhānam
translated: Where there is the absence of all specificities, that is the primordial matter.

original: yadi tu pṛthivyādīnāṃ nityamavyāvṛtaṃ sati kauṭasthyameṣāṃ prāptam /
analyzed: yadi tu pṛthivī ādīnām nityam avyāvṛtam sati kauṭasthyam eṣām prāptam
translated: But if it is argued that the earth and so on are always unobstructed, then their immutability would follow.

analyzed: tasmāt na dharmi svarūpa abhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no absence of the nature of the substratum.

analyzed: śakteḥ vā sāmānya bhāva abhyupagamāt
translated: Or because the potentiality is accepted as a universal.

original: athavā sukhaduḥkhamohaśaktaya eveha mahadādinā viśeṣāntena liṅgena pariṇāmaṃ pratipadyante /
analyzed: athavā sukha duḥkha moha śaktayaḥ eva iha mahat ādinā viśeṣa antena liṅgena pariṇāmam pratipadyante
translated: Or else, the potencies of pleasure, pain, and delusion alone undergo transformation here through the linga (indicator) beginning with Mahat (the Great One) up to Viśeṣa (Distinction).

original: tāsāṃ ca satataṃ sāmānyapratyayanimittatvātsvarūpādapracyute taddravyatvaṃ liṅgasya dharmatvam /
analyzed: tāsām ca satatam sāmānya pratyaya nimitta tvāt svarūpāt apracyute tat dravya tvam liṅgasya dharma tvam
translated: And because those (potencies) are always the cause of the notion of universality, they do not deviate from their own nature, and that substantiality is the property of the indicator.

analyzed: aprasiddheḥ ayuktam iti ced na ukta tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is not proper because it is not well-known, it is not so, because it has been stated.

analyzed: prāk uktam etat sukha ādi pūrvakam viśvam iti
translated: This has been stated earlier that the universe is preceded by pleasure and so on.

analyzed: āha evam api vaiśvarūpya anupapattiḥ
translated: Even so, it is said that the diversity of forms is not possible.

analyzed: kāraṇa viśeṣāt
translated: Because of the particular cause.

original: yadi sukhādiśaktaya eva pariṇāminyo yadidaṃ brahmādi sthāvarāntaṃ vaiśvarūpyaṃ tannopapadyate /
analyzed: yadi sukha ādi śaktayaḥ eva pariṇāminyaḥ yat idam brahma ādi sthāvara antam vaiśvarūpyam tat na upapadyate
translated: If the transforming potencies of pleasure and so on alone are the cause, then this diversity of forms ranging from Brahman down to the inanimate objects is not possible.

analyzed: kasmāt na hi abhinnam kāryam utpadyate iti
translated: Why? Because a non-different effect is not produced.

analyzed: ucyate śaktitaḥ ca pariṇāmini
translated: It is said that it is due to the potentiality and the transforming nature.

analyzed: bhavati tena vaiśvarūpyam katham
translated: By that, there is diversity of forms. How?

analyzed: salila vat prati prati guṇa āśraya viśeṣāt
translated: Like water, due to the difference in the substratum of each quality.

analyzed: yathā antarikṣa a viśiṣṭasya ambhasaḥ pracyutiḥ āśrayeṇa go bhujaṅgama uṣṭra ādīnām  viśeṣāt kṣīra mūtra viṣa ādi vaiśvarūpyam ca upapadyate
translated: Just as the water, which is not different from the atmosphere, falls down with its substratum, and becomes milk, urine, poison, etc. in the cows, snakes, camels, etc. due to the difference in the substratum, and thus the diversity of milk, urine, poison, etc. is possible.

original: tathā guṇaśaktayo viśiṣṭāḥ parasparāśrayaviśeṣād brahmādi stambāntaṃ jātyākṛtivāgbuddhisvabhāvāhāravihārarūpaṃ vaiśvarūpyaṃ pratipadyante /
analyzed: tathā guṇa śaktayaḥ viśiṣṭāḥ paraspara āśraya viśeṣāt brahma ādi stamba antam jāti ākṛti vāc buddhi svabhāva āhāra vihāra rūpam vaiśvarūpyam pratipadyante
translated: Similarly, the specific powers of the gunas, due to the difference in the specific substratum, attain the diversity of form ranging from Brahman to a clump of grass, with their respective species, shapes, speech, intellect, nature, food, and behavior.

analyzed: tasmāt siddham etat prakṛtiḥ eva sarva bhāvanām prasavitrī
translated: Therefore, it is established that primordial matter alone is the cause of all modifications.

analyzed: na ca kaścid doṣaḥ iti
translated: And no fault is incurred.

analyzed: yuktidīpikāyām sāṃkhyasaptatipaddhatau caturtham āhnikam
translated: In the Yuktidipika, in the path of the Sāṃkhyasaptati, the fourth chapter.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: Kārikā

analyzed: āha samadhigatam pradhānam
translated: It is said: Primordial matter has been understood.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ idānīm kārya kāraṇa vyatiriktaḥ sti iti etat pratipādyam
translated: Now it is to be established that the puruṣa exists apart from the effect and the cause.

original: kutaḥ saṃśaya iti cet anupalabhyamānasyobhayathā dṛṣṭatvādityuktam /
analyzed: kutas saṃśayaḥ iti ced anupalabhyamānasya ubhayathā dṛṣṭa tvāt iti uktam
translated: If it is asked why there is doubt, it has been said that what is not perceived is seen in both ways.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

analyzed: ācārya vipratipatteḥ
translated: Due to the disagreement of the teachers.

original: vijñānaskandhavyatirikto nāsti kaścidartha iti śākyaputrīyāḥ pratipannāḥ /
analyzed: vijñāna skandha vyatiriktaḥ na asti kaścid arthaḥ iti śākyaputrīyāḥ pratipannāḥ
translated: The Śākya sons have accepted that there is no object at all apart from the aggregate of consciousness.

analyzed: kasmāt sarva pramāṇa anupalabdheḥ
translated: Why? Because it is not perceived by any means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: iha yat asti tat pratyakṣa ādinā pramāṇena upalabhyate
translated: Here, what exists is perceived by means of valid knowledge such as perception.

analyzed: tat yathā rūpa ādi
translated: For example, form and so on.

analyzed: tatas ca tāvat ayam ātmā na pratyakṣataḥ upalabhyate
translated: And therefore, this self is not perceived by perception.

analyzed: kasmāt a śabda ādi lakṣaṇāt
translated: Why? Because it has characteristics different from sound and so on.

analyzed: na antar pratyakṣataḥ
translated: Not by internal perception.

analyzed: kasmāt triguṇa ādi viparītasya tad aviṣaya tvāt
translated: Why? Because what is contrary to the three qualities and so on is not its object.

analyzed: na pūrvavat śeṣavadbhyām
translated: Not by analogy with the prior or the subsequent.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because cause and effect are not possible.

analyzed: na ca sāmānyatodṛṣṭāt
translated: And not by inference from general observation.

analyzed: dharma sāmānya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no common property.

analyzed: na āpta vacanāt
translated: Not from the words of a reliable person.

analyzed: anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is not accepted.

analyzed: na hi bauddhānām śruti smṛti purāṇa itihāsāḥ pramāṇam
translated: For the Buddhists, the Vedas, Smritis, Puranas and Itihasas are not valid means of knowledge.

original: yaścaiṣāmāgamaḥ / sa evamāha🔽ātmaiva hyātmano nāsti viparītena kalpyate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca eṣām āgamaḥ saḥ evam āha  ātmā eva hi ātmanaḥ na asti viparītena kalpyate
translated: And their scriptures say:🔽The self itself does not exist, it is imagined to be the opposite.

analyzed: na eva iha sattvam ātmā asti dharmāḥ tu ete sa hetukāḥ
translated: There is no self or being here, but these phenomena have causes.

analyzed: dvādaśa eva tava aṅgāni skandha āyatana dhātavaḥ
translated: You have only twelve factors, aggregates, sense bases and elements.

analyzed: vicintya sarvāṇi etāni pudgalaḥ na upalabhyate
translated: Having examined all these, the individual is not perceived.

analyzed: śūnyam ādhyātmikam viddhi śūnyam paśya bahis gatam
translated: Know the internal to be empty, see the external as empty.

original: na dṛśyate so 'pi kaścidyo bhāvayati śūnyatām //
analyzed: na dṛśyate saḥ u pi kaścid yaḥ bhāvayati śūnyatām
translated: Even that one who cultivates emptiness is not seen.

analyzed: punar api āha asti karma asti vipākaḥ
translated: Again, it is said: There is karma, there is result,

analyzed: kārakaḥ tu na upalabhyate yaḥ imān svān dharmān ākṣipati
translated: but the doer is not perceived, who projects these his own dharmas

analyzed: anyān ca prati sandadhāti
translated: and connects with others.

analyzed: anyatra dharma saṃketāt
translated: Except for the convention of dharmas.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva pramāṇa anupalabdheḥ na asti ātmā iti
translated: Therefore, because no means of knowledge perceives it, the self does not exist.

original: ucyate yattāvaduktaṃ pratyakṣataḥ pūrvavaccheṣavadbhyāṃ cātmano nopalabdhiriti /
analyzed: ucyate yat tāvat uktam pratyakṣataḥ pūrvavat śeṣavadbhyām ca ātmanaḥ na upalabdhiḥ iti
translated: It is said: As for what was said, that the self is not perceived by direct perception, inference, or analogy,

analyzed: satyam etat
translated: this is true.

analyzed: yat tu uktam sāmānyatodṛṣṭāt anupalabdhiḥ ātma sāmānya anupapatteḥ iti
translated: But what was said, that its non-perception is due to the impossibility of the generality of the self,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: saṃghāta para artha tvāt
translated: Because of the purposefulness of the aggregate.

analyzed: iha saṃghātāḥ para arthāḥ dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: Here, aggregates are seen to have a purpose for something else.

analyzed: tat yathā śayana āsana ratha caraṇa ādayaḥ
translated: For example, like beds, seats, chariots, feet, etc.

analyzed: asti ca ayam śarīra lakṣaṇaḥ saṃghātaḥ
translated: And this aggregate characterized by the body exists.

analyzed: tasmāt anena api parārthena bhavitavyam
translated: Therefore, it must also exist for the sake of something else.

analyzed: yaḥ sau paraḥ sa puruṣaḥ
translated: And that other is the person.

analyzed: tasmāt asti puruṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the person exists.

analyzed: āha saṃghāta parārtha tva upalabdheḥ
translated: It is said: Because of the perception of the purposefulness of the aggregate.

analyzed: śayana ādayaḥ hi sati api parārtha tve saṃghāta arthāḥ
translated: For even though beds, etc. have a purpose for something else, they are for the sake of the aggregate.

original: yadi ca tairatideśaḥ kāryakāraṇasaṃghātasya kriyate prāptamasya tadvatsaṃghātārthatvam /
analyzed: yadi ca taiḥ atideśaḥ kārya kāraṇa saṃghātasya kriyate prāptam asya tadvat saṃghāta artha tvam
translated: And if they were to make an extension of the aggregate of causes and effects, it would follow that it has the same purpose as that aggregate.

analyzed: evam puruṣa viparīta artha siddhi prasaṃgaḥ
translated: In the same way, there would be the undesirable consequence of establishing a meaning contrary to the person.

analyzed: atha etat aniṣṭam
translated: But if this is undesirable,

analyzed: na tarhi cakṣuḥ ādayaḥ para arthāḥ
translated: then the eye and so on are not for the sake of another.

analyzed: ucyate na śakyam etat āpādayitum
translated: It is said that this cannot be argued.

analyzed: kasmāt asaṃhata tva siddhau vāda pravṛtteḥ
translated: Why? Because the argument is based on the establishment of non-aggregation.

analyzed: siddhe satya saṃhata tve puruṣasya ayam vādaḥ pravṛttaḥ
translated: When the non-aggregation of the person is established, this argument is put forth.

analyzed: tasmāt na pārārthyam anena bādhyate
translated: Therefore, the fact that it is for the sake of another is not contradicted by this.

analyzed: katham avagamyate iti ced
translated: If it is asked how it is understood,

analyzed: pratyakṣatas na upalabdheḥ
translated: it is because of the non-apprehension by direct perception.

original: sati hi saṃghātatve devadattādivadayaṃ puruṣaḥ pratyakṣata evopalabhyeta /
analyzed: sati hi saṃghāta tve devadatta ādi vat ayam puruṣaḥ pratyakṣatas eva upalabhyeta
translated: For if aggregation existed, this person would be directly perceived like Devadatta and others.

original: tathā ca sati saṃśayābhāvātpravṛttirevāsya vādasya na syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca sati saṃśaya abhāvāt pravṛttiḥ eva asya vādasya na syāt
translated: And if that were so, because there would be no doubt, this argument of his would not occur at all.

analyzed: tasmāt ayuktam saṃhata arthāḥ śayana ādi vat cakṣuḥ ādayaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is not correct that the eye and so on are for the sake of the aggregate, like a bed and so on.

analyzed: āha paraspara upakāri tvāt pārārthya siddhiḥ
translated: It is said: The establishment of being for the sake of another is due to mutual benefit.

analyzed: iha kṣetra udaka sūrya ādayaḥ śasya ādīnām upakārakāḥ
translated: Here, the field, water, sun, and so on are benefactors of crops and so on.

analyzed: tathā kārya kāraṇa tvāt saṃghātaḥ ca
translated: Similarly, they are a collection because of being cause and effect.

analyzed: yathā uktam tasmāt ayuktam eteṣām pāratantryam iti
translated: As it is said, therefore their dependence is unreasonable.

analyzed: ucyate na śayana ādi vat tatas
translated: It is said: Not like lying down, etc., because they have a purpose through something else.

original: tadyathā śayanādyaṅgānāṃ sati parasparopakāritve tato 'nyenārthavattvāttadabhāve cārthānarthakyam /
analyzed: tat yathā śayana ādi aṅgānām sati paraspara upakāri tve tatas nyena arthavat tvāt tad abhāve ca artha ānarthakyam
translated: Just as, when the parts of lying down have mutual benefit, they have a purpose through something else, and when that is absent they are purposeless.

original: evaṃ cakṣurādīnāṃ sati parasparopakāritve tato 'nyenārthavattvaṃ bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: evam cakṣuḥ ādīnām sati paraspara upakāri tve tatas bhavitum arhati
translated: In the same way, when the eye, etc. have mutual benefit, they should have a purpose through something else.

analyzed: tad abhāve ca artha ānarthakyam iti
translated: And when that is absent they are purposeless.

original: āha / śayanādīnāṃ devadattārthatvāttasya ca bhedā bahirbhāvātparasparārthatvaprasaṃgaḥ /
analyzed: āha śayana ādīnām devadatta artha tvāt tasya ca bhedāḥ bahirbhāvāt paraspara artha tva prasaṃgaḥ
translated: It is said: Because lying down, etc. are for Devadatta, and because of his difference and external existence, there is the consequence of mutual purpose.

analyzed: evam śayana ādayaḥ devadatta arthāḥ
translated: In the same way, lying down, etc. are for Devadatta.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa saṃghātaḥ ca devadatta śabda vācyaḥ tatra bhedānām eva bheda artha tvāt puruṣa artha siddhiḥ
translated: And the collection of causes and effects is denoted by the word Devadatta. There, because only the differences have the purpose of difference, the human goal is accomplished.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta abhāvaḥ vā
translated: Or there is no example.

analyzed: atha matam śayana ādayaḥ na devadatta arthāḥ
translated: Now if it is thought that lying down, etc. are not for Devadatta,

analyzed: kim tarhi kṣetrajña arthāḥ
translated: then what? They are for the experiencer.

analyzed: tathā sati sādhyasamaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ iti
translated: If that is so, the example is the same as what is to be proven.

analyzed: ucyate na prasiddhi anurodhāt
translated: It is said: No, because of conformity with what is well-known.

analyzed: satyam kārya kāraṇa saṃghātasya pārārthyam
translated: It is true that the aggregate of effects and causes is for the sake of another.

analyzed: bhoktṛ tvam na upapadyate
translated: But the state of being an experiencer is not tenable.

analyzed: loke tu devadatta artha tvam śayana ādīnām prasiddham
translated: But in the world, it is well-known that things like a bed are for Devadatta.

analyzed: atas tat anugacchantaḥ vayam api evam brūmaḥ
translated: Therefore, following that, we also speak in the same way.

analyzed: kasmāt prasiddheḥ
translated: Why? Because of what is well-known.

original: prasiddhena hyaprasiddhaṃ taddharmatāmāpadyate bhavadbhirapyuktaṃ yasya hi pratikṣaṇamanyathātvaṃ nāsti tasya bāhyapratyayayoḥ bhedaḥ /
analyzed: prasiddhena hi aprasiddham tad dharma tām āpadyate bhavadbhiḥ api uktam yasya hi pratikṣaṇam anyathātvam na asti tasya bāhya pratyayayoḥ bhedaḥ
translated: For what is well-known takes on the nature of what is not well-known. It has been said by you also that what does not have a change from moment to moment does not have a difference due to external conditions.

analyzed: paścāt viśeṣa grahaṇe na asti
translated: When a difference is grasped later, it does not exist.

analyzed: tat yathā bhūmeḥ a pacyamānāyāḥ pāka jānām
translated: For example, of the earth that is not decaying, of the things produced by baking.

analyzed: na ca bhūmeḥ pratikṣaṇam anyathātvam na asti
translated: And it is not that there is no change from moment to moment of the earth.

analyzed: akṣaṇika tva prasaṃgāt
translated: Because of the consequence of being non-momentary.

analyzed: saukṣmyāt duradhigamaḥ bhedaḥ iti dṛṣṭāntaḥ prayuktaḥ
translated: The example is used that the difference is difficult to understand because of subtlety.

analyzed: tasmāt siddham saṃghāta parārtha tvāt asti puruṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is established that because of being for the sake of another, the Purusha exists.

analyzed: i taḥ ca
translated: And also from this:

analyzed: triguṇa ādi viparyayāt
translated: Because of the contradiction with the three qualities and so on.

original: triguṇamaviveki viṣayaḥ sāmānyamacetanaṃ prasavadharmi ca bāhyādhyātmikaṃ tathā pradhānam /
analyzed: triguṇam aviveki viṣayaḥ sāmānyam acetanam prasava dharmi ca bāhya ādhyātmikam tathā pradhānam
translated: The Pradhana has three qualities, is non-discriminating, is an object, is general, is insentient, and has the nature of producing, externally and internally.

analyzed: tatra yadi etāvat etat syāt kim apekṣya vyakta avyaktayoḥ traiguṇyāt iti
translated: If this much were said there, what is the basis for the manifestation of the manifest and unmanifest in terms of the three qualities?

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: What else?

analyzed: adhiṣṭhānāt
translated: From the controller.

analyzed: iha ākasmikyām pradhāna pravṛttau artha vaśaḥ sanniveśa niyamaḥ na syāt
translated: Here, if the activity of prakriti were accidental, there would be no restriction in the arrangement according to purpose.

analyzed: śrotra ādi pṛthivī ādīnām deva mānuṣa tiryakṣu hita yoga arthaḥ ca apratiṣedha arthaḥ ca saḥ

analyzed: ucyate na kaivalyāt apratibandha prasaṃgāt

analyzed: anāmiśra rūpam puruṣa tattvam iti etat upariṣṭāt vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will explain later that the essence of Purusha is of a form that is not mixed.

analyzed: sa yadi vyavasāya ātmakaḥ syāt
translated: If it were of the nature of determination,

original: apratibandhena diṅniścayādiṣu suptamattamūrcchitānāṃ ca vyavasāyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: apratibandhena diś niścaya ādiṣu supta matta mūrcchitānām ca vyavasāyaḥ syāt
translated: then determination would occur without obstruction in the ascertainment of directions and so on for those who are asleep, intoxicated, or unconscious.

analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ tu evam avasthasya vyavasāya pratibandhaḥ
translated: But the obstruction of determination is seen in one who is in such a state.

analyzed: tasmāt na puruṣasya

original: yasya punarantaḥkaraṇaṃ vyavasāyakaṃ tasyaivaṃ doṣo nāsti /
analyzed: yasya punar antaḥkaraṇam vyavasāyakam tasya evam doṣaḥ na asti
translated: But for one whose internal organ is the determiner, there is no such fault.

analyzed: kasmāt traiguṇyāt
translated: Why? Because of the three qualities.

analyzed: sattva ādi saṃsthāna viśeṣaḥ hi buddhiḥ
translated: For the intellect is a particular arrangement of sattva and so on.

analyzed: karaṇa antara pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because of the denial of other instruments.

original: tatra yadādhyavasāyalakṣaṇaṃ sattvaṃ guṇābhāvātpradhānabhūtena tamasā tiraskṛtaśakti bhavati tadādhyavasāyapratibandhaḥ /
analyzed: tatra yadā adhyavasāya lakṣaṇam sattvam guṇa abhāvāt pradhāna bhūtena tamasā tiraskṛta śakti bhavati tadā adhyavasāya pratibandhaḥ
translated: There, when the existence characterized by determination has its power obscured by tamas, which is the principal [attribute] due to the absence of the qualities, then there is an obstruction to determination.

analyzed: āha katham punar etat gamyate sarvam idam acetanam iti
translated: It is said: How is it understood that all this is insentient?

analyzed: ucyate prakṛti vikāra bhūta tvāt
translated: It is said: because it is the material cause and the effect.

analyzed: iha yat prakṛti vikāra bhūtam tat acetanam
translated: Here, that which is the material cause and the effect is insentient.

analyzed: tat yathā tantu paṭa ādayaḥ prakṛti vikāra bhūtam tasmāt acetanam
translated: For example, threads and cloth, etc. are the material cause and effect, therefore they are insentient.

analyzed: ākāśe darśanāt na ekāntaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that space is not an instance of the universal because it is seen, that is not so.

analyzed: asiddha tvāt
translated: Because it is not established.

analyzed: na hi ākāśasya ātma pakṣe prakṛti vikāra tva abhāvaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: For the absence of being the material cause and effect of space is not established in the view of the self.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam etat prakṛti vikāra bhūta tvāt acetanam sarvam  atas eva ca cetanasya a prakṛti vikāra bhūta tvam paraspara vaidharmyāt
translated: Therefore, this is correct: all is insentient because it is the material cause and effect.🔽And for this very reason, the self is not the material cause or effect of anything else, because of the difference between them.

analyzed: tasmāt na anyasya paramārthasya bhoktṛ tvam ācetanyāt upapadyate
translated: Therefore, the state of being the experiencer does not apply to anything else in reality, because of being insentient.

analyzed: na ced sūktam bhoktṛ bhāvāt asti puruṣaḥ
translated: And if not, it is well said that the person exists because of being the experiencer.

analyzed: kaivalya artham pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: And because of activity for the sake of liberation.

analyzed: iha pravṛttimatām nimittam antareṇa nivṛttiḥ na upapadyate
translated: Here, for those engaged in activity, cessation is not possible without a cause.

analyzed: pradhānam api ca pravṛttimat
translated: And the pradhāna is also engaged in activity.

analyzed: vyakta darśanāt
translated: Because of the perception of the manifest.

analyzed: tasmāt yasya kaivalyam pradhāna pravṛtti hetuḥ sa puruṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the puruṣa is the one for whom isolation is the cause of the pradhāna's activity.

analyzed: pradhāna anabhyupagamāt ubhaya aprasiddhiḥ iti ced syāt etat
translated: If it is argued that there is non-establishment of both because of the non-acceptance of the pradhāna, it may be said:

analyzed: pradhānam cetana vat asmākam aprasiddham
translated: And the pradhāna is not established for us as if it were conscious.

original: yāvattasya kaivalyārthaṃ pravṛttirbhavatā puruṣāstitve liṅgamapadiśyate tadidamasiddhaṃ pradipādyata iti /
analyzed: yāvat tasya kaivalya artham pravṛttiḥ bhavatā puruṣa astitve liṅgam apadiśyate tat idam asiddham pradipādyate iti
translated: As long as its activity for the sake of isolation is indicated by you as a reason for the existence of the puruṣa, this is indeed unestablished and is being stated.

analyzed: etat ca ayuktam
translated: And this is improper.

analyzed: kasmāt pūrvam tad pratipādanāt
translated: Why? Because it was established earlier.

analyzed: prāk pradhānam a pratipādya evam ācakṣāṇaḥ satyam evam paryanuyoga arhaḥ syāt
translated: If one were to speak in this way without first establishing the pradhāna, one would indeed deserve to be questioned.

original: sādhitaṃ tu pradhānaṃ parimāṇādibhirityato na kiṃcidetat /
analyzed: sādhitam tu pradhānam parimāṇa ādibhiḥ iti atas na kiṃcid etat
translated: But the pradhāna has been established through finitude and other [arguments], so this is nothing.

analyzed: sarva ācārya vipratipatteḥ puruṣa artha siddhiḥ iti ced syāt matam
translated: If it is argued that the accomplishment of the purpose of the puruṣa is due to the disagreement of all the teachers, it may be thought:

analyzed: yadi puruṣasya sattvam eva syāt tena tam prati ācāryāṇām na dharma vivādaḥ syāt
translated: If the existence of the puruṣa were true, then there would be no disagreement among the teachers regarding dharma for him.

analyzed: asti ca asau
translated: But that exists.

analyzed: tathā hi keṣāṃcid nirguṇaḥ
translated: For some, it is without qualities.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid paravān
translated: For some, it is dependent on others.

analyzed: atas sarveṣām vibhuḥ
translated: Therefore, it is all-pervading for all.

analyzed: parimitaḥ ni eṣām
translated: It is limited for others.

analyzed: tathā ekaḥ na ekaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, it is one and not one.

analyzed: tasmāt bhrānti mātram puruṣa kalpanā iti
translated: Therefore, the conception of a person is mere delusion.

analyzed: etat anupapannam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt sarva padārtha abhāva prasaṃgāt
translated: Why? Because it would lead to the non-existence of all things.

analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu api vipratipatteḥ
translated: There are also disagreements regarding form and so on.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid kṣaṇikāḥ
translated: For some, they are momentary.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid kāla antara avasthāyinaḥ
translated: For some, they remain for a period of time.

analyzed: tathā āśritāḥ
translated: Similarly, they are dependent.

analyzed: svatantrāḥ ityādi
translated: Independent, and so on.

analyzed: tathā śrota ādīni bhautikāni
translated: Similarly, hearing and so on are material.

analyzed: āhaṃkārikāṇi
translated: They are made of ego.

analyzed: pauruṣāṇi iti vipratipattiḥ
translated: They are masculine, there are disagreements.

analyzed: evam sarva padārtha abhāvaḥ syāt
translated: Thus, there would be the non-existence of all things.

analyzed: tasmāt asti puruṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the person exists.

original: tatra yuktaṃ sarvapramāṇānupalabdhernāsti puruṣa iti etadayuktam /
analyzed: tatra yuktam sarva pramāṇa anupalabdheḥ na asti puruṣaḥ iti etat ayuktam
translated: Regarding that, it is appropriate to say the person does not exist because all means of valid cognition cannot apprehend it. This is not correct.

original: yadapyuktam śūnyakamādhyātmikaṃ paśyeti tasya paścātpratiṣedhaṃ vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: yat api uktam śūnyakam ādhyātmikam paśya iti tasya paścāt pratiṣedham vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: What was said, one should see the inner as empty, that will be refuted later.

original: yatpunaretaduktaṃ asti karmāsti vipākaḥ kārakastu nopalabhyata iti satyametat /
analyzed: yat punar etat uktam asti karma asti vipākaḥ kārakaḥ tu na upalabhyate iti satyam etat
translated: What was said again, there is karma, there is ripening, but the agent is not apprehended, this is true.

original: na hi puruṣaskandhānāṃ nikṣepe pratisaṃdhāne 'nyatra vā kāraka iti naḥ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: na hi puruṣa skandhānām nikṣepe pratisaṃdhāne nyatra vā kārakaḥ iti naḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: For it is not our view that there is an agent in the transference of the aggregates of a person, in rebirth, or elsewhere.

analyzed: tasmāt śreyaḥ rthibhiḥ sarva āgama tarka viruddhām nairātmya vāda parikalpanā bhrāntim asamañjasām apohya  puruṣa sattva parijñānāt eva janana maraṇa ādi sarva upadrava pratipakṣa bhūtam parama mṛtam
translated: Therefore, those who seek the highest good should avoid the confused conception of the doctrine of selflessness, which contradicts all scriptures and reasoning, and which is unreasonable.🔽By fully understanding the existence of the self, one attains the highest immortality,

analyzed: dhruvam sthānam avāptavyam iti
translated: which is the antidote to all calamities such as birth and death, and is the stable state.

analyzed: kārikā

analyzed: āha gṛhṇīmahe tāvat asti ayam ātmā iti
translated: He says: We accept that this self exists.

analyzed: idānīm anekaḥ thā ekaḥ iti vicāryam
translated: Now it should be considered whether it is many or one.

analyzed: kutas saṃśayaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked why there is doubt,

analyzed: sambandhinām ubhayathā dṛṣṭa tvāt

analyzed: iha kasyacid anekasya anekena sambandhaḥ upalabhyate
translated: Here, a relationship of many with many is observed in some cases.

analyzed: tat yathā śrotra ādinā śarīrasya
translated: For example, of the body with the ear and other [sense organs].

analyzed: kasyacid ekasya anekena
translated: A relationship of one with many is observed in some cases.

analyzed: tat yathā ākāśasya ghaṭa ādinā
translated: For example, of space with the pot and other [containers].

analyzed: ayam api ca ātmā kārya kāraṇa sambandhi iti atas saṃśayaḥ kim śrotra ādi vat anekaḥ
translated: And this self is related as cause and effect. Therefore, there is doubt: Is it many like the ear and others,

analyzed: ākāśa vat ekaḥ vā iti kim ca anyat
translated: or one like space? Moreover,

analyzed: ācārya vipratipatteḥ
translated: because of the disagreement of the teachers.

analyzed: aupaniṣadāḥ khalu ekaḥ ātmā iti pratipannāḥ
translated: The followers of the Upaniṣads, on the other hand, maintain that there is one Self.

analyzed: kāṇāda akṣapāda ārhata prabhṛtayaḥ punar eke iti
translated: The Kāṇādas, Ākṣapādins, Ṛṣabha, and others maintain that there are many.

analyzed: yathā ca eka aneka tvam pratyātmanaḥ vipratipattiḥ evam sākṣi tva audāsīnya draṣṭṛ tva akartṛ tveṣu
translated: Just as there is disagreement about whether the Self is one or many, so also about whether it is the witness, indifferent, the seer, or not the agent.

analyzed: tasmāt vaktavyam katham ete dharmāḥ puruṣe vatiṣṭhante iti
translated: Therefore, it must be explained how these qualities abide in the person.

original: ucyate yattāvaduktaṃ sambandhitvādātmapadārthe sandehaḥ kimaneko 'thaika iti /
analyzed: ucyate yat tāvat uktam sambandhi tvāt ātma padārthe sandehaḥ kim anekaḥ iti
translated: It is said: As for what was said, that there is doubt about the meaning of the word Self because of its relation, whether it is many or one,

analyzed: atra brūmaḥ bahavaḥ puruṣāḥ iti pratijñā kasmāt
translated: we reply: The proposition is that there are many persons. Why?

analyzed: janma maraṇa karaṇānām pratiniyamāt
translated: Because of the restriction of birth, death, and the organs.

original: janmeti mahadādeḥ sūkṣmaśarīrāśritasya liṅgasya yathāsaṃskāraṃ bāhyena śarīreṇa sambandhaḥ /

translated: Birth is the connection of the subtle body-based linga with the external body according to its impressions.

original: maraṇamiti pūrvakṛtasya karmaṇaḥ phalabhogaparisamāpteḥ sāmpratasya ca phalabhogasya pratyupasthāne liṅgasya pūrvaśarīratyāgaḥ /
analyzed: maraṇam iti pūrva kṛtasya karmaṇaḥ phala bhoga parisamāpteḥ sāmpratasya ca phala bhogasya pratyupasthāne liṅgasya pūrva śarīra tyāgaḥ
translated: Death is the giving up of the previous body by the linga when the enjoyment of the fruits of previously done actions is completed and the enjoyment of the present fruits is imminent.

analyzed: karaṇam trayodaśavidham iti isk vakṣyati
translated: The organs will be explained as thirteen.

original: janma ca maraṇaṃ ca karaṇāni ca janmamaraṇakaraṇāni /
analyzed: janma ca maraṇam ca karaṇāni ca janma maraṇa karaṇāni
translated: Birth and death and the organs, are the birth, death, and organs.

analyzed: teṣām pratipuruṣam niyamaḥ
translated: They are restricted to each individual.

analyzed: etasmāt liṅgāt ātmanaḥ bahu tvam avasīyate
translated: From this mark, the plurality of the self is ascertained.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati janmalakṣaṇaṃ ca maraṇalakṣaṇaṃ ca kāryakāraṇasyāvasthāntaram /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati janma lakṣaṇam ca maraṇa lakṣaṇam ca kārya kāraṇasya avasthā antaram
translated: This is what is said: Birth and death are the different states of the effect and cause.

analyzed: paraspara virodhinī tamaḥ prakāśa vat
translated: They are mutually contradictory, like light and darkness.

translated: If there were only one self in that case, just as one substance cannot experience light and darkness falling on one place, because it is impossible,

analyzed: evam ayam janma maraṇe api na śaknuyāt upabhoktum
translated: in the same way, this [self] would not be able to experience birth and death.

analyzed: asti ca ayam kenacid kārya karaṇena janma upabhogaḥ kenacid maraṇa upabhogaḥ
translated: But this experience of birth is by some effect and organ, and the experience of death is by some other.

analyzed: tena manyāmahe nānā ātmānaḥ
translated: Therefore we think the selves are many.

analyzed: yeṣām virodhi dharma upabhoga sāmarthyam iti
translated: Whose capacity is to experience mutually contradictory things.

analyzed: tathā karaṇānām prakāśa atiśayaḥ viṣaya grahaṇa lakṣaṇa aśuddhi atiśayaḥ ca aṣṭāviṃśatidhā āśaktiḥ
translated: Similarly, the organs have twenty-eight kinds of power, consisting of the excess of light and the characteristic purity of grasping objects.

analyzed: tayoḥ paraspara virodhāt ekena ātmanā yugapad upabhogaḥ na upapadyate
translated: Because of the mutual contradiction between those two, the simultaneous experience by one self is not possible.

original: na hi śakyamekenātmanā prakāśātiśayo viṣayagrahaṇalakṣaṇo 'śuddhyatiśayaścāśaktilakṣaṇo virodhitvādyugapadupabhoktum /
analyzed: na hi śakyam ekena ātmanā prakāśa atiśayaḥ viṣaya grahaṇa lakṣaṇaḥ śuddhi atiśayaḥ ca aśakti lakṣaṇaḥ virodhi tvāt yugapad upabhoktum
translated: For it is not possible for a single self to experience simultaneously the excess of manifestation characterized by the apprehension of objects and the excess of impurity characterized by incapacity, because of contradiction.

analyzed: asti ca ayam karaṇa nimittaḥ prati puruṣam niyamaḥ
translated: And this restriction based on the instrument is for each person.

analyzed: tena manyāmahe nānā ātmānaḥ iti
translated: Therefore we think the selves are many.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: What else?

analyzed: ayugapad pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: And because of non-simultaneous activity.

analyzed: puruṣa bahu tvam siddham
translated: The existence of many souls is established.

analyzed: kasmāt ayugapad pravṛtteḥ pradhānasya iti śeṣaḥ  yasya pravṛttiḥ upapadyate
translated: Why? Because of non-simultaneous activity of the primordial nature, this is the remainder.🔽Whose activity is possible?

analyzed: kasya pravṛttiḥ upapadyate
translated: Whose activity is possible?

analyzed: pradhānasya
translated: Of the primordial nature.

analyzed: katham iti
translated: How?

original: ucyate yadyeka ātmā syāttenaikapuruṣādhikāranibaddhaṃ pradhānam /🔽śaktaścāsau yugapadanekāni śarīrāṇi upabhoktumityato yāvadbhiḥ śarīrairapacitāsu kālamātrāsvasminbhavaparivarte bhavitavyaṃ sarveṣāmutpattiṃ
analyzed: ucyate yadi ekaḥ ātmā syāt tena eka puruṣa adhikāra nibaddham pradhānam  śaktaḥ ca asau yugapad anekāni śarīrāṇi upabhoktum iti atas yāvadbhiḥ śarīraiḥ apacitāsu kāla mātrāsu asmin bhava parivarte bhavitavyam sarveṣām utpattim
translated: It is said: If there were one self, then the primordial nature would be bound to the eligibility of one person.

analyzed: prati yugapad pravarteta
translated: And it is capable of simultaneously experiencing many bodies, therefore in all the kalpas in this cycle of existence, where it has to exist with reduced bodies, it would operate simultaneously for the origin of all.

analyzed: dṛṣṭā tu pradhānasya ayugapad śarīra bhāvena pravṛttiḥ
translated: But the activity of the primordial nature is seen to occur with the existence of bodies not simultaneously.

analyzed: tasmāt ayugapad pravṛtteḥ ca nānā ātmānaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because of the non-simultaneous functioning, the selves are many.

analyzed: anye punar āhuḥ bahiṣkaraṇām eva ayugapad pravṛtteḥ
translated: Others, however, say that it is because of the non-simultaneous functioning of the external sense organs.

original: katham / yadyeka ātmā syāttena tatsaṃskāropanibaddhānyeva sarvāṇi karaṇānītyataḥ pratipaṇḍitamavasthitaiḥ karaṇairyugapadviṣayāngṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: katham yadi ekaḥ ātmā syāt tena tad saṃskāra upanibaddhāni eva sarvāṇi karaṇāni iti atas pratipaṇḍitam avasthitaiḥ karaṇaiḥ yugapad viṣayān gṛhṇīyāt
translated: How? If there were one self, then all the sense organs would be bound to the impressions of that, and therefore they would simultaneously grasp objects with the sense organs remaining in place for each individual.

analyzed: bādhirya ādi upaghāte vā sati piṇḍa antara sambandhinā karaṇena asya śabda ādi karaṇam apratiṣiddham syāt
translated: Or, if there were a defect such as deafness, then for him the sense organs for sound and so on would be unobstructed by the sense organs connected to another body.

analyzed: na tu tathā bhavati
translated: But it does not happen that way.

analyzed: tasmāt karaṇānām ayugapad pravṛtteḥ nānā ātmānaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because of the non-simultaneous functioning of the sense organs, the selves are many.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt pūrveṇa aviśeṣāt
translated: Why? Because there is no distinction from the previous argument.

analyzed: karaṇānām pratiniyamāt iti anena ayam upasaṃgṛhītaḥ rthaḥ
translated: This meaning is included by this [argument] that the sense organs are restricted.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā uktam eva astu
translated: Therefore, let it be as stated.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: What else?

analyzed: triguṇa ādi viparyayāt ca eva
translated: And because of the difference from the three qualities and so on.

original: iha triguṇamaviveki viṣayaḥ sāmānyamacetanaṃ prasavadharmītyete dharmāḥ pratipiṇḍamupalabhyante /
analyzed: iha triguṇam aviveki viṣayaḥ sāmānyam acetanam prasava dharmi iti ete dharmāḥ pratipiṇḍam upalabhyante
translated: Here, the qualities of being composed of the three qualities, being non-discriminating, being an object, being general, being insentient, and having the nature of producing are observed for each individual.

original: yathā caite tathā tatpratiyogino nairguṇyādayaḥ puruṣadharmāḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca ete tathā tad pratiyoginaḥ nairguṇya ādayaḥ puruṣa dharmāḥ
translated: And just as these [qualities], so also their opposites, non-excellence and so on, are qualities of the soul.

analyzed: tatra yathā eva guṇa svabhāva viparīta svabhāvasya upalambhāt ekasmāt piṇḍāt eka puruṣa siddhiḥ evam prati piṇḍam guṇa svabhāva viparīta svabhāvasya upalambhāt puruṣa nānātvam avaseyam
translated: Just as from one lump [of clay] the existence of one soul is established by the perception of a nature opposite to the nature of qualities, in the same way, from the perception of a nature opposite to the nature of qualities in each lump, the plurality of souls should be understood.

analyzed: tasmāt avasthitam etat nānā ātmānaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is established that [souls] are many.
