original: ucyate yaduktaṃ tasya kasminnarthe vṛttirityatra brūmaḥ
analyzed: ucyate yat uktam tasya kasmin arthe vṛttiḥ iti atra brūmaḥ
translated: It is said: What was said, in which object does it function? Here we say:

analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu pañcānām ālocana mātram iṣyate vṛttiḥ
translated: The function of the five is considered to be mere perception in form and so on.

original: rūpādiṣu śabdasparśarūparasagandheṣu svabhedabhinneṣu pañcānāṃ śrotratvakcakṣurjihvāghrāṇānāṃ śravaṇasparśanadarśanarasanaghrāṇalakṣaṇo vyāpāro
analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandheṣu sva bheda bhinneṣu pañcānām śrotra tvac cakṣuḥ jihvā ghrāṇānām śravaṇa sparśana darśana rasana ghrāṇa lakṣaṇaḥ vyāpāraḥ
translated: In form and so on, in sound, touch, form, taste and smell, which are different in their own divisions, the operation of the five, ear, skin, eye, tongue and nose, which is characterized by hearing, touching, seeing, tasting and smelling,

analyzed: vṛttiḥ iti ucyate
translated: It is called activity.

original: tatra karaṇanirdeśe śrotrendriyasya prākpāṭhāttadviṣayanirdeśātilaṃghane prayojanaṃ nāstīti kṛtvā śabdādiṣu pañcānāmityeva paṭhitavyam /
analyzed: tatra karaṇa nirdeśe śrotra indriyasya prāk pāṭhāt tad viṣaya nirdeśa atilaṃghane prayojanam na asti iti kṛtvā śabda ādiṣu pañcānām iti eva paṭhitavyam
translated: There, since there is no purpose in skipping the teaching of the object of that [ear sense faculty] when the ear sense faculty is mentioned first in the teaching of the instruments, it should be recited as of the five beginning with sound.

analyzed: prāktanaḥ tu pramāda pāṭhaḥ
translated: But the former recitation is due to carelessness.

analyzed: yat punar etat uktam kiṃlakṣaṇā iti atra brūmaḥ ālocana mātram iṣyate
translated: Now, as for what was said here about the characteristic, we say: mere apprehension is accepted.

analyzed: ālocanam grahaṇam iti anarthāntaram
translated: Apprehension is mere grasping, it is not a different meaning.
The word mere is for the purpose of excluding a particular [quality].

original: tadyathā bhaikṣamātramasmingrāme labhyata ityukte nānyo viśeṣa iti jñāyate /
analyzed: tat yathā bhaikṣa mātram asmin grāme labhyate iti ukte na anyaḥ viśeṣaḥ iti jñāyate
translated: For example, when it is said alms are obtained in this village only, it is understood that there is no other particular [quality].

analyzed: chandraḥ mātram adhīte māṇavakaḥ iti ukte na anyat adhīte iti
translated: When it is said the boy studies only the Chandoramas, it is understood that he does not study anything else.

original: evamālocanamātramindriyāṇāmiṣyate vṛttirityukte nānyo viśeṣa iti gamyate /
analyzed: evam ālocana mātram indriyāṇām iṣyate vṛttiḥ iti ukte na anyaḥ viśeṣaḥ iti gamyate
translated: In the same way, when it is said that mere apprehension is accepted as the activity of the sense faculties, it is understood that there is no other particular [quality].

analyzed: tena kim siddham bhavati
translated: What is established by that?

original: yaduktamanyairācāryaiḥ sāmānyajñānamindriyāṇāṃ viśeṣajñānaṃ buddheriti tatpratiṣiddhaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yat uktam anyaiḥ ācāryaiḥ sāmānya jñānam indriyāṇām viśeṣa jñānam buddheḥ iti tat pratiṣiddham bhavati
translated: What was said by other teachers, that the sense faculties have the knowledge of the general [properties] and the intellect has the knowledge of the specific [properties], that is refuted.

original: āha / kaḥ punarasmindarśane doṣo yata etatpratiṣidyata iti /
analyzed: āha kaḥ punar asmin darśane doṣaḥ yatas etat pratiṣidyate iti
translated: He says: But what is the fault in this view that it is refuted?

original: ucyate sāmānyaviśeṣayoritaretarāpekṣatve satyekasminnavirodhādanyataraparikalpanānarthakyam /🔽yadi khalvindriyasya sāmānyajñānaṃ na syāttena viśeṣāpekṣaṃ sāmānyaṃ sāmānyāpekṣaśca
analyzed: ucyate sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ itaretara apekṣa tve sati ekasmin avirodhāt anyatara parikalpanā ānarthakyam  yadi khalu indriyasya sāmānya jñānam na syāt tena viśeṣa apekṣam sāmānyam sāmānya apekṣaḥ ca
translated: It is said: When generality and particularity are mutually dependent, there is no contradiction in one, so positing the other is pointless.🔽If the sense organ did not have knowledge of generality, then generality would depend on particularity, and particularity would depend on generality.

original: viśeṣa iti yatra sāmānyajñānaṃ tatra viśeṣajñānamapi na pratiṣidhyata ityubhayamapīndriyasya syāt /
analyzed: viśeṣaḥ iti yatra sāmānya jñānam tatra viśeṣa jñānam api na pratiṣidhyate iti ubhayam api indriyasya syāt
translated: So where there is knowledge of generality, knowledge of particularity is not denied, so both would belong to the sense organ.

analyzed: tatas ca antaḥkaraṇa parikalpanā ānarthakyam
translated: And from that, positing an internal organ is pointless.

original: viśeṣavato vāntaḥkaraṇasya kaḥ sāmānyena virodha ityubhayasyāpi tatra sambhavādindriyānarthakyam /
analyzed: viśeṣavataḥ vā antaḥkaraṇasya kaḥ sāmānyena virodhaḥ iti ubhayasya api tatra sambhavāt indriya ānarthakyam
translated: Or what contradiction does the internal organ, which has particularities, have with generality? Since both are possible there, the sense organ is pointless.

analyzed: tasmāt apratyayam indriyam iti
translated: Therefore, the sense organ is not a condition.

analyzed: indriyasya ced pratyayaḥ syāt yathā pratyayavataḥ ntaḥkaraṇasya aniyata viṣaya tvam
translated: If the sense organ were a condition, then just as the internal organ, which is a condition, has undetermined objects,

analyzed: evam asya api syāt na tu tat asti
translated: so would this [sense organ]. But that is not the case.

analyzed: tasmāt apratyayam indriyam iti
translated: Therefore, the sense organ is not a condition.

analyzed: kiṃca kāla ativṛtti prasaṃgāt
translated: And also because of the consequence of exceeding the time.

original: indriyasya cetpratyayaḥ syādyathā pratyayavato 'ntaḥkaraṇasya trikālaviṣayatvamevamasyāpi syāt /
analyzed: indriyasya ced pratyayaḥ syāt yathā pratyayavataḥ ntaḥkaraṇasya tri kāla viṣaya tvam evam asya api syāt
translated: If the sense faculty were the condition, then just as the internal organ, which has a condition, has objects in all three times, so would this [sense faculty].

analyzed: na tu tat asti
translated: But that is not the case.

analyzed: tasmāt apratyayam indriyam iti
translated: Therefore, the sense faculty is not a condition.

analyzed: kim ca anyat smṛti adarśanāt
translated: Moreover, because memory is not seen.

analyzed: indriyasya ced pratyayaḥ syāt yathā pratyayavataḥ ntaḥkaraṇasya ādi rūpa upapattiḥ evam atra api syāt
translated: If the sense faculty were the condition, then just as the internal organ, which has a condition, has a beginning and form, so would it be here as well.

analyzed: na tu tat asti
translated: But that is not the case.

analyzed: tasmāt apratyayam indriyam siddham iti
translated: Therefore, it is established that the sense faculty is not a condition.

analyzed: ucyate na kāraṇa antara prasaṃgāt
translated: It is said: because of the non-occurrence of another cause.

original: yadi pradīpavadindriyaṃ prakāśakaṃ syāttena yathā tatprakāśiteṣu ghaṭādiṣvartheṣu karaṇāntaramārgaṇamevamatrāpi syāt /
analyzed: yadi pradīpa vat indriyam prakāśakam syāt tena yathā tad prakāśiteṣu ghaṭa ādiṣu artheṣu karaṇa antara mārgaṇam evam atra api syāt
translated: If the sense faculty were illuminating like a lamp, then just as in the case of objects like pots illuminated by that lamp, another instrument is required, so would it be here as well.

analyzed: na ca etat iṣṭam
translated: But that is not accepted.

analyzed: atas na pradīpavat indriyam prakāśakam iti
translated: Therefore, the sense faculty is not illuminating like a lamp.

original: antaḥkaraṇasadbhāvādayuktamiti cet syānmatam asti kāraṇāntaraṃ buddhilakṣaṇaṃ yadindriyeṇa pradīpavatprakāśitamarthaṃ gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa sadbhāvāt ayuktam iti ced syāt matam asti kāraṇa antaram buddhi lakṣaṇam yat indriyeṇa pradīpa vat prakāśitam artham gṛhṇāti
translated: If it is argued that this is not so because of the existence of the internal organ, it may be thought that there is another cause characterized by cognition, if it grasps an object illuminated by the sense faculty like a lamp.

analyzed: tasmāt paravāda anuvādaḥ yam kriyate
translated: Therefore, this is a mere repetition of the opponent's view.

analyzed: na pratiṣedhaḥ iti
translated: Not a prohibition.

analyzed: tat ca na evam
translated: And that is not so.

analyzed: kasmāt pradīpa indriyayoḥ anyatara anupādāna prasaṃgāt
translated: Why? Because it would lead to the absurdity of not using one of the two, the lamp and the sense organ.

analyzed: indriyam api prakāśakam
translated: The sense organ also illuminates, and the lamp also.

analyzed: tatra anyatarasya anupādānam prasaktam
translated: There, the non-use of one of them would be implied.

analyzed: kasmāt na hi eka artha kāriṇaḥ yugapad karaṇe sāmarthyam asti iti
translated: Why? Because there is no ability to use both simultaneously for a single purpose.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa hāneḥ
translated: Because of the loss of the internal organ.

analyzed: indriyeṇa pradīpa vat prakāśitān bāhyān arthān sākṣāt antaḥkaraṇam gṛhṇāti iti vadataḥ ntaḥkaraṇam eva hīyate
translated: For one who says that the internal organ directly grasps external objects illuminated by the sense organ like a lamp, the internal organ itself is lost.

analyzed: tasmāt ayuktam antaḥkaraṇasya sāmarthyam
translated: Therefore, it is not proper for the internal organ to have the ability.

analyzed: puruṣasya iti ced na karaṇa ānarthakya prasaṃgāt
translated: If it is said to belong to the self, that is not so, because it would lead to the absurdity of the sense organs being useless.

analyzed: sākṣāt viṣaya grahaṇa samartham puruṣam icchataḥ karaṇa ānarthakyam prasajyate
translated: For one who desires the self to be capable of directly grasping objects, it would lead to the absurdity of the sense organs being useless.

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam etat grāhakam indriyam na tu pradīpa vat prakāśakam iti
translated: Therefore, it is proper to say that the sense organ is the grasper, but it does not illuminate like a lamp.

analyzed: āha bhavatu tāvat grahaṇa mātram indriya vṛttiḥ apratyayā
translated: He says: Let it be for now that the function of the sense organ is mere grasping, without a cause.

analyzed: grahaṇa pratyaya prakāśa abhedaḥ
translated: The difference between the illumination of the cause of grasping and the illumination of the object.

analyzed: ucyate viṣaya samparkāt tādrūpya āpattiḥ indriya vṛtti grahaṇam
translated: It is said that the apprehension of the functioning of the sense organs is the attainment of that form through contact with the object.

original: tathā viṣayendriyavṛttyanukāreṇa niścayo gaurayaṃ śuklo dhāvatītyevamādiḥ pratyayaḥ /
analyzed: tathā viṣaya indriya vṛtti anukāreṇa niścayaḥ gauḥ ayam śuklaḥ dhāvati iti evamādiḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: Similarly, the cognition that arises in conformity with the object and the functioning of the sense organs, such as This is a white cow running, is a cognition.

analyzed: tathā viṣaya samparka āgame śrotra ādi vṛtteḥ tādrūpya āgamaḥ vartamāna kālatā
translated: Similarly, when there is contact with the object, the functioning of the ear and other sense organs attains that form, which is the present time.

original: grahaṇasyānubhavāttu saṃskārādhānaṃ tatpūrvikā ca smṛtiriti trikālaviṣayā pratyayasyetyayamanayorviśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: grahaṇasya anubhavāt tu saṃskāra ādhānam tad pūrvikā ca smṛtiḥ iti tri kāla viṣayā pratyayasya iti ayam anayoḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: But from the experience of apprehension, there is the imprinting of impressions, and memory arises from that. Thus, the cognition has objects of all three times. This is the difference between these two.

analyzed: bāhyaḥ tu prakāśaḥ na viṣaya rūpa āpannaḥ
translated: But external light does not attain the form of the object.

original: saṃskārāttu ghaṭādīnāṃ vyavadhānarūpaṃ pārthivaṃ chāyālakṣaṇaṃ vyañjakatvāya kalpate /
analyzed: saṃskārāt tu ghaṭa ādīnām vyavadhāna rūpam pārthivam chāyā lakṣaṇam vyañjaka tvāya kalpate
translated: However, due to the impressions, the earthen shadow-like obstruction of pots and other things becomes suitable for manifestation.

analyzed: cakṣuṣaḥ nugrahāya
translated: For the benefit of the eye.

analyzed: ubhayoḥ vā cakṣuḥ viṣayayoḥ iti apare
translated: Others say it is for the benefit of both the eye and the object.

analyzed: tasmāt upapannam etat prakāśakam pradīpa ādi  grāhakam śrotra ādi
translated: Therefore, it is established that a lamp and other things are illuminators.🔽The ear and other sense organs are apprehenders.

analyzed: vyavasāyakam antaḥkaraṇam iti
translated: The internal organ is the determiner.

original: atha karmendriyāṇāṃ kā vṛttirityucyate naiyāyikāstvevamāhuḥ ghrāṇarasanacakṣustvakcchrotrāṇīndriyāṇi bhūtebhyaḥ /
analyzed: atha karmendriyāṇām kā vṛttiḥ iti ucyate naiyāyikāḥ tu evam āhuḥ ghrāṇa rasana cakṣuḥ tvac śrotrāṇi indriyāṇi bhūtebhyaḥ
translated: Now, what is the function of the organs of action? The Naiyāyikas say this: The nose, tongue, eyes, skin, and ears are the sense organs derived from the elements.

original: bhūtebhya ityanena svaviṣayopalabdhilakṣaṇaṃ hīndriyāṇāṃ bhūtaprakṛtitve sati nirvahati / nānyathā /
analyzed: bhūtebhyaḥ iti anena sva viṣaya upalabdhi lakṣaṇam hi indriyāṇām bhūta prakṛti tve sati nirvahati na anyathā
translated: By from the elements, the definition of the function of the sense organs as the apprehension of their own objects is accomplished when they have the elements as their material cause, not otherwise.

analyzed: tāni punar indriya kāraṇāni pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyuḥ ākāśam iti bhūtāni
translated: Moreover, those causes of the sense organs are the elements: earth, water, fire, air, and space.

original: ebhyaḥ pañcabhyo yathāsaṃkhyaṃ ghrāṇarasanacakṣustvakcchrotrāṇi pañcendriyāṇi bhavanti /
analyzed: ebhyaḥ pañcabhyaḥ yathāsaṃkhyam ghrāṇa rasana cakṣuḥ tvac śrotrāṇi pañca indriyāṇi bhavanti
translated: From these five, the five sense organs - nose, tongue, eyes, skin, and ears - arise in order.

analyzed: bhūta prakṛti tvam iti bhūta svabhāvam vyākhyāyamānam pañcasu api sambhavati
translated: When the state of being derived from the elements is explained as having the nature of the elements, it is possible in all five.

analyzed: bhūta kāraṇa tvam tu anyeṣu caturṣu tathā eva
translated: But being the material cause of the elements is the same in the other four.

analyzed: śrotre tu kathaṃcid karṇa śaṣkulī avacchinna nabhaḥ bhāga abhiprāyeṇa vyavahārataḥ samarthanīyam
translated: But in the case of the ear, it must be justified somehow by the intention of a part of space enclosed by the ear-drum, from the point of view of usage.

original: evaṃ bhautikānīndriyāṇi svasvaviṣayamadhigantumutsahanta iti tallakṣaṇatvameṣāṃ sidhyatīti /
analyzed: evam bhautikāni indriyāṇi sva sva viṣayam adhigantum utsahante iti tad lakṣaṇa tvam eṣām sidhyati iti
translated: Thus, the sense organs derived from the elements are capable of apprehending their own objects, so their definition is established.

analyzed: atas bhūtebhyaḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said from the elements.

analyzed: etat tu sāṃkhya ācāryāṇām na iṣṭam
translated: But this is not accepted by the teachers of Sāṃkhya.

original: evaṃ hi sāṃkhyavṛddhā āhuḥ āhaṅkārikāṇīndriyāṇi arthaṃ sādhayitumarhanti nānyathā /
analyzed: evam hi sāṃkhya vṛddhāḥ āhuḥ āhaṅkārikāṇi indriyāṇi artham sādhayitum arhanti na anyathā
translated: For the elders of Sāṃkhya say thus: The senses, which are born of egoism, are capable of accomplishing the object, not otherwise.

original: tathā hi kārakaṃ kārakatvādeva prāpyakāri bhavati /
analyzed: tathā hi kārakam kāraka tvāt eva prāpya kāri bhavati
translated: For thus, an agent acts only by reaching the object to be acted upon.

original: bhautikāni cendriyāṇi kathaṃ prāpyakārīṇi duravartini viṣaye bhaveyuḥ /
analyzed: bhautikāni ca indriyāṇi katham prāpya kārīṇi duravartini viṣaye bhaveyuḥ
translated: And how could the senses, which are material, become the agents that reach the object when the object is far away?

analyzed: āhaṃkārikāṇām tu teṣām vyāpaka tvāt
translated: But for those which are born of egoism, their action is possible because they are all-pervading.

original: viṣayākārapariṇāmātmikā vṛttirvṛttimato 'nanyā satī sambhavatyeveti suvacaṃ prāpyakāritvam api ca mahadaṇuguṇagrahaṇamāhaṅkāritve teṣāṃ kalpate /
analyzed: viṣaya ākāra pariṇāma ātmikā vṛttiḥ vṛttimataḥ na anyā satī sambhavati eva iti suvacam prāpyakāri tvam api ca mahat aṇu guṇa grahaṇam āhaṅkāri tve teṣām kalpate
translated: The modification in the form of the object, which is not different from the possessor of modification, is indeed possible. Therefore, it is well-said that they are agents that reach the object. Moreover, the grasping of the gross and subtle qualities is possible if they are born of egoism.

analyzed: na bhautika tve
translated: But not if they are material.

original: bhautikatve hi yatparimāṇaṃ karaṇaṃ tatparimāṇaṃ grāhyaṃ gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: bhautika tve hi yad parimāṇam karaṇam tad parimāṇam grāhyam gṛhṇīyāt
translated: For if they were material, the object grasped would have the same size as the instrument that grasps it.

analyzed: āha atha karmendriyāṇām kā vṛttiḥ iti
translated: Now, what is the function of the organs of action?

analyzed: ucyate  vacana ādāna viharaṇa utsarga ānandāḥ ca pañcānām
translated: It is said:🔽The functions of the five are speaking, taking, moving, excreting, and enjoying.

original: vākpāṇipādapāyūpasthānāṃ tu vacanādānaviharaṇotsargānandalakṣaṇā yathākramaṃ vṛttayaḥ pratyavagantavyāḥ /
analyzed: vāc pāṇi pāda pāyu upasthānām tu vacana ādāna viharaṇa utsarga ānanda lakṣaṇāḥ yathākramam vṛttayaḥ pratyavagantavyāḥ
translated: The functions of speech, hands, feet, anus, and genitals should be understood as having the characteristics of speaking, taking, moving, excreting, and enjoying, respectively.

analyzed: tatra ucyate nena iti vacanam
translated: Speech is that by which something is said there.

original: tasmādya evārthapratyāyanasamartho varṇasamudāyaḥ padavākyaślokagranthalakṣaṇaḥ sa vāgindriyasyārtho nānyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt yaḥ eva artha pratyāyana samarthaḥ varṇa samudāyaḥ pada vākya śloka grantha lakṣaṇaḥ sa vāc indriyasya arthaḥ na anyaḥ
translated: Therefore, that very collection of letters capable of conveying meaning, characterized by words, sentences, verses, and texts, is the object of the speech faculty, not anything else.

analyzed: ādīyate nena iti ādānam
translated: Taking is that by which something is taken.

analyzed: āṅ abhividhi arthe prayujyate
translated: The prefix ā is used in the sense of abhividhi (intensification).

original: tataśca yadeva prakṣālanaparimārjanopasparśanādhyayanapraharaṇaśilpavyāyāmādi kṛtsnaṃ grahaṇaṃ sa indriyārthā nānyaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca yat eva prakṣālana parimārjana upasparśana adhyayana praharaṇa śilpa vyāyāma ādi kṛtsnam grahaṇam saḥ indriya arthāḥ na anyaḥ
translated: And therefore, that very act of grasping, which includes washing, wiping, touching, studying, fighting, craftsmanship, exercise, etc., is the object of the sense faculty, not anything else.

analyzed: viśiṣṭam haraṇam viharaṇam
translated: Moving is the special act of carrying.

analyzed: atas ca yat eva sama viṣama nimna unnata caṅkramaṇa parivartana nāṭya vyāyāma ādiḥ saḥ indriyārthaḥ na anyaḥ
translated: And therefore, that very act of walking, turning, dancing, exercising, etc., on even, uneven, low, high ground, is the object of the sense faculty, not anything else.

analyzed: evam utkṛṣṭaḥ sargaḥ utsargaḥ
translated: Similarly, the excellent creation is the emission.

analyzed: na anyaḥ
translated: Not anything else.

original: ataśca ya evāśitapītavipariṇāmasya samyakstrotomārgānusāriṇo visargaḥ sa indriyārtho nānyaḥ /
analyzed: atas ca yaḥ eva aśita pīta vipariṇāmasya samyak strotaḥ mārga anusāriṇaḥ visargaḥ saḥ indriya arthaḥ na anyaḥ
translated: And therefore, that very emission of the transformation of what is eaten and drunk, which follows the proper course of the channels, is the object of the sense faculty, not anything else.

analyzed: evam abhivyāpya ānandam ānandaḥ
translated: Similarly, the bliss that is pervaded is bliss.

analyzed: tatas ca yaḥ eva asādhāraṇa prīti nayana abhiniṣpatti lakṣaṇaḥ saḥ indriya arthaḥ na anyaḥ  /
translated: And therefore, that which is characterized by the accomplishment of the uncommon delight of the eyes is the object of the sense faculty, not anything else.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: kārikā

analyzed: āha prāk antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti nirdeśaḥ
translated: He says: The teaching of the functions of the internal organs should come first.

analyzed: sarga krama anugamāt pūrvam buddhi ahaṃkāra manasām vṛtti nirdeśaḥ kartavyaḥ
translated: The teaching of the functions of intellect, ego, and mind should come first, following the order of creation.

analyzed: kim kāraṇam
translated: What is the reason?

analyzed: evam hi sarga kramaḥ nugataḥ bhavati
translated: For in this way the order of creation is followed.

analyzed: krama bhede vā prayojanam vaktavyam iti
translated: Or if there is a difference in order, a purpose must be stated.

analyzed: ucyate na indriya vṛtti pūrvakatvāt
translated: It is said: No, because the internal organ is preceded by the functions of the senses.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇasya hi indriya vṛtti pravartakaḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: For the intellect, which is the internal organ, has a notion that sets the functions of the senses in motion.

original: tathā ca vakṣyati dṛṣṭe tathāpyadṛṣṭe trayasya tatpūrvikā vṛttiriti ISk /
analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyati dṛṣṭe tathā api adṛṣṭe trayasya tad pūrvikā vṛttiḥ iti
translated: And thus he will say: Even in the seen, but not in the unseen, there is the function of the three preceded by that.

original: tasmātsargakrameṇa vinā tannirdeśaḥ prāgācāryeṇa kriyate iti /
analyzed: tasmāt sarga krameṇa vinā tad nirdeśaḥ prāk ācāryeṇa kriyate iti
translated: Therefore, the teacher first teaches it without the order of creation.

analyzed: āha tad asambhavaḥ
translated: He says: That is impossible.

analyzed: śāstre prāk abhimāna abhidhānāt
translated: Because the ego is mentioned first in the scriptures.

original: śāstraṃ hyevamāha kā nu bhoḥ saṃjñā māturudare 'vasthitaṃ kumāraṃ pratyabhinirviśata iti /
analyzed: śāstram hi evam āha kā nu bhoḥ saṃjñā mātuḥ udare vasthitam kumāram pratyabhinirviśate iti
translated: For the scriptures say: What, sir, is the name of the boy who is conceived in the mother's womb?

analyzed: asmi iti eṣā māhātmī saṃvid iti
translated: This is the great-souled consciousness.

analyzed: tathā kārya kāraṇa vyūha sama kālam māhātmya śarīraḥ smi iti pratibuddhyate
translated: Thus, simultaneously with the arrangement of cause and effect, one awakens to the thought I am the body of greatness.

analyzed: pravṛttāḥ ca eva hi avyaktāḥ bhavanti asmi iti asmitā mātrāḥ
translated: And they are indeed unmanifest, being mere identification with the thought I am.

analyzed: pramāṇam ca śāstram
translated: And scripture is a means of knowledge.

analyzed: tasmāt prāk antaḥkaraṇa nirdeśaḥ kartavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the internal organ should be mentioned first.

analyzed: ucyate tad nimitta arthena vivakṣita tvāt
translated: It is said that this is intended in the sense of being the cause.

analyzed: satyam etat kārya kāraṇa vyūha niṣpatti sama kālam asmi iti eṣā māhātmī saṃvid pratyupadhīyate
translated: This is true. At the time of the manifestation of the arrangement of cause and effect, this consciousness of I am is present.

analyzed: śabda ādi viṣayaḥ tu antaḥkaraṇa pratyayaḥ śrotra ādi nimittaḥ iti
translated: But the cognition of the internal organ with regard to objects such as sound is caused by the ear etc.

analyzed: etat pūrva śabdena vivakṣitam
translated: This is what is meant by the word first.

analyzed: na ca nimittam atikramya naimittika abhidhānam nyāyyam
translated: And it is not proper to speak of the effect without going beyond the cause.

original: athavā naiva vayamidaṃ praṣṭavyā yathā prāgantaḥkaraṇavṛttinirdeśaḥ kartavya iti /
analyzed: athavā na eva vayam idam praṣṭavyāḥ yathā prāk antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti nirdeśaḥ kartavyaḥ iti
translated: Or rather, we should not be asked how the internal organ should be mentioned first.

analyzed: kim kāraṇam yasmāt
translated: What is the reason? Because

analyzed: svālakṣaṇyam vṛttiḥ trayasya  sva lakṣaṇam eva svālakṣaṇyam
translated: the function of the three is their own characteristic.🔽The own characteristic itself is the own-function.

analyzed: svārthe taddhita vṛttiḥ
translated: The suffix is used in the sense of its own object.

analyzed: anya bhāvaḥ tu kāla śabda vyavāyāt iti
translated: But the existence of another is due to the separation of the word time, it is said.

original: yathā buddhyahaṃkāramanasāṃ hi saukṣmyānna śakyaṃ svarūpamabhidhātumityato vṛttireva lakṣaṇabhāvenopadiśyate /
analyzed: yathā buddhi ahaṃkāra manasām hi saukṣmyāt na śakyam svarūpam abhidhātum iti atas vṛttiḥ eva lakṣaṇa bhāvena upadiśyate
translated: Just as the nature of intellect, ego, and mind cannot be described because of their subtlety, so their functions alone are taught as their characteristics.

analyzed: śrotra ādīnām api ca saukṣmyāt lakṣaṇam apadeṣṭum aśakyam iti vṛttiḥ evā ucyate
translated: And since the characteristics of the ear and others cannot be taught because of their subtlety, their functions alone are mentioned.

analyzed: na lakṣaṇam
translated: Not their characteristics.

analyzed: tat eva ca eṣā lakṣaṇam bhavati
translated: And that itself is their characteristic.

analyzed: yat śabda ālocana samartham tat śrotram
translated: That which is capable of perceiving sound is the ear.

analyzed: evam itareṣu api vaktavyam
translated: The same should be said for the others.

analyzed: buddhi ahaṃkāra manasām ca lakṣaṇam adhyavasāya ādi uktam
translated: And the characteristics of intellect, ego, and mind have been stated as determination and so on.

original: tadeva vṛttitvenācakṣāṇaḥ śrotrādīnāmeva cābhidadhānaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ cāpyācakṣāṇo vṛttivṛttimatorananyatvaṃ jñāpayati /
analyzed: tat eva vṛtti tvena ācakṣāṇaḥ śrotra ādīnām eva ca abhidadhānam lakṣaṇam ca api ācakṣāṇaḥ vṛtti vṛttimatoḥ ananyatvam jñāpayati
translated: By mentioning that itself as their function and by mentioning the characteristics of the ear and others, he indicates that the function and the possessor of the function are not different.

original: anyathā tu yathādhyavasāyādi lakṣaṇamevaṃ rūpādiṣu pañcānāmalocanamātraṃ lakṣaṇamityucyate /
analyzed: anyathā tu yathā adhyavasāya ādi lakṣaṇam evam rūpa ādiṣu pañcānām alocana mātram lakṣaṇam iti ucyate
translated: Otherwise, if determination and so on were the characteristics as stated, mere seeing of form and so on would be the characteristic of the five,

analyzed: na tu vṛttiḥ iti
translated: but not the function.

analyzed: śrotra ādi vat buddhi ādīnām api vyavasāya ādayaḥ vṛttiḥ iti ucyate
translated: Like the ear and others, determination and so on of intellect and others are said to be the function,

analyzed: na tu lakṣaṇam
translated: but not the characteristic.

original: tasmādanyathā nirdeśo jñāpakaṃ vṛttivṛttimatoranyatvasyeti vyākhyātā karaṇavṛttiḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt anyathā nirdeśaḥ jñāpakam vṛtti vṛttimatoḥ anya tvasya iti vyākhyātā karaṇa vṛttiḥ
translated: Therefore, the explanation in a different way is an indication of the difference between the function and the possessor of the function. Thus the function of the instrument has been explained.

analyzed: sā eṣā bhavati asāmānyā
translated: This is indeed non-common.

original: seti pūrvakṛtāṃ vṛttimabhisambadhnāti /🔽eṣeti sarvanāmnā pratyākṛṣṭāṃ tāmeva pratyakṣaṃ prati nirdiśati /
analyzed: sā iti pūrva kṛtām vṛttim abhisambadhnāti  eṣā iti sarvanāmnā pratyākṛṣṭām tām eva pratyakṣam prati nirdiśati
translated: The word this refers to the previously mentioned function.🔽The word this refers to the same [function] that is drawn back by the pronoun, and indicates it as perception.

analyzed: bhavati iti vakṣyamāṇena dharma antareṇa asyāḥ tadvat tā anubhāvitam khyāpayati
translated: The word is indicates that this [function] has that nature, which is suggested by the subsequent property.

analyzed: asāmānyā iti dharmam ācaṣṭe
translated: The word non-common describes a property.

analyzed: sāmānyā sādhāraṇā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of common is shared by many.

analyzed: na sāmānya asāmānyā
translated: It is not non-common in the sense of being uncommon.

analyzed: pratikaraṇam niyatā iti uktam bhavati
translated: It is said to be restricted to each instrument.

original: yā hīyamanukrāntā karaṇaparvaṇo 'dhyavasayādikā vṛttiriyaṃ vyastānāṃ karaṇānāṃ pratisvaṃ niyatā /
analyzed: yā hi iyam anukrāntā karaṇa parvaṇaḥ dhī avasaya ādikā vṛttiḥ iyam vyastānām karaṇānām pratisvam niyatā
translated: For this function beginning with determination, which has been mentioned in the section on the instruments, is restricted to each of the separated instruments.

analyzed: tatas ca eṣām buddhi ādīnām kārya viśeṣa nimitta bhāva saṃsūcitasya svarūpasya asaṃkaraḥ siddhaḥ
translated: And from that, the unmixed nature of these intellect etc., indicated by the state of being the cause of specific effects, is established.

analyzed: āha sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ itaretara apekṣa tvāt asāmānya abhidhānena sāmānyasya api abhidhānāt adhyavasāya ādikā karaṇānām asāmānyā vṛttiḥ iti ukte rthāt āpannam eṣām
translated: He says: Because the general and the particular are mutually dependent, by expressing the particular, the general is also expressed. When it is said that the function of the sense faculties is not general, such as inference, it is implied that

analyzed: sāmānyā api vṛttiḥ asti iti
translated: they also have a general function.

analyzed: tasmāt asau api vaktavyā iti
translated: Therefore, that [general function] should also be stated.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: sāmānya karaṇa vṛttiḥ prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca
translated: The general function of the sense faculties is the five life-breaths and so on.

analyzed: sāmānyā ca asau karaṇa vṛttiḥ sāmānya karaṇa vṛttiḥ
translated: This is a general function of the sense faculties.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ ca ādyaḥ yeṣām te prāṇa ādyāḥ
translated: Those that have life-breath as the first are the life-breaths and so on.

analyzed: prāṇa apāna samāna udāna vyānāḥ pañca samasta karaṇa vṛttiḥ pratyavagantavyā iti
translated: The five life-breaths, exhalation, inhalation, equalization, upward movement, and circulation, should be understood as the general function of all the sense faculties.

original: taiḥ sarvaiḥ sahitaḥ prāṇa iti vedānteṣvapi /
analyzed: taiḥ sarvaiḥ sahitaḥ prāṇaḥ iti vedānteṣu api
translated: In the Vedanta scriptures also, it is said that life-breath is associated with all of them.

analyzed: āha ayuktam etat
translated: He says: This is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt dharmiṇaḥ dharmi antara vṛtti bhāva anupapatteḥ
translated: Why? Because the existence of the function of one thing in another thing is not possible.

analyzed: vṛttiḥ iti ayam śabdaḥ vyāpāram ācaṣṭe
translated: This word function denotes activity.

original: na ca dharmāntaraṃ dharmāntarasya vyāpāro bhavitumarhatīti /
analyzed: na ca dharma antaram dharma antarasya vyāpāraḥ bhavitum arhati iti
translated: And another property cannot be the activity of another property.

analyzed: ucyate na kārye kāraṇa upacārāt
translated: It is said: Because the effect is figuratively designated as the cause.

analyzed: satyam etat
translated: This is true.

analyzed: dharmī dharmi antarasya vṛtti tvena aśakyaḥ parikalpayitum
translated: A substance cannot be imagined to inhere in another substance.

original: kiṃ tu sāmānyakaraṇavṛttyā preryamāṇo vāyustatpravaṇatvāttatkāryatāṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: kim tu sāmānya karaṇa vṛttyā preryamāṇaḥ vāyuḥ tad pravaṇa tvāt tad kārya tām pratipadyate
translated: But the air, being impelled by the operation of the common organs, becomes inclined towards that effect, and so attains that character.

original: tatra prāṇādikārye vāyau prāṇopacāraṃ kṛtvā evamucyate prāṇādyā vāyavaḥ pañca /
analyzed: tatra prāṇa ādi kārye vāyau prāṇa upacāram kṛtvā evam ucyate prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca
translated: There, in the air which is the effect of prāṇa etc., the air is figuratively called prāṇa, and it is said that the five airs beginning with prāṇa are the effects of that.

analyzed: tad preraṇa asiddheḥ ayuktam iti ced syāt etat
translated: If it is argued that this is not proper because the establishment of its impulsion is not proper, it may be said this.

original: kathametadavagamyate 'rthāntarapreritasya vāyoriyaṃ kriyā bhavati na punaḥ svatantrasyeti /
analyzed: katham etat avagamyate ṛtha antara preritasya vāyoḥ iyam kriyā bhavati na punar svatantrasya iti
translated: How is this understood - that this action of the air impelled by another object occurs, and not that of the independent one?

analyzed: ucyate na svatas
translated: It is said - not by itself.

analyzed: tad vyatirikta tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it cannot be different from that.

analyzed: iha iyam akasmāt bhinnā kriyā vāyoḥ svatas vā syāt
translated: Here, this action, different from the air, would be either by itself or by the operation of the organs.

analyzed: karaṇa vṛtti vyatirikta tvāt vā
translated: Or because it is different from the operation of the organs.

analyzed: kim ca atas tatra tāvat svatas upapadyate
translated: And what follows from that? First, it is proper by itself.

original: kasmāt / sarvatra prasaṃgāt svābhāvike hi vāyordiksaṃcāre 'bhyupagamyamāne sarvatra tatsaṃbhavaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kasmāt sarvatra prasaṃgāt svābhāvike hi vāyoḥ diś saṃcāre bhyupagamyamāne sarvatra tad saṃbhavaḥ syāt
translated: Why? Because it would follow everywhere. If the natural movement of the air in the directions is accepted, its occurrence would be possible everywhere.

analyzed: tatas ca tiryakpāta ādi vṛttiḥ hanyeta
translated: And from that, the operation of falling obliquely etc. would be obstructed.

analyzed: na ca anyatas
translated: And not from anything else.

analyzed: kasmāt adarśanāt
translated: Why? Because it is not seen.

analyzed: na hi pṛthivī ādīnām vāyu preraṇa sāmarthyam kvacid upalabdham
translated: For nowhere is it observed that earth and so on have the ability to propel wind.

analyzed: bhastrā ādiṣu dṛṣṭam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is seen in bellows and so on, that is not so.

analyzed: anya nimitta tvāt
translated: Because it has another cause.

analyzed: atra api caitra vyāpāraḥ upalabhyate iti avaśyam anyat nimittam upalabhyate iti abhyupagantavyam
translated: And in this case also, the activity of Caitra is observed, so it must be accepted that another cause is necessarily observed.

analyzed: ātmā iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is the self, that is not so.

analyzed: kriyā pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because action is denied.

analyzed: upapāditam etat pūrvam ātmā niṣkriyaḥ iti
translated: This has been established before that the self is inactive.

analyzed: na ca niṣkriyasya preraṇam upapadyate
translated: And impulsion is not possible for what is inactive.

analyzed: na ca nirnimittā svabhāva bhedānām an ākasmika tvāt
translated: And it cannot be without a cause, because the differences in nature are not accidental.

analyzed: tasmāt yat tad nimittam sā samasta karaṇa vṛttiḥ
translated: Therefore, that which is the cause is the activity of all the organs.

original: sa cāyaṃ vāyureka eva sthānasaṃcāraviśeṣānnānākhyo bhavati /
analyzed: sa ca ayam vāyuḥ ekaḥ eva sthāna saṃcāra viśeṣāt nānā ākhyaḥ bhavati
translated: And this wind is called by various names due to the differences in its location and movement.

original: yathaiko devadattaḥ pācako lāvaka iti kvacit /
analyzed: yathā ekaḥ devadattaḥ pācakaḥ lāvakaḥ iti kvacid
translated: Just as the same Devadatta is called a cook, a washerman, etc. in some places.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt yugapad paraspara atiśaya virodhāt
translated: Why? Because simultaneous mutual superiority is contradictory.

analyzed: pūrvasmāt pūrvasmāt uttaraḥ uttaraḥ vāyuḥ balīyān iti hi abhyupagamaḥ
translated: For it is accepted that the wind that comes later is stronger than the one that came before.

analyzed: tat etat ekasya ekasmin kāle na upapadyate
translated: But that is not possible for one at one time.

analyzed: tasmāt upapannam prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that the winds are five, beginning with prāṇa.

analyzed: kim punar eṣām prāṇa ādīnām lakṣaṇam iti
translated: What, then, are the characteristics of these prāṇas and so on?

analyzed: ucyate dvividhāḥ prāṇa ādayaḥ
translated: It is said: The prāṇas and so on are of two kinds.

analyzed: antar vṛttayaḥ bahis vṛttayaḥ ca  tatra mukha nāsikābhyām pragamanāt praṇateḥ ca prāṇaḥ
translated: Internal functions and external functions.🔽Among them, prāṇa is exhalation and inhalation through the mouth and nose.

original: yo 'yaṃ mukhanāsikābhyāṃ sañcarati so 'ntarvṛttirvāyuḥ prāṇa ityabhidhīyate /
analyzed: yaḥ yam mukha nāsikābhyām sañcarati saḥ antar vṛttiḥ vāyuḥ prāṇaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: The air that moves through the mouth and nose is called the internal function prāṇa.

original: yā kācitpraṇatirnāma bhūteṣu tadyathā praṇateyaṃ senā /
analyzed: yā kācid praṇatiḥ nāma bhūteṣu tat yathā praṇatā iyam senā
translated: Whatever is called bending in beings, just as this army is bent,

analyzed: praṇataḥ yam vṛkṣaḥ  praṇataḥ yam dharme
translated: this tree is bent,🔽this dharma is bent,

analyzed: praṇataḥ yam arthe
translated: this artha is bent,

analyzed: praṇataḥ yam kāme
translated: this kāma is bent,

analyzed: praṇataḥ yam vidyāyām
translated: this vidyā is bent,

analyzed: tad viparīteṣu vā bāhya prāṇa vṛttiḥ eṣā
translated: or in their opposites, this is the external function of prāṇa.

analyzed: prāṇi viṣayaḥ eva eṣā bhavati
translated: This pertains only to living beings.

analyzed: sa khalu ayam atra abhivyaktaḥ bhavati
translated: That is indeed manifested here.

original: tadyathā mahatā vā duḥkhenābhiplutasya mahatā vā bandhunā viyuktasya /
analyzed: tat yathā mahatā vā duḥkhena abhiplutasya mahatā vā bandhunā viyuktasya
translated: For example, of one overwhelmed by great suffering or separated from a great relative,

analyzed: sahitasya vā saurabheyasya
translated: or of one united with a cow,

analyzed: nipāna avatīrṇasya vā mahiṣasya avagateḥ
translated: or of a buffalo that has descended to drink water and is aware of it,

analyzed: apakramaṇāt ca apānaḥ
translated: and by moving away, apāna.

original: yo 'yaṃ rasaṃ dhātūn śukraṃ mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ vātārtavagarbhāṃścākarṣannadhogacchannayamantarvṛttirvāyurapāna ityabhidhīyate /
analyzed: yaḥ yam rasam dhātūn śukram mūtram purīṣam vāta ārtava garbhān ca ākarṣan adhas gacchan ayam antar vṛttiḥ vāyuḥ apānaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: This downward-moving wind, which draws rasa, dhatus, semen, urine, feces, vata, menstrual blood, and fetus downward, is called apana.

original: yaccāpi kiṃcidapakramaṇaṃ nāma bhūteṣu tadyathā apakrānto 'yaṃ dharmādibhyastadviparītebhyo vā iti bāhyā khalvapānavṛttireṣā /
analyzed: yat ca api kiṃcid apakramaṇam nāma bhūteṣu tat yathā apakrāntaḥ yam dharma ādibhyaḥ tad viparītebhyaḥ vā iti bāhyā khalu apāna vṛttiḥ eṣā
translated: And whatever outward movement there is in beings, such as he has moved away from dharma etc. or from their opposites, this is indeed the outward function of apana.

analyzed: apāna viṣayaḥ eva eṣa bhavati
translated: This belongs to the domain of apana alone.

analyzed: balavattaraḥ ca ayam prāṇaḥ ud vāyoḥ kasmāt
translated: And why is this prana wind stronger?

original: eṣā hyetaṃ prāṇamūrdhvaṃ vartamānamarvāgeva sanniyacchati arvāgeva sanniruṇaddhi /
analyzed: eṣā hi etam prāṇam ūrdhvam vartamānam arvāk eva san niyacchati arvāk eva san niruṇaddhi
translated: For this one, while prana is moving upwards, restrains it downwards, restrains it right here.

analyzed: eṣa u tra abhivyaktaḥ bhavati
translated: This one becomes manifest here.

analyzed: tat yathā upa kūpam upa śvabhram vā parivartamānasya āśatapadīm laṅghayataḥ
translated: Just as when jumping over a well or a pit.

analyzed: hṛdi avasthānāt saha bhāvāt ca samānaḥ
translated: Sama is because it abides in the heart and because it exists together.

original: yastvayaṃ prāṇāpānayormadhye hṛdyavatiṣṭhate sa samāno vāyurantarvṛttiḥ yaścāpi kaścitsaha bhāvo nāma bhūteṣu dvandvārāmatā /🔽tadyathā saha dāsye /
analyzed: yaḥ tu ayam prāṇa apānayoḥ madhye hṛdi avatiṣṭhate sa samānaḥ vāyuḥ antar vṛttiḥ yaḥ ca api kaścid saha bhāvaḥ nāma bhūteṣu dvandva ārāma tā  tat yathā saha dāsye
translated: But this one that abides in the heart between prana and apana is the internal function of the sama wind, and whatever existence together there is in beings, the delight in pairs,🔽such as together with the maid,

analyzed: saha yakṣye
translated: together with the Yaksha,

original: saha tapaścariṣyāmi saha bhāryāputrairbandhubhiḥ suhṛdbhiśca vartiṣya bāhyā samānavṛttireṣā /
analyzed: saha tapaḥ cariṣyāmi saha bhāryā putraiḥ bandhubhiḥ suhṛdbhiḥ ca vartiṣya bāhyā samāna vṛttiḥ eṣā
translated: I will practice austerities together with my wife, sons, relatives, and friends. I will live with them, with the same conduct as they. This is the rule.

analyzed: samāna viṣayaḥ eva eṣa bhavati iti
translated: This is the same for all.

analyzed: balavattaraḥ khalu ayam prāṇa apānābhyām
translated: This [apāna] is indeed stronger than the exhalation and inhalation [prāṇa].

original: eṣa hyetau prāṇāpānau ūrdhvamarvākca vartamānau madhya eva sanniyacchati /
analyzed: eṣa hi etau prāṇa apānau ūrdhvam arvāk ca vartamānau madhye eva san niyacchati
translated: For this [apāna] controls the exhalation and inhalation [prāṇa] that move upwards and downwards right in the middle.

analyzed: madhye eva san niruṇaddhi
translated: It restrains them right in the middle.

original: sa caiṣau 'trābhivyakto bhavati /🔽tadyathā srutasārasya vā sārameyasya /
analyzed: sa ca eṣau tra abhivyaktaḥ bhavati  tat yathā srutasārasya vā sārameyasya
translated: And that [apāna] becomes manifest here.🔽Just like the saliva of a dog that is drooling,

analyzed: anaḍuhaḥ voḍhabhārasya
translated: or the load-bearing of an ox,

analyzed: dharma abhitaptāyāḥ vai eḍakāyāḥ ardha ardha kāyam śaka śaka iti
translated: or the half-body of a sheep that is tormented by heat, shaking here and there.

original: prāṇānte sarvaprāṇināṃ prāṇāpānāvutsṛjyordhvamadhaśca muktayoktrau hayāviva viṣamaṃ saṃcārayan śarīraṃ sa parāsyati /
analyzed: prāṇānte sarva prāṇinām prāṇa apānau utsṛjya ūrdhvam adhas ca mukta yoktrau hayau iva viṣamam saṃcārayan śarīram sa parāsyati
translated: At the end of life, for all living beings, the exhalation and inhalation [prāṇa] are released upwards and downwards, and the body moves unevenly like two horses with loose reins. It will fall down.

analyzed: mūrdha ārohaṇa dātma utkarṣaṇāt ca udānaḥ
translated: And udāna [life-breath] is due to ascending the head and self-exaltation.

original: yastvayaṃ prāṇāpānasamānānāṃ sthānānyatikramya rasaṃ dhātūṃścādāya mūrdhānamārohati
analyzed: yaḥ tu ayam prāṇa apāna samānānām sthānāni atikramya rasam dhātūn ca ādāya mūrdhānam ārohati
translated: But this [udāna] that, having gone beyond the places of exhalation, inhalation, and circulation [prāṇa], takes up the essence and bodily constituents, ascends to the head,

analyzed: tatas ca pratihataḥ nivṛttaḥ sthāna karaṇa anupradāna viśeṣāt varṇa pada vākya śloka grantha lakṣaṇasya
translated: And then, being obstructed, it turns back. Due to the special bestowal of the organs of speech, it becomes the cause of the manifestation of the sound characterized by letters, words, sentences, verses, and texts.

analyzed: śabdasya abhivyakti nimittam bhavati ayam antar vṛttiḥ vāyuḥ udānaḥ iti ucyate
translated: This internal function of the wind is called udāna.

original: yaścāpi kaścidātmotkarṣo nāma bhūteṣu tadyathā hīnādasmi śreyān /🔽sadṛśena vā sadṛśaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ ca api kaścid ātma utkarṣaḥ nāma bhūteṣu tat yathā hīnāt asmi śreyān  sadṛśena vā sadṛśaḥ
translated: And whatever kind of self-exaltation there is among beings, such as I am superior to an inferior,🔽or I am equal to an equal,

analyzed: sadṛśāt asmi śreyān  śreyasā vā sadṛśaḥ
translated: or I am superior to an equal,🔽or I am equal to a superior,

original: śreyaso vā śreyān /🔽etasmiṃstathā rūpābhimāno vā prāptavidyastu /
analyzed: śreyasaḥ vā śreyān  etasmin tathā rūpa abhimānaḥ vā prāpta vidyaḥ tu
translated: or I am superior to a superior,

analyzed: tat yathā bahu antara viśeṣāt alpa antara viśeṣaḥ smi aguṇavataḥ vā guṇavān asmi iti bāhya udāna vṛttiḥ eṣā
translated: or in one who has attained knowledge, such as I am of little difference from one with a great difference, or I am virtuous when I am devoid of virtues, this is the external function of udāna.

analyzed: udāna viṣayaḥ eva eṣa bhavati
translated: This occurs only in the domain of udāna.

analyzed: balavattaraḥ khalu ayam pūrvabhyaḥ
translated: This is indeed stronger than the previous ones.

analyzed: katham eṣa hi etān prāṇa ādīn ūrdhvam avāk madhye ca vartamānān ūrdhvam eva unnayati
translated: How so? For this one carries upwards, above and below, those beginning with prāṇa, which are located above and below, and carries them upwards.

analyzed: ūrdhvam eva utkarṣati
translated: It carries them upwards only.

original: sa caiṣo 'trābhivyakto bhavati śītodakena vā paryukṣitasya prāsamasiṃ vikośaṃ codyatamabhipaśyataḥ /
analyzed: sa ca eṣaḥ trā abhivyaktaḥ bhavati śīta udakena vā paryukṣitasya prāsam asim vikośam ca udyatam abhipaśyataḥ
translated: And this is manifested here when one is sprinkled with cold water or when one sees a sword drawn from its scabbard.

analyzed: śarīra vyāpteḥ atyanta avinābhāvāt ca vyānaḥ
translated: And Vyāna is so called because it pervades the body and is always inseparable from it.

original: yastvayamālomanakhāccharīraṃ vyāpya rasādīnāṃ dhātūnāṃ pṛthivyādināṃ vyūhaṃ marmaṇāṃ ca praspandanaṃ prāṇādīnāṃ ca sthitiṃ karoti so 'ntarvṛttirvyānaḥ
analyzed: yaḥ tu ayam ā loma nakhāt śarīram vyāpya rasa ādīnām dhātūnām pṛthivī ādinām vyūham marmaṇām ca praspandanam prāṇa ādīnām ca sthitim karoti saḥ ntar vṛttiḥ vyānaḥ
translated: And that which pervades the body from the hair to the nails, arranges the bodily constituents such as rasa, etc., and the elements such as earth, etc., and causes the throbbing of the vital parts and the stability of the vital airs such as Prāṇa, etc., that internal function is Vyāna.

original: yaścāpi kaścidatyantāvinābhāvo nāma bhūteṣu tadyathā pativratā bhartāraṃ mṛtamapyanugacchati
analyzed: yaḥ ca api kaścid atyanta avinābhāvaḥ nāma bhūteṣu tat yathā pativratā bhartāram mṛtam api anugacchati
translated: And that which is called absolute inseparability among beings, such as a faithful wife follows her dead husband,

original: bhavāntare 'pyayameva bhartā syāt tathā dharmādibhistadviparītaiśceti bāhyo vyānaviṣaya evaiṣa prabhavati /
analyzed: bhava antare pi ayam eva bhartā syāt tathā dharma ādibhiḥ tad viparītaiḥ ca iti bāhyaḥ vyāna viṣayaḥ eva eṣa prabhavati
translated: and in another life also, this very one would be her husband, and so also with Dharma, etc., and their opposites - this external Vyāna operates only on that.

analyzed: balavattamaḥ ca ayam sarvebhyaḥ
translated: And this is the strongest of all.

original: katham / anena hi vyāpte śarīradaṇḍake tadvaśīkṛtānāṃ prāṇādīnāṃ samā sthitirbhavati /
analyzed: katham anena hi vyāpte śarīra daṇḍake tad vaśīkṛtānām prāṇa ādīnām samā sthitiḥ bhavati
translated: How? For when this pervades the body, the stability of Prāṇa, etc., which are brought under its control, becomes equal.

analyzed: saḥ eṣaḥ nta kāle prāṇabhṛtām avinābhāvena vartamānaḥ bhivyajyate
translated: And this, existing inseparably at the end of life of living beings, is manifested.

original: tadyathā hā tarhi pādau haimau śītībhūtau gulphe jaṅghe urū kaṭirudaramuraḥkaṇṭhe 'sya khuraghuro vartate hū /
analyzed: tat yathā hā tarhi pādau haimau śītībhūtau gulphe jaṅghe urū kaṭiḥ udaram uraḥ kaṇṭhe sya khuraghuraḥ vartate hū
translated: As if saying, Alas! Then the feet become cold, the ankles, calves, thighs, waist, belly, chest, and throat make a khur-ghur sound.

analyzed: iti ava eṣaḥ bāhyaḥ vyānaḥ iti
translated: Thus, this is the external vyāna.

original: evamete prāṇādyāḥ sthānakāryaviśeṣasūcitāḥ pañca vāyavo vyākhyātāḥ teṣāṃ prerikā sāmānyakaraṇavṛttiḥ /
analyzed: evam ete prāṇa ādyāḥ sthāna kārya viśeṣa sūcitāḥ pañca vāyavaḥ vyākhyātāḥ teṣām prerikā sāmānya karaṇa vṛttiḥ
translated: Thus, these five winds beginning with prāṇa, indicated by the specific locations and functions, have been explained. Their general function of the sense organs is that which impels them.

analyzed: eṣā ca tantra antareṣu prayatnaḥ iti ucyate
translated: And this is called effort in other systems.

original: sa ca dharmādisaṃskārabhāvanāvaśādanuparato jīvanam / āha ca
analyzed: sa ca dharma ādi saṃskāra bhāvanā vaśāt anuparataḥ jīvanam āha ca
translated: And that is life which is not interrupted by the formation of impressions such as virtue, etc. It is said:

analyzed: vṛttiḥ antar samastānām karaṇānām pradīpa vat
translated: The function of all the internal sense organs is like a lamp.

analyzed: aprakāśā kriyā rūpā jīvanam kāya dhārikā
translated: It is the form of action that is not light, which sustains life and supports the body.

original: sā yāvadaniruddhā tu hanti vāyuṃ rajo 'dhikā /
analyzed: sā yāvat aniruddhā tu hanti vāyum rajaḥ dhikā
translated: As long as that is not stopped, it drives away the wind, which is dominated by rajas.

analyzed: dharma ādi anāvṛtti vaśāt tāvat jīvati mānavaḥ
translated: As long as there is no cessation of virtue, etc., a human being lives.

analyzed: atra ca sāmānya karaṇa vṛtti grahaṇa sāmarthyāt prāṇa ādyāḥ pañca vāyavaḥ
translated: And here, by the power of grasping the general function of the sense organs, the five winds beginning with prāṇa are included.

analyzed: buddhīndriyāṇi ṣaṣṭham
translated: The five sense organs are the sixth.

analyzed: karmendriyāṇi saptamam
translated: The five action organs are the seventh.

analyzed: pūḥ aṣṭamam
translated: The pūr is the eighth.

analyzed: pūḥ iti ahaṃkāra avasthā saṃvidham adhikurute
translated: The pūr refers to the state of the ego and the consciousness.

analyzed: yasmāt āha tatra
translated: Because of this, it is said there:

analyzed: saṃvid ahaṃkāra gatam kāryam kāraṇam pūrayati yasmāt
translated: Consciousness, located in the ego, fulfills the function of the cause.

analyzed: tasmāt pūḥ iti uktā pratyavabhāsā aṣṭamam bhoktuḥ
translated: Therefore, it is called Pūra, the eighth manifestation of the enjoyer.

analyzed: sā ca ahaṅkāra gatā saṃvid buddhi gatā eva puruṣeṇa upalabhyate
translated: And that consciousness located in the ego is perceived by the Purusha only as located in the intellect.

analyzed: yasmāt vakṣyati
translated: Because it will be said:

original: ete pradīpakalpāḥ parasparavilakṣaṇā guṇaviśeṣāḥ /🔽kṛtsnaṃ puruṣasyārthaṃ prakāśya buddhau prayacchanti // ISk
analyzed: ete pradīpa kalpāḥ paraspara vilakṣaṇāḥ guṇa viśeṣāḥ  kṛtsnam puruṣasya artham prakāśya buddhau prayacchanti
translated: These qualities, which are like lamps, are mutually distinct.🔽Having illuminated the entire purpose of the Purusha, they deliver it to the intellect.

analyzed: sarva pratyupabhogam yasmāt puruṣasya sādhayati buddhiḥ
translated: Because the intellect accomplishes all the experiences of the Purusha.

analyzed: tasmāt sā eva pūḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it alone is called Pūra.

analyzed: śāstram ca evam āha prāṇa apāna samāna udāna vyānāḥ pañca vāyavaḥ
translated: And the scripture says thus: The five vital airs are Prāṇa, Apāna, Samāna, Udāna, and Vyāna.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭham manaḥ
translated: The sixth is the mind.

analyzed: saptamī pūraṣṭamī vāc
translated: The seventh is Pūra, and the eighth is speech.

analyzed: vāc grahaṇena karmendriya parvaṇaḥ grahaṇam
translated: By the word speech, the set of organs of action is included.

analyzed: manaḥ grahaṇena buddhīndriya parvaṇaḥ
translated: By the word mind, the set of organs of sense is included.

original: tadetatprāṇāṣṭamaṃ vaikārikaṃ guṇaśarīrasya paridraṣṭuḥ kṣetrajñasya śarīramādadānasya nityaṃ stambhasthānīyaṃ pratyaṅgaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tat etat prāṇa aṣṭamam vaikārikam guṇa śarīrasya paridraṣṭuḥ kṣetrajñasya śarīram ādadānasya nityam stambha sthānīyam pratyaṅgam bhavati
translated: This eightfold vital air is the eternal limb of the knower of the field, who takes up the body of the aggregate of qualities of the Purusha, like a pillar.

analyzed: acchedyam abhedyam adāhyam avināśyam avikampyam
translated: It is indivisible, indestructible, unburnable, imperishable, and unshakable.

original: anityāni punarbhautikāni bāhyāni kuśamṛttikāsthānīyāni upacīyante ceti /
analyzed: anityāni punar bhautikāni bāhyāni kuśa mṛttikā sthānīyāni upacīyante ca iti
translated: But the external elements, which are subject to change, are perishable and can be accumulated, like grass, mud, and clay.

original: āha / kutaḥ punariyaṃ prāṇādivṛttiḥ pravartata iti /
analyzed: āha kutas punar iyam prāṇa ādi vṛttiḥ pravartate iti
translated: He asks: But from what do these functions of life, beginning with breathing, proceed?

analyzed: ucyate sā karma yonibhyaḥ
translated: It is said: They arise from the wombs of karma.

original: mahataḥ pracyutaṃ hi rajo vikṛtam aṇḍasthānīyāḥ pañca karmayonayo bhavanti dhṛtiḥ śraddhā sukhā vividiṣā avividiṣeti / āha ca
analyzed: mahataḥ pracyutam hi rajaḥ vikṛtam aṇḍa sthānīyāḥ pañca karma yonayaḥ bhavanti dhṛtiḥ śraddhā sukhā vividiṣā a vividiṣā iti āha ca
translated: For when the great one falls away, the defiled rajas becomes the five wombs of karma, which are like an egg: steadfastness, faith, pleasure, desire to know, and lack of desire to know. And it is said:

original: pracyuto mahato yastu na prāpto jñānalakṣaṇam /
analyzed: pracyutaḥ mahataḥ yaḥ tu na prāptaḥ jñāna lakṣaṇam
translated: He who has fallen from the great one, but has not attained the characteristic of knowledge,

analyzed: vyāpāraḥ jñāna yoni tvāt sā yoniḥ kukkuṭa aṇḍa vat
translated: his activity, being born from the womb of knowledge, is like a hen's egg.

analyzed: tāsām lakṣaṇa viṣaya sa tattva guṇa samanvayāḥ bhavanti
translated: They have the characteristics, objects, truth, and qualities in common.

analyzed: tatra lakṣaṇam tāvat vyavasāyāt apracyavanam dhṛtiḥ
translated: Among them, the characteristic is as follows: Steadfastness is not deviating from determination.

analyzed: phalam an abhisandhāya śāstra ukteṣu kāryeṣu avaśya kartavya tā bīja bhāvaḥ śraddhā
translated: Faith is the seed-like state of the necessary duty in tasks prescribed by the scriptures, without aiming for a result.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa ānuśravika phala abhilāṣa dvārakaḥ hi buddheḥ ābhogaḥ sukhā  vettum icchā vividiṣā

analyzed: tad nivṛttiḥ avividiṣā

original: tatra yadāyaṃ jantuḥ śubhāśubheṣu kāryeṣu vṛttyanusārī jijñāsurajijñāsurvā śarīraṃ parityajati tāmeva karmayonimupapadyate /
analyzed: tatra yadā ayam jantuḥ śubha aśubheṣu kāryeṣu vṛtti anusārī jijñāsuḥ ajijñāsuḥ vā śarīram parityajati tām eva karma yonim upapadyate
translated: There, when this creature, following his inclinations in good and bad actions, whether desirous of knowing or not, abandons the body, he is reborn in that very womb of action.

analyzed: tasyām upapannaḥ tām eva bhāvayati
translated: Having been reborn there, he develops that very [action].

analyzed: āha ca

translated: He who does not keep his promise in speech, action, intention, and vow,

analyzed: tad niṣṭhaḥ tad pratijñaḥ ca dhṛteḥ etat hi lakṣaṇam
translated: Devoted to that and keeping that vow, this is the characteristic of fortitude.

analyzed: anasūyā brahmacaryam yajanam yājanam tapaḥ
translated: Non-envy, celibacy, sacrifice, officiating at sacrifices, austerity,

analyzed: dānam parigrahaḥ śaucam śraddhāyām lakṣaṇam smṛtam

analyzed: sukha arthī yaḥ tu seveta vidyām karma tapāṃsi vā
translated: He who seeks happiness should resort to knowledge, action, or austerities,

analyzed: prāyaścitta paraḥ nityam sukhāyām sa tu vartate

analyzed: dvi tva eka tva pṛthaktvam nityam cetanam acetanam sūkṣmam
translated: Duality, unity, separateness, the eternal, the conscious, the unconscious, the subtle,

analyzed: satkāryam asatkārya vividiṣitavyam vividiṣāyāḥ

analyzed: viṣa pīta supta matta vat a vividiṣā dhyāyinām sadā yoniḥ
translated: The womb of those who meditate is always like one who has drunk poison, fallen asleep, or is intoxicated, when there is no desire to know.

analyzed: kārya karaṇa kṣaya karī prākṛtikā gatiḥ samākhyātā
translated: The natural state, which destroys the effect and the means of effect, is said to be the same.

analyzed: viṣaya sa tattvam punar sarva viṣayiṇī dhṛtiḥ

analyzed: āśrama viṣayiṇī śraddhā

analyzed: dṛṣṭa ānuśravika viṣayiṇī sukhā  vyakta viṣayiṇī vividiṣā
translated: Happiness is the firm conviction regarding the seen and the heard.🔽Desire to know is the firm conviction regarding the manifest.

analyzed: avyakta viṣayiṇī avividiṣā
translated: Non-desire to know is the firm conviction regarding the unmanifest.

analyzed: guṇa samanvayaḥ tu rajaḥ tamaḥ bahulā dhṛtiḥ

analyzed: sattva rajaḥ bahulā śraddhā
translated: Faith is dominated by sattva and rajas.

analyzed: sattva tamaḥ bahulā sukhā
translated: Happiness is dominated by sattva and tamas.

analyzed: rajaḥ bahulā vividiṣā
translated: Desire to know is dominated by rajas.

analyzed: tamaḥ bahula vividiṣāḥ iti uktam ca
translated: Non-desire to know is dominated by tamas. It is also said:

analyzed: lakṣaṇa viṣaya sa tattvam traiguṇya samanvayam ca pañcānām
translated: The characteristics, objects, truth, and possession of the three qualities of the five have been explained.

original: yonīnāṃ yo vidyādyativṛṣabhaṃ taṃ tvahaṃ manye //
analyzed: yonīnām yaḥ vidyāt yati vṛṣabham tam tu aham manye

analyzed: iti uktāḥ prāṇa ādayaḥ yonayaḥ ca

analyzed: etat dvayam adhigamya samyak mārga anugamanam kuryāt
translated: Having understood these two, one should follow the right path.

analyzed: rajaḥ tamaḥ dharma ādi sādhana bhāva vinivṛttitaḥ tu atra prāṇānām antar vṛttiḥ anupādhika tvāt anivartyā
translated: But here, the internal functioning of the vital airs is irreversible due to the absence of conditions, from the cessation of the state of being the means of virtue, etc. dominated by rajas and tamas.

analyzed: bahis vṛttiḥ tu mārga amārga viṣaya tayā prayoktavyā
translated: However, the external functioning should be employed in terms of the objects of the path and the non-path.

analyzed: katham iti ucyate prāṇa viṣayā tāvat praṇatiḥ dharma ādi viṣaye eva aparoddhavyā
translated: How is this? First, the bowing to the vital airs should be obstructed only in terms of virtue, etc.

analyzed: tatas hi asya sattva vṛddhiḥ
translated: For from that, his vitality increases.

analyzed: sattva vṛddheḥ ca uttarottara buddhi rūpa adhigamaḥ
translated: And from the increase of vitality, the attainment of progressively higher forms of intelligence.

original: apānaviṣayastvapakramaṇaṃ dharmādiviṣaya evāparoddhavyamevaṃ hyasya khyātiviṣayākārasya tamaso nirhrāsaḥ /
analyzed: apāna viṣayaḥ tu apakramaṇam dharma ādi viṣayaḥ eva aparoddhavyam evam hi asya khyāti viṣaya ākārasya tamasaḥ nirhrāsaḥ
translated: But the downward movement should be understood to have only virtue, etc., as its object. For in this way, there is a decrease of that darkness which has the form of the object of manifestation.

analyzed: tatas ca uttara uttara buddhi rūpa adhigamaḥ
translated: And from that, the attainment of progressively higher forms of intelligence.

analyzed: tathā samāna viṣayam sāhacarya sattva dharma anuguṇam kuryāt
translated: Similarly, it should be made to have the same object, to be concomitant, and to be in accordance with the nature of beings.

analyzed: yasmāt śāstram āha sattva ārāmaḥ sattva mithunaḥ ca sadā syāt iti
translated: For this reason, the treatise says: One should always be devoted to beings and have intercourse with beings.

analyzed: ātma utkarṣa tu udāna viṣayam

analyzed: avidyā parvaṇaḥ ntyam rūpam vivarjya tad pratipakṣaiḥ nivartayet
translated: One should avoid the last form of the part of ignorance and turn it away with its antidotes.

original: atyantāvinābhāvaṃ ca vyānaviṣayaṃ jñānaviṣaya eva bhāvayet /🔽yonīnāṃ catasṛṇāṃ dharmatābījatāmevādadyāt /

translated: And one should cultivate the knowledge that has the all-pervading non-separation as its object.🔽And one should give the nature of the seeds of the four wombs.

analyzed: a vividiṣām api aniṣṭa phala hetuṣu bhāvayet
translated: And even for those who do not desire, one should cultivate [the four wombs] in relation to the causes of undesirable results.

original: so 'yaṃ dharmādiṣu pravaṇastatpratipakṣāpakrāntaḥ sattvārāmo vinivṛttābhimāno jñānaniṣṭhaḥ saviśuddhayoniracireṇa parama brahmopapadyata iti
analyzed: saḥ yam dharma ādiṣu pravaṇaḥ tad pratipakṣa apakrāntaḥ sattva ārāmaḥ vinivṛtta abhimānaḥ jñāna niṣṭhaḥ sa viśuddhayoniḥ acireṇa parama brahma upapadyate iti
translated: He who is inclined towards Dharma and so on, who has turned away from their opposites, who delights in beings, who has abandoned conceit, who is established in knowledge, who has a pure source, is quickly reborn in the highest Brahman.

analyzed: āha ca  bāhyām prāṇa vivṛttim samyak mārge budhaḥ pratiṣṭhāpya
translated: And it is said:🔽Having properly established the external life-force in the right path,

analyzed: vinivṛtta vikhara kaluṣaḥ dhruvam amṛtam sthānam abhyeti
translated: the wise one, whose rough impurities have ceased, certainly attains the state of immortality.

analyzed: pañcānām yonīnām dharma ādi nimitta tām ca saṃsthāpya
translated: Having established the five sources as the causes of Dharma and so on,

analyzed: paripakvam iti adhastāt na punar tad bhāvitaḥ gacchet
translated: when they are ripe, one should not go back to that state below.

analyzed: iti vyākhyātā vyasta samastā karaṇānām vṛttiḥ  kārikā
translated: Thus the functioning of the individual and combined organs has been explained.🔽The verse says:

original: āha / yeyamekaikasmin rūpādāvarthe karaṇacatuṣṭayasya vṛttiḥ sā kiṃ yugapat āhosvit krameṇeti /
analyzed: āha yā iyam ekaikasmin rūpa ādau arthe karaṇa catuṣṭayasya vṛttiḥ sā kim yugapad āhosvit krameṇa iti
translated: It is said: Is the functioning of the four organs in each object such as form simultaneous or gradual?

analyzed: kutas saṃśayaḥ iti ced ubhayathā dṛṣṭa tvāt

analyzed: iha eka artha viṣayāṇām yugapad api vṛttiḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: Here, the functioning of those with the same object is seen simultaneously.

analyzed: tat yathā candra maṇḍale cakṣuṣām manasaḥ vā

analyzed: kramaśas ca tat yathā ghaṭe madhu udaka payasām
translated: And gradually, like that of honey, water, and milk in a pot.

analyzed: eka artha viṣayam ca karaṇa catuṣṭayam

original: ato naḥ saṃśayaḥ kiṃ cakṣurmanovadyugapadasya vṛttiḥ /
analyzed: atas naḥ saṃśayaḥ kim cakṣuḥ manaḥ vat yugapad asya vṛttiḥ
translated: Therefore we have a doubt: Does the fourfold instrument function simultaneously like the eye and mind,

analyzed: āhosvit madhu ādi vat krameṇa iti
translated: or in succession like honey and so on?

analyzed: ucyate yathādarśanam api tāvat ucyatām
translated: It is said: Let it be stated according to what is seen.

analyzed: kim atra yuktam bhavān manyate
translated: What do you think is appropriate here?

original: sa cetsapyagupadekṣyasi ko nirbandhastadeva pratipadyāmahe iti /

translated: If you will teach that too, what is the point of insisting? We will accept that alone.

analyzed: yat yavam tasmāt idam asmad darśanam  yugapad catuṣṭayasya tu vṛttiḥ
translated: If so, this is our view:🔽But the function of the four is simultaneous.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ yugapad eva iti arthaḥ

analyzed: buddhi ahaṃkāra manasām hi buddhīndriyāṇām ca samāna deśa tvam
translated: For the intellect, ego, and mind, and the cognitive organs, have the same location.

original: tatra na śakyata etadvaktuṃ sati śaktisadbhāve viṣayasambandhe ca kasyacittatra vṛttiḥ kasyacinneti /
analyzed: tatra na śakyate etat vaktum sati śakti sadbhāve viṣaya sambandhe ca kasyacid tatra vṛttiḥ kasyacid na iti
translated: There it cannot be said that when the presence of ability and the connection with an object exist, the function of one exists there and not of another.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

analyzed: megha stanita ādiṣu krama anupalabdheḥ
translated: Because sequence is not perceived in clouds, thunder, and so on.

original: yadi hi krameṇa śrotrādīnāmantaḥkaraṇasya ca bāhye 'rthe vṛttiḥ syādapi tarhi meghastanitakṛṣṇasarpālocanādiṣvapyupalabhyate kramaḥ /
analyzed: yadi hi krameṇa śrotra ādīnām antaḥkaraṇasya ca bāhye rthe vṛttiḥ syāt api tarhi megha stanita kṛṣṇa sarpa ālocanā ādiṣu api upalabhyate kramaḥ
translated: For if the functioning of the ear, etc. and the internal organ were sequential with respect to the external object, then even in the case of a cloud, thunder, a black serpent, and looking, sequence would be perceived.

analyzed: na tu upalabhyate

analyzed: tasmāt yugapad eva bāhye rthe catuṣṭaya vṛttiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the functioning of the four is simultaneous with respect to the external object.

analyzed: ayuktam etat
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: kim kāraṇam
translated: What is the reason?

analyzed: yasmāt asmākam
translated: Because for us

analyzed: kramaśas ca tasya nirdiṣṭā
translated: and the sequence of that is indicated.

analyzed: tasya iti catuṣṭayam api sambadhyate

analyzed: caśabdaḥ vadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of determination.

analyzed: kramaśas eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is only in sequence.

analyzed: kramaśas eva hi bāhya antaḥkaraṇa vṛttyoḥ eka artha nipātaḥ
translated: For the functioning of the external and internal organs is the simultaneous engagement with one object.

analyzed: yat tu uktam samāna deśānām śakti sambandha sadbhāve vṛtti abhāva anupapattiḥ iti
translated: But what was said, that in the presence of the connection of power of those with the same location, the non-occurrence of functioning is not possible,

analyzed: atra brūmaḥ cakṣuḥ ādi vat etat syāt
translated: to that we reply: This would be like the eye, etc.

original: tadyathā cakṣustvacoḥ samānadeśatve śaktiviṣayasambandhopapattau rajodhūmātapādigataḥ sparśa evopalabhyate / na rūpam /
analyzed: tat yathā cakṣuḥ tvacoḥ samāna deśa tve śakti viṣaya sambandha upapattau rajaḥ dhūma ātapa ādi gataḥ sparśaḥ eva upalabhyate na rūpam
translated: For example, when the eye and the skin have the same location, and the connection with the object is possible, only the touch present in dust, smoke, and fog is perceived, not the color.

analyzed: evam iha api syāt tasmāt
translated: In the same way, it could be so here. Therefore,

analyzed: dṛṣṭe tathā api adṛṣṭe
translated: even though it is seen, when it is not seen,

analyzed: kramaśas eva catuṣṭayasya vṛttiḥ
translated: the four [types of cognition] operate in sequence.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa grahaṇena punar atra atīna āgata vyavahita viṣaya grahaṇam
translated: Moreover, in this [verse], the term not seen refers to the cognition of an object that is past, future, or obstructed.

analyzed: tatra atītam dvividham
translated: There, the past is of two kinds:

analyzed: dṛṣṭa viṣaya dṛṣṭa viṣayam ca

analyzed: atra api dṛṣṭa viṣayam pratyabhijñānam iti abhipretam
translated: Here too, recognition with a seen object is intended.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa viṣayam smṛtiḥ
translated: Memory is that which has an unseen object.

analyzed: sā tu liṅga āgamābhyām akasmāt vā bhavati
translated: But that arises either from an inferential mark or from a verbal testimony, or suddenly.

original: tathā ca vṛṣagaṇavīreṇāpyuktaṃ bhavati anāgatavyavahitaviṣayajñānaṃ tu liṅgagāgamābhyām / āha ca
analyzed: tathā ca vṛṣa gaṇa vīreṇa api uktam bhavati anāgata vyavahita viṣaya jñānam tu liṅga ga āgamābhyām āha ca
translated: And thus it is also said by Vṛṣagana Vīra: But the cognition of an object that is future or obstructed arises from an inferential mark or from a verbal testimony. He says:

analyzed: viṣaya indriya saṃyogāt pratyakṣa jñānam ucyate  tat eva atīndriyam jātam punar bhāvanayā smṛtiḥ
translated: Perceptual cognition is said to arise from the conjunction of the object and the sense faculty.🔽That very [cognition], when it becomes supersensible, is memory through reflection.

analyzed: tat eva bhāvanā apekṣa jñānam kāla antare punar
translated: That very cognition which depends on reflection, when it arises again at a later time,

analyzed: tatra eva sa indriyam jātam pratyabhijñānam ucyate
translated: with the same sense faculty, is said to be recognition.

original: tatra duṣṭe kramaḥ prati nāsti sandehaḥ /
analyzed: tatra duṣṭe kramaḥ prati na asti sandehaḥ
translated: There, if that is faulty, there is no doubt about the sequence.

original: yatpunaretaduktaṃ dṛṣṭe meghastanitakṛṣṭasarpālocanādau kramānupalabdheryugapaccatuṣṭayasya vṛttirityatra brūmaḥ etadapyayuktam /
analyzed: yat punar etat uktam dṛṣṭe megha stanita kṛṣṭa sarpa ālocanā ādau krama anupalabdheḥ yugapad catuṣṭayasya vṛttiḥ iti atra brūmaḥ etat api ayuktam
translated: As for what was said here, that since the sequence is not perceived in the seen, such as the lightning, thunder, snake, and eye, the four occur simultaneously, we say this is also incorrect.

analyzed: kim kāraṇam yasmāt
translated: What is the reason? Because

analyzed: trayasya tad pūrvikā vṛttiḥ
translated: the functioning of the three is preceded by that.

analyzed: na tāvat buddhi ahaṃkāra manasām sākṣāt bāhya artha grahaṇa sāmarthyam asti
translated: The intellect, ego, and mind do not have the power to directly grasp external objects.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa anupapatti prasaṃgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the non-existence of the internal organ.

analyzed: śrotra ādi vaiyarthya prasaṃgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the uselessness of the ear and other sense organs.

analyzed: dvāri dvāra bhāva vyāghāta prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because it would lead to the contradiction of the relation of door and door-opener.

analyzed: tasmāt pūrvam śrotra ādīnām artha sambandhaḥ sti megha stanita ādau api avaśyam etat abhyupagantavyam
translated: Therefore, it must necessarily be accepted that there is a prior connection of the ear and other sense organs with objects, even in the case of clouds, thunder, etc.

analyzed: paścāt tu tad vṛtti upanipātāt antaḥkaraṇasya iti asti
translated: But later, due to the convergence of their functioning, there is the functioning of the internal organ. So the sequence exists here also.

analyzed: tatra yat uktam megha stanita ādiṣu krama ananugate yugapad catuṣṭayasya vṛttiḥ iti etat ayuktam
translated: In that regard, what was said - that in the case of clouds, thunder, etc., which do not follow a sequence, the four occur simultaneously - this is incorrect.

analyzed: anyaiḥ tu anyathā anvayaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: But others have shown a different interpretation.

original: tadyathā catuṣṭayasya mano 'haṃkārabuddhīnāmantaḥkaraṇānāṃ bāhyenaikena karaṇena śrotreṇa vā cakṣuṣā vā saha catuṣṭayasyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā catuṣṭayasya manaḥ haṃkāra buddhīnām antaḥkaraṇānām bāhyena ekena karaṇena śrotreṇa vā cakṣuṣā vā saha catuṣṭayasya iti arthaḥ
translated: For example, of the four - mind, ego, intellect, which are the internal organs - together with one external organ, either the ear or the eye, it means of the four.

analyzed: asya dṛṣṭe vartamāne yugapad vṛttiḥ pūrva ācāryaiḥ nirdiṣṭā
translated: The functioning of this [mind] in the present, which is seen, has been indicated by the teachers to be simultaneous.

analyzed: ācāryeṇa tu krameṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: But the teacher [says] it is sequential.

analyzed: adṛṣṭe tīta ādau api kramaśas ca krameṇa eva
translated: Even in the unseen, past etc., it is also sequential, by sequence.

analyzed: yatas trayasya antaḥkaraṇasya tad pūrvikā bāhya indriya pūrvikā vṛttiḥ
translated: Because the functioning of the three internal organs is preceded by that, preceded by the external organs.

analyzed: yadā yathā anubhavaḥ tathā saṃskāraḥ
translated: When there is experience, the impression is in that way.

analyzed: yathā ca saṃskāraḥ tathā smṛtiḥ iti evam vṛttiḥ bāhya indriya pūrvikā iti
translated: And when there is impression, memory is in that way. Thus the functioning is preceded by the external organs.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: kārikā
