analyzed: āha kim punar eṣām karaṇānām sva viṣaya niyamena vṛttiḥ bhavati āhosvit vyatikareṇa iti
translated: It is said: Moreover, does the functioning of these organs occur restricted to their own objects, or by mutual interchange?

original: ucyate nanu ca prāgeva rūpādiṣu pañcānāmālocanamātramiṣyate vṛttiriti ISk
analyzed: ucyate nanu ca prāk eva rūpa ādiṣu pañcānām ālocana mātram iṣyate vṛttiḥ iti
translated: It is said: Is it not that the functioning of the five [sense organs] in form etc. is considered to be mere perception from the beginning?

analyzed: ca uktvā ācāryeṇa ante padiṣṭam sā eṣā bhavati asāmānyā iti
translated: And having said this, the teacher has stated at the end that this is indeed non-common.

analyzed: tatra evam gate bhavataḥ saṃśayaḥ
translated: When that is so, you have doubt.

analyzed: kutas iti ucyate satyam eva etat
translated: This is true.

analyzed: tathā api jāyate saṃśayaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, doubt arises.

analyzed: kutas karaṇa antareṇa sva viṣaya upalabdhau karaṇa antara autsukya darśanāt
translated: Why? Because when an object is perceived by another sense organ, activity of another sense organ is observed.

original: iha karaṇāntareṇa cakṣuṣāmradāḍimādirūpopalabdhau satyāṃ karaṇāntarasya jihvālakṣaṇasyautsukyaṃ pravṛttiścopalabdhā /
analyzed: iha karaṇa antareṇa cakṣuṣā āmra dāḍima ādi rūpa upalabdhau satyām karaṇa antarasya jihvā lakṣaṇasya autsukyam pravṛttiḥ ca upalabdhā
translated: Here, when the form of mango, pomegranate, etc. is perceived by the eye, which is another sense organ, activity and engagement of another sense organ characterized by the tongue is observed.

analyzed: tat yadi sva viṣaya niyatāni indriyāni
translated: If the sense organs are restricted to their own objects,

analyzed: na eṣām karaṇa antara viṣaya upalambhāt tad sāhacarya apekṣaḥ sva viṣaya grahaṇa bhāvaḥ syāt
translated: then their function of apprehending their own objects should not depend on the perception of the objects of other sense organs and on the activity of other sense organs.

analyzed: asti ca
translated: But it does.

analyzed: tasmāt upapannaḥ saṃśayaḥ  tatra idānīm bhavataḥ pratipattiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, doubt is reasonable.🔽Now, what is your understanding of this?

original: ucyate atrāpi nāstīndriyāṇāṃ svaviṣayagrahaṇavyatikaraḥ / kiṃ tarhi
analyzed: ucyate atra api na asti indriyāṇām sva viṣaya grahaṇa vyatikaraḥ kim tarhi
translated: It is said that even here, there is no conflict of the sense organs in apprehending their own objects. Rather,

analyzed: svām svām pratipadyante paraspara ākūta hetukīm vṛttim
translated: each attains its own, and the activity is based on the intention of each other.

original: puruṣārtha eva heturna kenacit kāryate karaṇam // //
analyzed: puruṣa arthaḥ eva hetuḥ na kenacid kāryate karaṇam
translated: The purpose of the person is the only cause. No instrument is produced by anyone.

original: yasya karaṇasya yā vṛttirapadiṣṭā tadyathā śrotrasya śabdagrahaṇam /
analyzed: yasya karaṇasya yā vṛttiḥ apadiṣṭā tat yathā śrotrasya śabda grahaṇam
translated: The activity of a particular instrument is mentioned, such as the hearing of sound by the ear,

analyzed: cakṣuṣaḥ rūpa grahaṇam ityādi
translated: the seeing of form by the eye, and so on.

analyzed: tām eva pratipadyante sva viṣaya jidhṛkṣayā avalambantaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: They attain that very [object], meaning they rely on it with the desire to grasp their own object.

analyzed: parasparasya ākūtam paraspara ākūtam  ākūtam abhiprāyaḥ bhisandhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The mutual intention is the mutual intention.🔽Intention means purpose, intention, resolution - this is the meaning.

analyzed: paraspara ākūtam hetuḥ pratipatteḥ asyāḥ
translated: The mutual intention is the cause of this attainment.

analyzed: sā iyam paraspara ākūta hetukī
translated: This is the one that has mutual intention as its cause.

original: parasparākūtaṃ pratipatteḥ kāraṇamiti kṛtvā tācchabdyaṃ labhate /
analyzed: paraspara ākūtam pratipatteḥ kāraṇam iti kṛtvā tācchabdyam labhate
translated: Considering the mutual intention to be the cause of attainment, it obtains the same name.

analyzed: tat yathā dadhi trapusam jvaraḥ
translated: For example, curd and whey are fever.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati yadā cakṣuṣāmradāḍimādi rūpamupalabdhaṃ bhavati tadā rasanendriyamupāttaviṣayasya cakṣuṣo vṛttiṃ saṃvedya svaviṣayajighṛkṣayautsuktavadvikāramāpadyate /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati yadā cakṣuṣā āmra dāḍima ādi rūpam upalabdham bhavati tadā rasana indriyam upātta viṣayasya cakṣuṣaḥ vṛttim saṃvedya sva viṣaya jighṛkṣayā autsukta vat vikāram āpadyate
translated: This is what is said: When the eye has perceived the form of an orange, etc., then the gustatory organ, having become aware of the activity of the eye whose object has been grasped, undergoes a change as if eager with the desire to grasp its own object.

original: rasanasya vṛtiṃ saṃvedya pādau viharaṇamārabhete hastāvādānaṃ /🔽tāvadyāvadasau viṣayo rasanendriyayogyatāṃ nītaḥ /
analyzed: rasanasya vṛtim saṃvedya pādau viharaṇam ārabhete hastau ādānam  tāvat yāvat asau viṣayaḥ rasana indriya yogya tām nītaḥ
translated: Having become aware of the activity of the gustatory organ, the feet begin to move, and the hands to grasp.🔽This continues until that object is brought into contact with the gustatory organ.

analyzed: tatas rasanam sva viṣaye pravartate
translated: Then the gustatory organ operates on its own object.

analyzed: evam itareṣu api vaktavyam
translated: The same should be said of the others as well.

analyzed: āha yadi evam tena tarhi indriya antara vṛtti saṃvedane kṣa pratyayava tva prasaṃgaḥ
translated: He says: If it is so, then there is the undesirable consequence that the awareness of the functioning of another sense faculty would be a sense-based cognition.

analyzed: yadi tarhi indriya antareṇa indriya antarasya vṛttiḥ saṃvedyate
translated: If, on the other hand, the functioning of one sense faculty is cognized by another sense faculty,

analyzed: prāptam asya pratyayavat tvam
translated: then it follows that it is a sense-based cognition.

analyzed: atha apratyayam indriyam paraspara ākūta saṃvedanam
translated: But if the sense faculty is not a sense-based cognition and does not cognize the intention of another,

analyzed: tarhi na vācyam iti
translated: then it should not be said.

analyzed: kim ca paraspara dvāri dvāra bhāva prasaṃgaḥ ca
translated: Moreover, there would be the undesirable consequence of mutual dependence.

analyzed: indriya antaram ced indriya antarasya vṛttim saṃvedya sva artham ākāṃkṣet
translated: If one sense faculty cognizes the functioning of another sense faculty and desires its own object,

analyzed: prāptam asya dvāri tvam itarasya ca dvāra tvam
translated: then it follows that it is dependent and the other is the means of dependence.

analyzed: tat ayuktam indriyāṇām paraspara ākūta saṃvedanam iti
translated: That is not correct, that the sense faculties cognize each other's intention.

analyzed: ucyate na upacārāt  prāk eva upadiṣṭam asmābhiḥ apratyayam indriyam iti
translated: It is said: No, because of figurative usage.🔽It has already been taught by us that the sense faculty is not a sense-based cognition.

original: kiṃ tarhi svaviṣayasya paṭoḥ sahacāriṇamarthamindriyāntaraviṣayatāmāpannaṃ saṃspṛśya svabhāvata indriyāntaraṃ svaviṣayaṃ prati sākāṃkṣaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: kim tarhi sva viṣayasya paṭoḥ sahacāriṇam artham indriya antara viṣaya tām āpannam saṃspṛśya svabhāvataḥ indriya antaram sva viṣayam prati sākāṃkṣam bhavati
translated: Then how is it? The sense faculty, by nature, desires its own object in relation to the object that accompanies its own object, which has become the object of another sense faculty, by contacting it.

analyzed: tad sannidhau vikriyā darśanāt
translated: Because a change is observed in its presence.

analyzed: tatra saṃvedanam upacarya evam ucyate iti adoṣaḥ
translated: There, consciousness is metaphorically spoken of in this way, so there is no fault.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: Moreover, what else?

analyzed: bhautika avayava pratyaya vivṛtti vat tad vivṛtteḥ
translated: Because of the transformation of the parts of the elements, like the transformation of the parts of the elements.

original: yathā buddheḥ prasādamanantaraṃ bhautikānāmavayavānāṃ mukhanayanādīnāṃ prasādo bhavati /
analyzed: yathā buddheḥ prasādam anantaram bhautikānām avayavānām mukha nayana ādīnām prasādaḥ bhavati
translated: Just as immediately after the clarity of the intellect, there is clarity of the parts of the elements such as the face, eyes, etc.

analyzed: na ca eṣām pratyayavat tvam
translated: And these do not have conditions.

analyzed: evam iha api syāt
translated: In the same way, it could be so here.

analyzed: na ca pratyayavat tvam
translated: And it does not have conditions.

analyzed: etena dvāri dvāra bhāvaḥ pratyuktaḥ
translated: By this, the state of being a door and not a door is refuted.

analyzed: manaḥ dhiṣṭhāna sāmarthyāt vā
translated: Or by the power of the mind being the basis.

analyzed: athavā paraspara viṣayam ākūtam paraspara ākūtam
translated: Or else, mutual intention is mutual intention.

analyzed: yathā jala viṣayaḥ puruṣaḥ jala puruṣaḥ
translated: Just as a person who has water as his object is a water person.

analyzed: ākūtam icchā saṃkalpaḥ manaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Intention means desire, imagination, mind.

analyzed: sa hetuḥ asyāḥ sā iyam paraspara ākūta hetukī tām
translated: This has that as its cause, so it has mutual intention as its cause.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: yathā kiṃcidindriyaṃ viṣaye pravṛttaṃ bhavati tadā taddvāreṇa samastamarthamupalabhya tatsahacāriṇamarthāntaramākāṃkṣadindriyāntaraṃ vṛttyā 🔽pratitiṣṭhate /
analyzed: yathā kiṃcid indriyam viṣaye pravṛttam bhavati tadā tad dvāreṇa samastam artham upalabhya tad sahacāriṇam artha antaram ākāṃkṣat indriya antaram vṛttyā 🔽pratitiṣṭhate
translated: Just as when some sense faculty becomes engaged with an object, then through that door it perceives the entire object and desires another object that accompanies it, the other sense faculty remains established with activity.

original: tenākāṃkṣāvatā manasādhiṣṭhitāmindriyaṃ vikriyāmāpadyate /🔽tathā ca tantrāntare 'pyuktaṃ yasya yasyendriyasya viṣayaṃ manodhyāyatyabhisampattyarthena tasya tasyautsukyaṃ pravṛttiśca bhavatīti /
analyzed: tena ākāṃkṣāvatā manasā adhiṣṭhitām indriyam vikriyām āpadyate  tathā ca tantra antare pi uktam yasya yasya indriyasya viṣayam manaḥ dhyāyati abhisampatti arthena tasya tasya autsukyam pravṛttiḥ ca bhavati iti
translated: The sense faculty, controlled by the mind that desires it, undergoes modification.🔽And thus it is said in another treatise: The mind reflects on the object of each sense faculty with the aim of attaining it, and there arises eagerness and activity towards that.

original: etaduktaṃ svāṃ svāṃ pratipadyante parasparākūtahetukīṃ vṛttiriti /
analyzed: etat uktam svām svām pratipadyante paraspara ākūta hetukīm vṛttiḥ iti
translated: This is what is meant by the activity of the mind and sense faculties is based on each other's intention.

original: kimindriyaṃ manovṛttyādhiṣṭhāya svaviṣaye pravartayati yathā paraśvādīṃścaitra iti /
analyzed: kim indriyam manaḥ vṛttyā adhiṣṭhāya sva viṣaye pravartayati yathā paraśu ādīn caitraḥ iti
translated: Does the mind control the sense faculty and make it engage in its object, just as Caitra does with an axe, etc.?

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: No, it is said.

original: kiṃ tarhi svaviṣayasaṃkalpānugṛhītasya manasaḥ saṃsparśātsvayamevendriyaṃ svaviṣayaṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: kim tarhi sva viṣaya saṃkalpa anugṛhītasya manasaḥ saṃsparśāt svayam eva indriyam sva viṣayam pratipadyate
translated: Then what? The sense faculty engages in its own object by itself, through contact with the mind, which is aided by the intention towards its own object.

analyzed: kasmāt prayoga śakti asiddheḥ
translated: Why? Because the power of application is not established.

original: na hi yathā caitrasya paraśvādiprayogaśaktiḥ siddhā evaṃ manasa indriyaprayogaśaktiḥ /
analyzed: na hi yathā caitrasya paraśu ādi prayoga śaktiḥ siddhā evam manasaḥ indriya prayoga śaktiḥ
translated: Just as the power of application of an axe, etc. is established for Caitra, so the power of application of the sense faculties is not established for the mind.

analyzed: tasmāt ayuktam indriyasya manaḥ prerakam iti  rajaḥ iti ced syāt matam
translated: Therefore it is not correct that the sense faculty is impelled by the mind.🔽If it is argued that it is due to rajas, that may be so.

analyzed: rajasaḥ hi indriya antara prayoga sāmarthyam vidyate
translated: For rajas has the ability to apply other sense faculties.

analyzed: tasmāt ayuktam uktam prayoga śakti asiddheḥ na indriyāṇām manaḥ prayojakam iti
translated: Therefore, it is incorrect to say that the senses are not prompted by the mind because the power of application is not established.

analyzed: etat ca ayuktam
translated: And this is incorrect.

analyzed: kasmāt aviśeṣāt
translated: Why? Because there is no distinction.

original: indriyāntare 'pi hi tarhi rajo 'stītyata ātmabhūtenaivāsya nimittena pravṛttirapratiṣiddhā /
analyzed: indriya antare pi hi tarhi rajaḥ sti iti atas ātma bhūtena eva asya nimittena pravṛttiḥ a pratiṣiddhā
translated: For then, in another sense organ also, there is rajas. Therefore, its activity by its own inherent cause is not prohibited.

analyzed: kim manasā parikalpitena iti
translated: What is the use of imagining a mind?

analyzed: kim ca anyat karaṇa antara anupapatteḥ
translated: Moreover, because another instrument is not possible.

original: caitro hi paraśvādīnāṃ prayogaṃ karaṇāntareṇa karoti /
analyzed: caitraḥ hi paraśu ādīnām prayogam karaṇa antareṇa karoti
translated: For Caitra uses another instrument to apply the axe and so on.

analyzed: na tu manasaḥ karaṇa antaram asti iti asamānam
translated: But there is no other instrument for the mind. So it is not the same.

analyzed: pāṇi vat iti ced na caitra vyāpāra apekṣa tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is like the hand, no, because it depends on Caitra's activity.

original: tadapi hi caitravyāpārāpekṣaṃ pravartate na svataḥ /
analyzed: tat api hi caitra vyāpāra apekṣam pravartate na svatas
translated: For that also operates depending on Caitra's activity, not by itself.

analyzed: kiṃca tad vyatirekeṇa pravṛtti upalabdheḥ
translated: And because activity is observed apart from that.

original: yasya hi prayojakāntarāpekṣā pravṛttiḥ na tasya kadācidapi svatantrasya bhavati /
analyzed: yasya hi prayojaka antara apekṣā pravṛttiḥ na tasya kadācid api svatantrasya bhavati
translated: For that whose activity depends on another prompter never occurs independently.

analyzed: asti tu saṃkalpa vyatirekeṇa megha stanita ādiṣu indriyasya pravṛttiḥ
translated: But the activity of the sense organ is observed in clouds, thunder, etc., apart from intention.

analyzed: tasmāt na indriya antarasya manaḥ kārakam
translated: Therefore, the mind is not the cause of another sense organ.

original: na cetkārakaṃ yathā maulānāṃ guṇānāmevamihāpi puruṣārtha evaṃ heturna kena citkāryate karaṇamiti siddham // //
analyzed: na ced kārakam yathā maulānām guṇānām evam iha api puruṣa arthaḥ evam hetuḥ na kena cit kāryate karaṇam iti siddham  /
translated: If it is not an instrument, just as the primary qualities, so here also the purpose of man is the cause, and no instrument is produced by anyone. Thus it is established.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: kārikā

analyzed: āha karaṇam prati ācārya vipratipatteḥ
translated: He says: Due to the disagreement of the teachers regarding the instrument.

analyzed: tad avadhāraṇam karttavyam
translated: That determination should be made.

analyzed: ācāryāṇām karaṇam prati vipratipattiḥ
translated: There is disagreement among the teachers regarding the instrument.

analyzed: ekādaśavidham iti vārṣagaṇāḥ
translated: The Vārṣagaṇas say it is of eleven kinds.

analyzed: daśavidham iti tāntrikāḥ pañca ādi karaṇa prabhṛtayaḥ
translated: The Tāntrikas, Pañcādhikaraṇa and others, say it is of ten kinds.

analyzed: dvādaśavidham iti patañjaliḥ
translated: Paṭañjali says it is of twelve kinds.

analyzed: tasmāt bhavataḥ katividham karaṇam abhipretam iti vaktavyam etat
translated: Therefore, it should be stated how many kinds of instrument are intended by you.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: karaṇam trayodaśavidham tad āharaṇa dhāraṇa prakāśa karam
translated: The instrument is of thirteen kinds, which brings, holds and illuminates.

original: pañca karmendriyāṇi pañca buddhīndriyāṇi mano 'haṅkāro buddhiścetyetatsarvaṃ puruṣārthopayogikaraṇam /
analyzed: pañca karmendriyāṇi pañca buddhīndriyāṇi manaḥ haṅkāraḥ buddhiḥ ca iti etat sarvam puruṣa artha upayogi karaṇam
translated: The five organs of action, the five organs of sense, the mind, the ego and the intellect - all this is the instrument useful for the purpose of the soul.

analyzed: kasmāt apuruṣa artha upayogi tve tattva antara anupapatti prasaṃgāt
translated: Why? Because if it is not useful for the purpose of the soul, it would lead to the absurdity of being a separate reality.

original: yadi yathā vārṣagaṇā āhuḥ liṅgamātre mahānasaṃvedyaḥ kāryakāraṇarūpeṇa viśiṣṭāviśiṣṭalakṣaṇena /
analyzed: yadi yathā vārṣagaṇāḥ āhuḥ liṅga mātre mahān asaṃvedyaḥ kārya kāraṇa rūpeṇa viśiṣṭa a viśiṣṭa lakṣaṇena
translated: If, as the Vārṣagaṇas say, the great one is to be known only through its mark, in the form of cause and effect, characterized by the specific and non-specific,

analyzed: tathā syāt tattva antaram
translated: then it would be a different reality.

analyzed: tat na syāt anarthaka tvāt
translated: That would not be so, because it would be meaningless.

original: āha / satyam / pradhānalakṣaṇānāṃ guṇānāṃ vaiṣamyamātrarūpatve 'pi tattvāntaramasau bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: āha satyam pradhāna lakṣaṇānām guṇānām vaiṣamya mātra rūpa tve tattva antaram asau bhaviṣyati iti
translated: He says: True, even though the qualities characterized by the primary nature have the form of mere inequality, it will be a different reality.

analyzed: kasmāt sāmyāt vaiṣamyam upākhyā antaram iti
translated: Why? Because inequality is a different name for equality.

analyzed: etat ca ayuktam
translated: And this is improper.

analyzed: kasmāt tattva anavasthā prasaṃgāt
translated: Why? Because of the consequence of infinite regress of realities.

original: evaṃ hi parikalpyamāne pradhānamahatoryadantarālaṃ tadapi ca kriyārūpatvādakriyāvata upākhyāntaramiti tattvāntarānavasthāprasaṃgaḥ /
analyzed: evam hi parikalpyamāne pradhāna mahatoḥ yat antarālam tat api ca kriyā rūpa tvāt akriyāvataḥ upākhyā antaram iti tattva antara anavasthā prasaṃgaḥ
translated: For if it is imagined in this way, that which is between the primary nature and the great one would also be a different name for the non-active, because it has the form of action. Thus there would be the consequence of infinite regress of different realities.

analyzed: abhyupagame vā mahataḥ tattva antarāṇām ca kriyā kāla virodhaḥ
translated: Or, if accepted, there would be a contradiction between the great one and the different realities in terms of time of action.

analyzed: tasmāt tattva antara anupapattiḥ anavasthā vā
translated: Therefore, either the different realities are not possible, or there is an infinite regress.

analyzed: trayodaśavidham karaṇam iti anyatara vat avaśyam abhyupagantavyam
translated: The thirteen kinds of instruments must necessarily be accepted like one of them.

analyzed: tatra ca asmad pratijñātam eva nirdoṣam lakṣyate
translated: And among them, only what we have postulated is seen to be faultless.

analyzed: tasmāt upapannam etat trayodaśavidham karaṇam iti
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that there are thirteen instruments.

analyzed: āha karaṇam iti kriyā kāraka sambandha garbhaḥ yam nirdeśaḥ
translated: He says: This explanation of the instruments contains the relation of action and agent.

analyzed: katham yena tat karaṇam iti
translated: How? By which it is an instrument.

analyzed: tatra vaktavyam kā kriyā
translated: There it should be said: What is the action?

original: kiṃ ca tatkriyate yadapekṣya buddhyādīnāṃ karaṇatvamiti /
analyzed: kim ca tat kriyate yat apekṣya buddhi ādīnām karaṇa tvam iti
translated: And what is that which is done, in relation to which the instrumentality of the intellect etc. is [spoken of]?

original: ucyate yaduktaṃ kā kriyetyatra brūmaḥ tannirvartakamihābhipretāt na daṇḍādivat /
analyzed: ucyate yat uktam kā kriyā iti atra brūmaḥ tat nirvartakam iha abhipretāt na daṇḍa ādi vat
translated: It is said: What was asked, what is the action? Here it is said: The agent is intended here, not like a stick etc.

analyzed: kim tarhi tat āharaṇa dhāraṇa prakāśa karam
translated: What then? It is that which brings, holds, and illuminates.

analyzed: tatra āharaṇam karmendriyāṇi kurvanti
translated: Among them, the action-faculties perform the bringing.

analyzed: viṣaya arjana samartha tvāt
translated: Because they are capable of acquiring objects.

analyzed: dhāraṇam buddhīndriyāṇi kurvanti
translated: The sense-faculties perform the holding.

analyzed: viṣaya sannidhāne sati śrotra ādi vṛtteḥ tad rūpa āpatteḥ
translated: Because when an object is present, the function of the ear etc. takes on its form.

analyzed: prakāśam antaḥkaraṇam karoti
translated: The internal organ performs the illumination.

analyzed: niścaya sāmarthyāt
translated: Because of the capacity for ascertainment.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha āharaṇam karmendriyāṇi kurvanti
translated: Another says: The action-faculties perform the bringing.

analyzed: dhāraṇam manaḥ haṃkāraḥ ca
translated: The mind and ego perform the holding.

analyzed: prakāśanam buddhīndriyāṇi buddhiḥ ca iti
translated: The sense-faculties and intellect perform the illumination.

analyzed: etat abhisandhāya buddhi ādīnām karaṇa tvam ucyate iti

analyzed: śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhāt gandha tanmātrāt pañcaguṇā pṛthivī

analyzed: sādhāraṇaḥ pṛthivyāḥ

analyzed: gandhaḥ tu pārthivaḥ eva tad avayava anupraveśāt bhūta antareṣu upalabhyate
translated: But the smell is only of earth, and is perceived in other elements due to the penetration of its particles.

analyzed: iti ete pṛthivī ādīnām dharmāḥ

analyzed: anye ca paraspara anugrāhakāḥ

analyzed: mārdavāt snāna avagāhanam eka kriyā kaṭhinānām cāvanāmanam

analyzed: rakṣātaḥ prajāsu ghora śamanam

analyzed: santānāt dravya saṃghātaḥ

analyzed: pavitra tvāt pūti dravya pavanam

analyzed: acchāya tvāt ahar rātra prasiddhiḥ

analyzed: asthi snāyu śukrāṇām pitṛtaḥ

translated: But when the limbs are developed and the sense organs are obtained, it comes out of the mother's womb and remains under the control of the two dharmas and adharmas created at the time of enjoying the six perfections,

analyzed: tad tyāgaḥ maraṇam

analyzed: kim ca sthāvarāṇām ca śarīra antara asambhavaḥ

analyzed: kasmāt amitam hi pradhāna tattvam bhāti jagat bīja bhūta tvāt mahat ādi bhāva pariṇāmena nyūnasya eka deśasya ātmanaḥ eva āpūrāt
translated: Why? Because the primordial nature shines forth as immeasurable due to being the seed of the universe, and because the Self, which is a part of it, is not filled up by the transformation into the state of Mahat and so on.

analyzed: tad vyatirekeṇa ca anyasya eka deśasya ubhaya dharmiṇaḥ bhoktṛ bhūtasya sadbhāvāt saṃprakṣālane ca apasaṃhṛtam
translated: And because there exists another part of it, which is characterized by both [being a product and a material cause], and which is the enjoyer, even when it is washed away, it is not withdrawn.

analyzed: vaiśvarūpyasya an ucchedāt
translated: Because the diversity is not destroyed.

original: tathā ca śāstramāha ambha iti guṇaliṅgasannicayamevādhikurute /
analyzed: tathā ca śāstram āha ambhaḥ iti guṇa liṅga sannicayam eva adhikurute
translated: And the scripture says thus: Water refers to the accumulation of the characteristics of the qualities.

original: guṇāśca sattvarajastamāṃsi /🔽liṅgaṃ ca mahadādi atra sannihitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: guṇāḥ ca sattva rajaḥ tamāṃsi  liṅgam ca mahat ādi atra sannihitam bhavati
translated: And the qualities are sattva, rajas, and tamas.🔽And the characteristic is Mahat and so on, which is present here.

analyzed: tat idam pradhānam amitam bhāti amitam upalabhyate iti ambhaḥ
translated: This primordial nature shines forth as immeasurable, is perceived as immeasurable, therefore it is water.

original: sa khalvayaṃ yogī pradhānalakṣaṇāṃ bhūmimavajitya tanmahimnā ca tadaśūnyaṃ dṛṣṭvā vyatiriktasya padārthāntarasyābhāvaṃ manyamānastāmeva bhūmiṃ
analyzed: sa khalu ayam yogī pradhāna lakṣaṇām bhūmim avajitya tad mahimnā ca tat a śūnyam dṛṣṭvā vyatiriktasya padārtha antarasya abhāvam manyamānaḥ tām eva bhūmim
translated: That yogi, having conquered the stage characterized by prakriti, and seeing it as not empty by its power, considering the absence of a separate different substance, grasps that very stage as

analyzed: kaivalyam iti gṛhṇāti
translated: isolation.

original: bhinne ca dehe prakṛtau layaṃ gacchati /
analyzed: bhinne ca dehe prakṛtau layam gacchati
translated: And when the body is dissolved, it merges into prakriti.

analyzed: tatas ca punar āvartate
translated: And then it returns again.

original: tasyāṃ ca tuṣṭāvanye sapta mahadādikāraṇino 'varuddhā draṣṭavyāḥ /
analyzed: tasyām ca tuṣṭau anye sapta mahat ādikāraṇinaḥ varuddhāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ
translated: And in that, the other seven consisting of mahat and so on, which are included, should be seen.

original: tatra yathā prādhānikasya puruṣe nāsti vijñānaṃ evamitareṣāmuttareṣu tattveṣu /🔽mahatkāraṇinaḥ pradhāne 'smitākāraṇino mahati /
analyzed: tatra yathā prādhānikasya puruṣe na asti vijñānam evam itareṣām uttareṣu tattveṣu  mahat kāraṇinaḥ pradhāne smitā kāraṇinaḥ mahati
translated: Just as the one consisting of prakriti has no consciousness in the purusha, in the same way the others have no consciousness in the higher principles.🔽The one consisting of mahat has no consciousness in prakriti.

analyzed: tanmātra kāraṇinaḥ haṃkāre
translated: The one consisting of ahamkara has no consciousness in mahat.

analyzed: tad eka deśāḥ ca eṣām bhoktāraḥ pūrvavat
translated: And a part of them are the enjoyers, as before.

analyzed: atra api ca sattva ādīnām saṃhata vivikta pariṇata vyasta samastānām bhedāt avidyā avaccheda ānantyam avaseyam
translated: And here also, the infinity of the divisions of ignorance should be understood from the differences of sattva and so on, combined, separated, transformed, mixed, and unmixed.

analyzed: āha tuṣṭi avidyayoḥ abhedaḥ lakṣaṇa eka tvāt
translated: It is said: There is no difference between tuști and ignorance, because of the identity of their characteristics.

analyzed: aṣṭāsu prakṛtiṣu ātma buddhiḥ tuṣṭiḥ
translated: Tuști is the notion of self in the eight prakritis.

analyzed: tat eva ca tamaḥ iti avidyā kāṇḍe nirdiṣṭam
translated: And that itself is called tamas in the section on ignorance.

analyzed: tasmāt padārtha saṃkaraḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is said that there is a confusion of the meanings of the words.

analyzed: ucyate na pratyaya viśeṣāt
translated: It is said no, because of the difference in the mental states.

original: tamaḥpradhānapuruṣopadeśe sati pratyayanirdidhārayiṣayā tayoḥ pradhānameva jyāyo na puruṣa ityabhiniviśeta /
analyzed: tamaḥ pradhāna puruṣa upadeśe sati pratyaya nirdidhārayiṣayā tayoḥ pradhānam eva jyāyaḥ na puruṣaḥ iti abhiniviśeta
translated: When tamas and purusha are taught as predominant, one would be firmly convinced that only the prakriti is superior, not the purusha, with the intention of determining the mental states.

original: tuṣṭistu kiṃ paramityāśritya pravṛttaḥ pradhānajñānamātre santoṣātpadārthāntaraṃ vijñātumeva nādriyate /
analyzed: tuṣṭiḥ tu kim param iti āśritya pravṛttaḥ pradhāna jñāna mātre santoṣāt padārtha antaram vijñātum eva na ādriyate
translated: But what is the ultimate satisfaction? Having taken this up, one who is engaged in it does not bother to know any other meaning at all, due to being content with just the knowledge of prakriti.

analyzed: kim ca prahāṇa viśeṣāt
translated: Moreover, because of the difference in renunciation.

analyzed: nirūḍha mūlaḥ hi anātmani ātma grahaḥ jñāna uttara kāla bhāvanayā prahātavyaḥ
translated: For the firm-rooted identification of the non-self as the self should be abandoned by the contemplation that comes after knowledge.

analyzed: tamaḥ bahula tvāt tamaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: It is called tamas because it is full of darkness.

analyzed: pelavaḥ tu sattva bahulaḥ darśana praṇayaḥ tuṣṭiḥ
translated: But satisfaction is slight, full of existence, and is the attachment to seeing.

analyzed: kiṃca tattva abhijayāt
translated: And also because of the conquest of reality.

analyzed: vijita bhūmikasya hi yoginaḥ tad māhātmya vaśīkṛta tvāt bhūmi antare pravṛttiḥ tuṣṭiḥ
translated: For the yogi who has conquered the stage, the satisfaction that arises in another stage is due to his being controlled by its greatness.

analyzed: itarasya tu abhiniveśa mātram eva iti anayoḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: But for the other, it is mere attachment. This is the difference between the two.

original: tasmānna padārthasaṃkara iti vyākhyātā prakṛtyākhyā tuṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt na padārtha saṃkaraḥ iti vyākhyātā prakṛti ākhyā tuṣṭiḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no confusion of meanings. Thus has been explained the satisfaction called prakriti.

original: yadā tu satyapi prakṛtisāmarthye nānapekṣya yathāsvamupādānaṃ bhāvānāmutpattiḥ sambhavati prakṛtyaviśeṣe sarvakālamutpattiprasaṃgāt /🔽prakṛtikṛtyamevedaṃ viśvamityabhyupagacchatastadaviśeṣād goḥ puruṣādutpattiprasaṃgaḥ /
analyzed: yadā tu sati api prakṛti sāmarthye na an apekṣya yathāsvam upādānam bhāvānām utpattiḥ sambhavati prakṛti aviśeṣe sarvakālam utpatti prasaṃgāt  prakṛti kṛtyam eva idam viśvam iti abhyupagacchataḥ tad aviśeṣāt goḥ puruṣāt utpatti prasaṃgaḥ
translated: But when, even though there is natural capability, the production of things does not occur without relying on their own material causes, because if there were no distinction in nature, production would occur at all times.

analyzed: puruṣasya vā mahiṣāt
translated: For one who accepts that this universe is just the activity of nature, there would be the consequence of production from a cow for a man, and from a buffalo for a man.

analyzed: kim ca jāti abheda prasaṃgāt
translated: And what's more, there would be the consequence of the non-distinction of species.

analyzed: prakṛti kṛtyam idam viśvam iti abhyupagacchataḥ jāti bhedaḥ na syāt
translated: For one who accepts that this universe is just the activity of nature, there would be no distinction of species.

analyzed: tad aviśeṣāt
translated: Because of the non-distinction of that.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam tu upādānāt jāti anuvidhānam bhāvānām
translated: But the dependence of things on their species is seen to be due to their material causes.

analyzed: tasmāt tat eva kāraṇa tvena parikalpayitum nyāyyam
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable to imagine that alone as the cause.

original: upādānaikadeśa eva ca kāryakāraṇavidhātmā bhoktetyetasmād darśanātsaṅgadveṣanivṛttiṃ labhate /
analyzed: upādāna eka deśaḥ eva ca kārya kāraṇa vidhā ātmā bhoktā iti etasmāt darśanāt saṅga dveṣa nivṛttim labhate
translated: And because of the seen fact that the self, which is a part of the material cause, is the enjoyer due to the arrangement of cause and effect, one attains the cessation of attachment and aversion.

analyzed: sā dvitīyā tuṣṭiḥ salilam iti abhidhīyate
translated: That second satisfaction is called water.

analyzed: katham punar etat salilam
translated: But how is this water?

analyzed: sati upādāne vikāraḥ līyate iti
translated: When there is a material cause, modification dissolves into it.

original: tathā ca kṛtvā śāsramāha salilaṃ salilamiti vaikārikopanipātamevādhikurute /
analyzed: tathā ca kṛtvā śāsram āha salilam salilam iti vaikārika upanipātam eva adhikurute
translated: And having done so, the scripture says water in water, it refers only to the contact with the modification.

analyzed: sati tasmin līyate jagat iti
translated: When that exists, the world dissolves.

original: sa khalvayaṃ yogī pārthivānavajitya tanmahimnā jagadaśūnyaṃ dṛṣṭvā padārthāntarasyābhāvaṃ manyamānastāmeva bhūmiṃ kaivalyamiti gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: sa khalu ayam yogī pārthivān avajitya tad mahimnā jagat a śūnyam dṛṣṭvā padārtha antarasya abhāvam manyamānaḥ tām eva bhūmim kaivalyam iti gṛhṇāti
translated: Now, this yogi, having conquered the earth, seeing the world as non-empty by its power, considering the absence of another object, grasps that very stage as liberation.

analyzed: bhinne ca dehe pṛthivī ādiṣu līyate
translated: And when the body is dissolved, he dissolves into earth and so on.

analyzed: tatas ca punar āvartate
translated: And then he returns again.

original: yadā ca satyupādānasāmarthye na tāvataiva bhāvānāṃ prādurbhāvaḥ kiṃ tarhi sannihitasādhanānāmapi kālaṃ pratyapekṣā bhavati kālaviśeṣādbījādaṅkuro🔽aṅkurānnālaṃ /
analyzed: yadā ca sati upādāna sāmarthye na tāvatā eva bhāvānām prādurbhāvaḥ kim tarhi sannihita sādhanānām api kālam pratyapekṣā bhavati kāla viśeṣāt bījāt aṅkuraḥ  aṅkurāt nālam
translated: And when there is the capacity of the material cause, if the manifestation of things does not occur just by that, then even for those with available means, there is dependence on time. From a specific time, a sprout from a seed,🔽from a sprout a stalk,

analyzed: nālāt kāṇḍam
translated: from a stalk a stem,

analyzed: kāṇḍāt prasavaḥ ityādi
translated: from a stem a flower, and so on.

analyzed: anyathā tu upādānānām sannidhāna mātrāt kṣaṇena eva amīṣām avasthā viśeṣāṇām abhivyaktiḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, by the mere presence of the material causes, these specific states would manifest in an instant.

analyzed: kiṃca kāla viparyayeṇa utpatti prasaṃgāt
translated: And because of the possibility of arising in the reverse order of time.

analyzed: na ca etat iṣṭam
translated: And this is not accepted.

analyzed: kim ca tad anabhidhānāt
translated: And what of that, because it is not mentioned?

analyzed: dṛśyante ca prāṇinām kāla anurūpāḥ sva abhāva āhāra vihāra vyavasthāḥ
translated: And the natural states of food and activity of beings are seen to correspond to time.

analyzed: tasmāt asau eva kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, that alone is the cause.

analyzed: tad eka deśaḥ ca a prakṛti vikāra bhūtaḥ bhoktā iti etasmāt darśanāt saṃga dveṣa nivṛttim labhate
translated: And a part of that, not being a product of primordial matter, is the enjoyer. From this view, one obtains cessation of attachment and aversion.

analyzed: sā tṛtīyā tuṣṭiḥ oghaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: That is the third contentment, called the flood.

analyzed: katham punar ayam kālaḥ oghaḥ iti ucyate
translated: How is this time called a flood?

analyzed: salila ogha vat sarva abhyāvahanāt
translated: Because it carries all along like a flood of water.

original: tadyathā salilaughastṛṇaṃ kāṣṭhamaśmānaṃ prāṇinaṃ vā svamūrtisaṃsṛṣṭaṃ sarvamevābhyāvahati /
analyzed: tat yathā salila oghaḥ tṛṇam kāṣṭham aśmānam prāṇinam vā sva mūrti saṃsṛṣṭam sarvam eva abhyāvahati
translated: Just as a flood of water carries along everything that is in contact with its form, such as grass, wood, stones, or living beings,

analyzed: evam ayam kālaḥ garbhāt bālyam  bālyāt kaumāram
translated: in the same way, this time carries from the womb to childhood,🔽from childhood to youth,

analyzed: kaumārāt yauvanam  yauvanāt sthāviryam
translated: from youth to maturity,

analyzed: sthāviryāt maraṇam
translated: from maturity to death.

original: tathā bījānmūlaṃ mūlādaṅkuramiti vahati / tathā cāha
analyzed: tathā bījāt mūlam mūlāt aṅkuram iti vahati tathā ca āha
translated: Similarly, from the seed to the root, from the root to the sprout, it carries. Thus it is said:

original: yāmeva prathamāṃ rātriṃ garbhe bhavati pūruṣaḥ /
analyzed: yām eva prathamām rātrim garbhe bhavati pūruṣaḥ
translated: The very first night a man is conceived in the womb,

analyzed: saṃprasthitaḥ tām bhavati sa gacchan na nivartate
translated: he sets out on his journey, going he does not return.

analyzed: tasmāt ogha sāmānyāt oghaḥ kālaḥ
translated: Therefore, because of the similarity to a flood, time is a flood.

original: sa khalvayaṃ yogī kālamavajitya padārthāntarābhāvaṃ manyamānastāmeva bhūmiṃ kaivalyamiti manyate /
analyzed: sa khalu ayam yogī kālam avajitya padārtha antara abhāvam manyamānaḥ tām eva bhūmim kaivalyam iti manyate
translated: That yogi, considering the absence of other things after conquering time, considers that very stage to be liberation.

analyzed: dehabhede ca kālam anupraviśati
translated: And upon the dissolution of the body, he enters into time.

analyzed: tatas ca punar āvartate
translated: And then he returns again.

original: yadā tu satyapi kālasāmarthye bhāvānāmutpattiḥ bhāgyānapekṣate /
analyzed: yadā tu sati api kāla sāmarthye bhāvānām utpattiḥ bhāgyān apekṣate
translated: But when, even in the presence of the power of time, the production of things does not depend on luck,

analyzed: kasmāt tad sannidhāne pi aprādurbhāvāt
translated: why is it so? Because they do not appear even in its presence.

original: satyapi sādhanasāmarthye kālaviśeṣe ca kasyacidutpattirbhavati kasyacinneti /
analyzed: sati api sādhana sāmarthye kāla viśeṣe ca kasyacid utpattiḥ bhavati kasyacid na iti
translated: Even when the power of the means and a particular time are present, the production of some happens, while that of some does not.

analyzed: tasmāt asti kāraṇa antaram yat apekṣya bhāvānām utpattiḥ anutpattiḥ ca
translated: Therefore, there is another cause depending on which there is the production and non-production of things.

analyzed: kim ca abhyutthāna anupapatti prasaṃgāt
translated: Moreover, because it would lead to the absurdity of the impossibility of rising up.

analyzed: kāla mātrāt phalam bhavati iti etat icchataḥ śāstra ukteṣu kriyā viśeṣeṣu abhiṣecana vrata upavāsa agnihotra ādiṣu abhyutthānam na syāt
translated: For one who desires that the result comes from time alone, there would be no rising up in the special actions enjoined by the scriptures, such as consecration, vows, fasting, agnihotra, etc.

analyzed: kasmāt ānarthakyāt
translated: Why is it so? Because of meaninglessness.

analyzed: asti ca tasmāt na kāla nimittā bhāvānām utpattiḥ
translated: And yet it does happen. Therefore, the production of things is not due to time.

analyzed: kim ca tad anuvidhānāt
translated: Moreover, because of its conformity.

analyzed: dṛśyante khalu api prakṛti upādāna kāla aviśeṣe pi bhāgya viśeṣāt phala viśeṣāḥ
translated: Indeed, even when there is no difference in nature, material cause, or time, differences in results are seen due to differences in fortune.

analyzed: tasmāt tad saṃkāraḥ eva kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, that transformation itself is the cause.

analyzed: tad eka deśaḥ ca a prakṛti vikāra bhūtaḥ bhoktā iti etasmāt darśanāt saṃga dveṣa nivṛttim labhate
translated: And a part of that, not being a modification of nature, is the enjoyer. From this teaching, one attains freedom from attachment and aversion.

analyzed: sā caturthī tuṣṭiḥ vṛṣṭiḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: That fourth satisfaction is called rain.

analyzed: katham punar vṛṣṭiḥ iti ucyate
translated: How is it called rain?

analyzed: sarva sattva āpyāyanāt
translated: Because it nourishes all beings.

original: yathā hi śīrṇānāmapi tṛṇalatādīnāṃ vṛṣṭiṃ prāpya punarāpyāyanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yathā hi śīrṇānām api tṛṇa latā ādīnām vṛṣṭim prāpya punar āpyāyanam bhavati
translated: Just as when grass, vines, etc. are withered, upon receiving rain they are nourished again,

analyzed: evam eva sarveṣām prāṇinām bhāgya vipariṇāmāt punar āpyāyanam bhavati
translated: in the same way, by the transformation of fortune, all living beings are nourished again.

analyzed: tasmāt vṛṣṭi sāmyāt bhāgya ākhyā tuṣṭiḥ vṛṣṭiḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: Therefore, because of its similarity to rain, the satisfaction called fortune is called rain.

analyzed: śāstram api āha vṛṣṭiḥ vṛṣṭiḥ iti śriyaḥ eva upanipātam adhikurute
translated: The scriptures also say, Rain, rain! It refers to the descent of prosperity.

analyzed: sā hi vṛṣṭi vat sarvam āpyāyati iti
translated: For just as rain nourishes everything, so does that.

original: sa khalvayaṃ yogī bhāgyānyavajitya tanmahimnā jagadaśūnyaṃ dṛṣṭvā padārthāntarasyābhāvaṃ manyamānastāmeva bhūmiṃ kaivalyamiti gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: sa khalu ayam yogī bhāgyāni avajitya tad mahimnā jagat a śūnyam dṛṣṭvā padārtha antarasya abhāvam manyamānaḥ tām eva bhūmim kaivalyam iti gṛhṇāti
translated: That yogi, having overcome good and bad luck, seeing the world as non-empty due to their power, considering there is no other reality, grasps that very stage as liberation.

analyzed: sa tasyām eva dehabhede līyate
translated: He dissolves into that very stage upon the dissolution of the body.

analyzed: tatas ca punar āvartate iti
translated: And then he returns again.

analyzed: āha kāla bhāgyayoḥ apratipattiḥ
translated: It is said: The non-understanding of time and luck.

analyzed: samākhyā parijñānāt
translated: Because of the recognition of the designation.

original: prakṛtyātmakasya tāvadyogino 'ṣṭau prakṛtayo viṣaya ityuktaṃ purastāt /
analyzed: prakṛti ātmakasya tāvat yoginaḥ ṣṭau prakṛtayaḥ viṣayaḥ iti uktam purastāt
translated: It has been said before that for the yogi who is of the nature of Prakṛti, the eight Prakṛtis are the objects.

analyzed: upādāna ātmakasya ca pṛthivī ādīni mahābhūtāni
translated: And for the one who is of the nature of upādāna, the great elements such as earth.

analyzed: kāla bhāgyayoḥ tu na tathā uktam
translated: But time and luck have not been said in the same way.

original: tasmādvaktavyaṃ kasya tattvasyaiṣā samākhyeti /🔽ucyate na / uktatvāt /
analyzed: tasmāt vaktavyam kasya tattvasya eṣā samākhyā iti  ucyate na ukta tvāt
translated: Therefore, it should be said: To which reality does this designation belong?🔽It is said: No, because it has already been stated.

analyzed: prāk eva etat apadiṣṭam na kālaḥ nāma kaścid padārthaḥ sti
translated: This has already been pointed out: There is no such thing as time.

analyzed: kim tarhi kriyāsu kāla saṃjñā
translated: Then what? The designation of time is in actions.

analyzed: tāḥ ca karaṇa vṛttiḥ iti
translated: And they are the function of the instruments.

analyzed: pratipāditam
translated: It has been explained.

analyzed: na ca anyā vṛttiḥ vṛttimataḥ
translated: And there is no other function than the functioning.

analyzed: tasmāt kāraṇa caitanya pratijñaḥ kāla ātmakaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the one who has vowed the consciousness of the cause is of the nature of time.

analyzed: bhāgya saṃjñā tu dharma adharmayoḥ
translated: But the designation of luck is of dharma and adharma.

analyzed: tau ca buddhi dharmau iti prāk apadiṣṭam
translated: And those two are the properties of intellect, as stated earlier.

analyzed: tasmāt bhāgya vādī buddhi caitanikaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the proponent of destiny is the one who asserts the sentience of intellect.

analyzed: āha na tuṣṭi antara tvāt
translated: He says: Not because of being a different satisfaction.

analyzed: prakṛti tvāt mahān pūrvam prakṛti ākhyāyām tuṣṭau avaruddhaḥ
translated: Because of being the cause, the great one is mentioned first. But in the designation of primordial nature, it is restricted.

analyzed: tasya idānīm tuṣṭi antara tvena parikalpanam na ati samañjasam iti
translated: Therefore, the conception of it as a different satisfaction is not very reasonable.

analyzed: ucyate mahān tarhi pūrva tuṣṭi viṣaya bhāvāt apakṛṣyate iti
translated: It is said: Then the great one is removed from the object of the previous satisfaction.

analyzed: kārya karaṇa vṛtti kriyā rūpām vṛttimat dyotyām parikalpya tasyām kāla tva mayam āha
translated: Having conceived the manifestation in the form of the activity of the functioning of the body and organs, he declares time in that manifestation.

original: mahataśca rūpaṃ dharmādikaṃ mahato 'rthāntaraṃ bhāgyamiti bhāgyavān /
analyzed: mahataḥ ca rūpam dharma ādikam mahataḥ ṛtha antaram bhāgyam iti bhāgyavān
translated: And the form of the great one, which is dharma etc., is different from the great one. Destiny is fortune. He is fortunate.

original: athavā bāhya evāyaṃ kālaḥ karmakāraṇaṃ nirdiśyate /
analyzed: athavā bāhyaḥ eva ayam kālaḥ karma kāraṇam nirdiśyate
translated: Or this external time is indicated as the cause of action.

original: tatra cānye 'pi svamatiparikalpitapadārthāntarātmabhāvagrahā eveti sāṅkhyāḥ pravādinaḥ pratikṣiptā boddhavyā iti /
analyzed: tatra ca anye sva mati parikalpita padārtha antarātma bhāva grahāḥ eva iti sāṅkhyāḥ pravādinaḥ pratikṣiptāḥ boddhavyāḥ iti
translated: And there, the Sāṃkhyas who proclaim other things imagined by their own minds as the nature of the self should be understood to be refuted.

original: apara āha / prakṛticaitanikaḥ pradhānabhāvāśādyupādānakālabhāgyavādino mahadahaṅkāratanmātravādina iti /
analyzed: aparaḥ āha prakṛti caitanikaḥ pradhāna bhāva āśā ādi upādāna kāla bhāgya vādinaḥ mahat ahaṅkāra tanmātra vādinaḥ iti
translated: Another says: The proponent of the sentience of primordial nature, the proponent of the primordial nature as the cause, the proponent of time, and the proponent of destiny, the proponent of the great one, the ego, and the subtle elements.

analyzed: tat etat apasiddha tvāt ayuktam
translated: This is not correct because it is self-contradictory.

original: na hi mahadahaṅkāratanmātralakṣaṇāḥ prakṛtaya upādānakālabhāgyabhāvena prasiddhāḥ /
analyzed: na hi mahat ahaṅkāra tanmātra lakṣaṇāḥ prakṛtayaḥ upādāna kāla bhāgya bhāvena prasiddhāḥ
translated: For the primal natures characterized as the great one, ego, and subtle elements are not well known as existing at the time of the material cause.

analyzed: tasmāt idam api ayuktam
translated: Therefore this is also incorrect.

analyzed: evam etāḥ ādhyātmikyaḥ catasraḥ tuṣṭayaḥ
translated: Thus these are the four kinds of contentment related to the self.

original: bāhyā viṣayoparamāt pañca ca nava tuṣṭayo 'bhihitāḥ // //
analyzed: bāhyāḥ viṣaya uparamāt pañca ca nava tuṣṭayaḥ bhihitāḥ
translated: And the five external ones are mentioned as the nine kinds of contentment due to the cessation of objects.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ vadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word and has the meaning of restriction.

analyzed: avyutpanna ātma vicārasya yoginaḥ viṣaya doṣa darśana mātrāt saṃga doṣa nivṛttiḥ bāhyā tuṣṭiḥ
translated: For the yogi whose investigation of the self is not yet developed, the cessation of attachment due to merely seeing the faults of objects is external contentment.

original: tatra yadārjanadoṣamavagacchati na tāvatsarvasyābhijātirastīti arthināvaśyaṃ viṣayārjane vartitavyam /
analyzed: tatra yadā arjana doṣam avagacchati na tāvat sarvasya abhijātiḥ asti iti arthinā avaśyam viṣaya arjane vartitavyam
translated: Among them, when one understands the fault of acquisition, one should not think that everyone has high birth, so those who seek must necessarily engage in acquiring objects.

analyzed: teṣām asvābhāvika tvāt kvacid eva avasthitiḥ iti uktam prāk
translated: Because they are not natural, their existence is only in some places, as stated earlier.

analyzed: kim ca sa pratyanīka tvāt
translated: Moreover, because of having adversaries.

original: svābhāvikamavasthānaṃ viṣayāṇāmaparikalpyāpi yadā pratigrahādibhirarjanaṃ pratyādriyate tadapyayuktam /
analyzed: svābhāvikam avasthānam viṣayāṇām a parikalpya api yadā pratigraha ādibhiḥ arjanam pratyādriyate tat api ayuktam
translated: If the natural existence of objects is accepted even without imagination, and their acquisition is undertaken through receiving gifts and so on, that is also incorrect.

analyzed: kutas sa pratyanīka tvāt
translated: Why? Because of having adversaries.

original: evamapi nāsti kaścidapratyanīka viṣayopārjanāya iti tadvighāte 'vaśyaṃ prayatitavyam /
analyzed: evam api nā asti kaścid apratyanīka viṣaya upārjanāya iti tad vighāte vaśyam prayatitavyam
translated: Even so, there is no object that is not opposed [to some other object], so one must certainly strive to counteract it.

original: sa ca yadi pratiyatamānaḥ pratyanīkivighātaṃ kuryātparopaghātenātmānugrahānuṣṭhānācchāstravirodhaḥ / yasmādāha
analyzed: sa ca yadi pratiyatamānaḥ pratyanīki vighātam kuryāt para upaghātena ātma anugraha anuṣṭhānāt śāstra virodhaḥ yasmāt āha
translated: And if, when one strives, one were to destroy the opposing object by harming others, then by engaging in benefiting oneself through harming others, one would contradict the scriptures. Because it is said:

analyzed: na tat parasya sandadhyāt pratikūlam yat ātmanaḥ
translated: One should not do to others what is disagreeable to oneself.

analyzed: eṣa saṃkṣepataḥ dharmaḥ kāmāt anyaḥ pravartate
translated: This, in brief, is the Dharma, which is different from desire and proceeds [from that].

analyzed: punar api āha  prāṇinām upaghātena yaḥ ṛthaḥ samupajāyate
translated: Again, it is said:🔽The wealth that arises through harming living beings

analyzed: saḥ napekṣaiḥ prahātavyaḥ loka antara vighāta kṛt
translated: should be abandoned by those who are impartial, for it destroys the welfare of other worlds.

analyzed: tasmāt saṃghāta mātra tvāt sattva ādīnām ghaṭa ādi vat
translated: Therefore, because living beings are mere aggregates, like pots and so on,

analyzed: ābrahmaṇaḥ parijñāya dehānām anavasthitim
translated: having fully understood the impermanence of bodies up to Brahma,

original: satyaṃ sadbhirādīptaṃ tṛṇolkācapalaṃ sukham /🔽sudṛḍhairna nipātavyaṃ duḥkhairdehāntarodbhavaiḥ //
analyzed: satyam sadbhiḥ ādīptam tṛṇa ulkā capalam sukham  su dṛḍhaiḥ na nipātavyam duḥkhaiḥ deha antara udbhavaiḥ
translated: the real happiness, which is firmly grasped by the virtuous, is fleeting like a grass torch,🔽one should not be struck down by the sufferings arising from other bodies.

analyzed: atha punar ayam pratyanīkaiḥ vihanyate
translated: But if this [happiness] is obstructed by opposing factors,

analyzed: viṣaya abhāvaḥ
translated: then it lacks an object.

original: sukhārthaṃ ca pravṛttasya bhūyiṣṭhaṃ duḥkhamevetyetasmāddarśanānmādhyasthyaṃ labhate /
analyzed: sukha artham ca pravṛttasya bhūyiṣṭham duḥkham eva iti etasmāt darśanāt mādhyasthyam labhate
translated: And for one engaged in action for the sake of pleasure, there is mostly only suffering. From this observation, one attains equanimity.

analyzed: sā pañcamī tuṣṭiḥ sutāram iti abhidhīyate
translated: That fifth satisfaction is called well-crossed.

analyzed: katham punar sutāram iti ucyate
translated: How, then, is it called well-crossed?

analyzed: sukham anena upāyena taranti viṣaya saṃkaṭam iti su tāram
translated: By this means, they cross the difficult terrain of objects, thus it is well-crossed.

original: yadā tu yogī pūrvadoṣādhigame 'bhijātyā vā yatnārjitaviṣayatve sati rakṣādoṣamupanyasyati /
analyzed: yadā tu yogī pūrva doṣa adhigame vā yatna arjita viṣaya tve sati rakṣā doṣam upanyasyati
translated: But when the yogi, having recognized the previous faults or having attained objects through effort, presents the fault of protection,

analyzed: katham bhoktṛ bhogya bhāva avyatirekāt sarva prāṇi sādhāraṇāḥ viṣayāḥ
translated: how? Because of the non-difference of the relation of enjoyer and enjoyed, objects are common to all living beings.

original: tasmātteṣāṃ rakṣā vidheyā /🔽tasyāṃ ca pravartamāno yadi paramuparundhyāt tadā pūrvoktadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt teṣām rakṣā vidheyā  tasyām ca pravartamānaḥ yadi param uparundhyāt tadā pūrva ukta doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, their protection should be undertaken.🔽And if one engages in that and obstructs others, then the previously mentioned fault arises.

analyzed: atha ātmānam
translated: If one obstructs oneself,

analyzed: viṣaya abhāvaḥ
translated: there is the absence of objects.

original: rātrindivaṃ ca tadekāgramanasaḥ sukhārthaṃ pravṛtasya bhūyiṣṭhaṃ duḥkhamevetyetasmāddarśanānmādhyasthyaṃ labhate /
analyzed: rātrindivam ca tad ekāgra manasaḥ sukha artham pravṛtasya bhūyiṣṭham duḥkham eva iti etasmāt darśanāt mādhyasthyam labhate
translated: And for one engaged in action for the sake of pleasure, with a one-pointed mind day and night, there is mostly only suffering. From this observation, one attains equanimity.

analyzed: sā ṣaṣṭhī tuṣṭiḥ supāram iti abhidhīyate
translated: That sixth satisfaction is called well-crossed.

analyzed: katham punar su pāram iti ucyate
translated: How, then, is it called well-crossed?

analyzed: sukham anena pāram viṣaya arṇavasya prayānti iti
translated: Because one easily goes by this to the other shore of the ocean of objects.

analyzed: yadā tu sati pūrva doṣe
translated: But when there is the previous fault,

original: sati vā grāmanagaranigamasanniveśādyupāyānuṣṭhānādvā kṛtaviṣayarakṣo yogī kṣayadoṣamupanyasyati / katham /
analyzed: sati vā grāma nagara nigama sanniveśa ādi upāya anuṣṭhānāt vā kṛta viṣaya rakṣaḥ yogī kṣaya doṣam upanyasyati katham
translated: or when the yogi, having practiced the means such as living in villages, towns, and markets, protects his objects from destruction, he points out the fault of destruction. How?

analyzed: yena dravyeṇa mohāt vā rantum icchanti dehinaḥ
translated: The very thing by which embodied beings desire to enjoy out of delusion,

analyzed: tat eva eṣām vināśi tvāt bhavati arati kāraṇam
translated: that itself becomes the cause of their sorrow due to its destructible nature.

analyzed: yatna upāttāḥ su guptāḥ ca viṣayāḥ viṣaya eṣiṇām
translated: The objects sought after by those who desire objects, though carefully guarded and attended to,

analyzed: paśyatām eva naśyanti budbudāḥ salile yathā
translated: are seen to perish just like bubbles in water.

analyzed: na tat asti jagati asmin bhūtam sthāvara jaṅgamam
translated: There is no being in this world, moving or unmoving,

analyzed: pratyakṣataḥ numānāt vā vināśaḥ yasya na īkṣyate  tasmāt vināśiṣu āsaktānām putra dāra gṛha ādiṣu
translated: whose destruction is not seen either directly or by inference.

analyzed: mama iti buddhim yatnena buddhimān vinivartayet
translated: Therefore, the wise one should carefully turn away the notion of mine from those attached to perishable things like children, wife, house, etc.

analyzed: iti etasmāt darśanāt mādhyasthyam labhate
translated: Thus, from this view, one attains equanimity.

analyzed: sā saptamī tuṣṭiḥ sunetram iti ucyate
translated: That seventh satisfaction is called good eye.

analyzed: katham punar sunetram iti ucyate
translated: How, then, is it called good eye?

analyzed: sukham anena ātmānam kaivalya avasthām nayanti iti sunetram
translated: It is the good eye because it leads the self to the state of kaivalya (isolation) through this (knowledge).

analyzed: yadā tu satsu pūrva doṣeṣu prasaṅga doṣam upanyasyati
translated: But when the previously mentioned faults are present, he states the fault of logical consequence.

analyzed: katham prāpta viṣayāṇām indriyāṇām tad abhilāṣāt nivṛtiḥ tat sukham
translated: How? The cessation of the senses whose objects have been attained due to the absence of desire for them is happiness.

analyzed: viṣaya jighṛkṣayā ca duḥkham
translated: And suffering is due to the desire to grasp objects.

analyzed: prāptiḥ api eṣām anupaśāntaye tad upabhoga kauśalāya ca yasmāt āha
translated: Attainment is also for the sake of not pacifying them and for the skill in enjoying them. Since it is said:

analyzed: yadā prabandhāt viṣayī viṣayān upasevate
translated: When one, due to a series, enjoys objects,

analyzed: tadā asya itas tu abhiprāyaḥ sutarām saṃpravartate
translated: then his desire for them proceeds all the more.

analyzed: atas pi yena puruṣaḥ śamayet vaḍavānalam
translated: Therefore, by which the person would extinguish the submarine fire,

analyzed: na indriyāṇi upabhogena viṣayebhyaḥ nivartayet
translated: he would not turn away the senses from objects by enjoyment.

analyzed: tasmāt viṣaya samparkam asamartham nivartane
translated: Therefore, the contact with objects is incapable of turning away

analyzed: indriyāṇām parijñāya nirāsaṅga matiḥ caret
translated: the senses. Having fully understood this, one should wander with an unattached mind.

original: ityetasmād darśanānmādhyasthyaṃ labhate sāṣṭamī tuṣṭiḥ sumārīcamityucyate /
analyzed: iti etasmāt darśanāt mādhyasthyam labhate sā aṣṭamī tuṣṭiḥ sumārīcam iti ucyate
translated: From this view, one attains equanimity. But the eighth contentment is called Sumāricha.

analyzed: katham sumārīcam iti ucyate
translated: How is it called Sumāricha? It is said:

original: arcateḥ pūjārthasya śobhanamarcitaṃ viṣayasaṃganivṛttasya yogino 'vasthānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: arcateḥ pūjā arthasya śobhanam arcitam viṣaya saṃga nivṛttasya yoginaḥ bhavati
translated: The beautiful worship is the state of the yogi who has turned away from attachment to objects.

analyzed: yadā tu pūrva doṣeṣu hiṃsā doṣam upanyasyati
translated: But when he mentions the fault of violence among the previous faults,

analyzed: katham an upahatyāni abhūtāni viṣaya bhoga anupapatteḥ
translated: how? Because it is impossible to enjoy objects without harming others.

analyzed: upabhogaḥ hi nāma manojña abhyavahāraḥ
translated: For enjoyment is said to be the use of pleasant things,

analyzed: strī sevā
translated: the service of women,

analyzed: haya gaja nara ādibhiḥ yānam iti evamādi
translated: riding on horses, elephants, men, and so on.

analyzed: tatra manojña abhyavahāra cikīrṣuṣā tad aṅgānām go jāvi balīvarda strī puruṣa ādīnām avaśyam upaghātaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: There, one who desires to use pleasant things must necessarily harm the limbs of that, such as cows, goats, sheep, bulls, women, men, and so on.

analyzed: anupaghāte vā viṣaya anupapatti prasaṃgaḥ
translated: Or, if there is no harm, there is the consequence of the impossibility of objects.

analyzed: striyam āsevamānena anyāsām strīṇām mātṛ pitṛ bhrātṛ prabhṛtīnām ca
translated: For one who serves a woman, there is the harm of other women, of one's mother, father, brother, and so on.

analyzed: anyathā tad abhāvaḥ haya ādīnām
translated: Otherwise, there is the absence of horses and so on.

original: tasmādupabhogārthināvaśyamanyopaghātaḥ kāryo nihitadaṇḍena vā viṣayopabhogastyājya iti / āha ca
analyzed: tasmāt upabhoga arthinā avaśyam anya upaghātaḥ kāryaḥ nihita daṇḍena vā viṣaya upabhogaḥ tyājyaḥ iti āha ca
translated: Therefore, one who desires enjoyment must necessarily harm others, or one must abandon the enjoyment of objects with a hidden punishment. And it is said:

original: yathā yathā hi viṣayo vṛddhiṃ gṛhṇāti dehinām /
analyzed: yathā yathā hi viṣayaḥ vṛddhim gṛhṇāti dehinām
translated: As the enjoyment of embodied beings increases,

analyzed: apaghātaḥ tad aṅgānām tathā eva asya vivardhate
translated: so the harm to its limbs also increases.

analyzed: tasmāt an icchan anyeṣām prāṇinām deha pīḍanam  santoṣeṇa eva varteta tyakta sarva paricchadaḥ
translated: Therefore, not wishing to cause bodily pain to other living beings,🔽one should live content alone, having renounced all possessions.

analyzed: satya vācaḥ praśāntasya sarva bhūtāni an icchataḥ
translated: For one who speaks the truth, is peaceful, and does not wish harm to any being,

analyzed: bhāva andhakāra anta jñānam acireṇa pravartate
translated: the knowledge that puts an end to the darkness of existence soon arises.

analyzed: iti etasmāt darśanāt mādhyasthyam labhate
translated: Thus, from this teaching, one attains impartiality.

analyzed: sā navamī tuṣṭiḥ uttamā abhayam iti apadiśyate
translated: But that ninth contentment is called the highest fearlessness.

original: katham / uttamaṃ hi prāṇināṃ sarvebhyo hiṃsābhayamiti tadapagamāduttamābhayamiti /
analyzed: katham uttamam hi prāṇinām sarvebhyaḥ hiṃsā bhayam iti tad apagamāt uttama abhayam iti
translated: How? For living beings, the greatest fear is from all kinds of violence. Therefore, due to the removal of that, it is called the highest fearlessness.

analyzed: āha arjana rakṣaṇa lakṣaṇayoḥ api tuṣṭyoḥ para upaghāta doṣāḥ
translated: It is said: But even in the two contentements characterized by acquisition and protection, there are faults of harming others.

analyzed: apadiṣṭaḥ syām api ca
translated: And in this one also, it is indicated.

analyzed: tatra katham anayoḥ viśeṣaḥ pratipattavyaḥ iti
translated: There, how should the difference between these two be understood?

original: ucyate na / viṣayabhedāt /🔽tatra yeṣāmarjanarakṣaṇe pratyādriyate viṣayī tadarthinā pratyanīkānāmavaśyamabhighāto 'nuṣṭhātavya ityādāvuktam /
analyzed: ucyate na viṣaya bhedāt  tatra yeṣām arjana rakṣaṇe pratyādriyate viṣayī tad arthinā pratyanīkānām avaśyam abhighātaḥ nuṣṭhātavyaḥ iti ādau uktam
translated: It is said: No, because of the difference in objects.🔽There, for those who are averse to acquisition and protection, it has been said that for those who seek that, the inevitable harm of adversaries must be carried out.

original: iha tu yeṣāmevārjanarakṣaṇe tadanupaghātenāśakyo viṣayopabhoga ityetadvivakṣitam /
analyzed: iha tu yeṣām eva arjana rakṣaṇe tad anupaghātena aśakyaḥ viṣaya upabhogaḥ iti etat vivakṣitam
translated: But here, it is intended that for those very ones, the enjoyment of objects is impossible without harming them in acquisition and protection.

analyzed: tasmāt asaṃkīrṇam etat iti evam ambhaḥ prabhṛtayaḥ nava viṣayebhyaḥ saṃga dveṣa nivṛtti hetavaḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: Therefore, these nine, beginning with water, are explained as the causes of the cessation of attachment and aversion towards objects.

analyzed: te jñāna virahitānām yoginām tuṣṭi śabda vācya tām labhante
translated: For yogis devoid of knowledge, they attain the state denoted by the word contentment.

original: jñānināṃ tu vairāgyaparvasaṃjñitā svāsu svāsu tattvabhūmiṣu siddhā eveti // //
analyzed: jñāninām tu vairāgyaparva saṃjñitā svāsu svāsu tattva bhūmiṣu siddhāḥ eva iti
translated: But for the wise, they are accomplished in their own respective stages of reality, under the name of the stage of detachment.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: Kārikā

analyzed: āha prāk apadiṣṭam aṣṭadhā siddhiḥ iti tat idānīm abhidhīyatām iti  ucyate
translated: It is said that eight kinds of accomplishment were mentioned earlier. Now that should be explained. It is said:

analyzed: ūhaḥ śabdaḥ dhyayanam duḥkha vighātāḥ trayaḥ suhṛd prāptiḥ
translated: Intuition, scripture, study, three kinds of relief of suffering, acquisition of a friend,

analyzed: dānam ca siddhayaḥ ṣṭau
translated: and giving are the eight accomplishments.

analyzed: tatra ūhaḥ nāma yadā pratyakṣa anumāna āgama vyatirekeṇa abhipretam artham vicāraṇā balena eva pratipadyate
translated: Among them, intuition is when one understands a desired object by the power of investigation, apart from perception, inference, and scripture.

original: sādyā siddhiḥ tārakamityapadiśyate tārayati saṃsārārṇavāditi tārakam /
analyzed: sā ādyā siddhiḥ tārakam iti apadiśyate tārayati saṃsāra arṇavāt iti tārakam
translated: That is the first accomplishment, called star-like. It is called star-like because it delivers one from the ocean of worldly existence.

original: yadā tu svayaṃ pratipattau pratihanyamāno gurūpadeśāt pratipadyate sā dvitīyā siddhiḥ sutāramityapadiśyate /
analyzed: yadā tu svayam pratipattau pratihanyamānaḥ guru upadeśāt pratipadyate sā dvitīyā siddhiḥ sutāram iti apadiśyate
translated: But when one, being obstructed in one's own understanding, learns from the teacher's instruction, that is the second accomplishment, called well-star-like.

analyzed: katham bhava saṅkaṭāt taranti iti
translated: How? Because by this [means] one crosses over the danger of continued existence even in the present life.

original: yadā tvanyopadeśādapyasamarthaḥ pratipattumadhyayanena sādhayati sā tṛtīyā siddhiḥ tārayantamityapadiśyate /
analyzed: yadā tu anya upadeśāt api asamarthaḥ pratipattum adhyayanena sādhayati sā tṛtīyā siddhiḥ tārayantam iti apadiśyate
translated: But when one is unable to understand even through the instruction of another, and accomplishes [understanding] through study, that is the third accomplishment, and is called delivering.

original: tadetat tāraṇakriyāyā adyatve 'pi avyāvṛtatvāt mahāviṣayatvāt tārayantamityapadiśyate /
analyzed: tat etat tāraṇa kriyāyāḥ adya tve pi a vyāvṛta tvāt mahā viṣaya tvāt tārayantam iti apadiśyate
